name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning. On the occasion of the Day of Remembrance that is celebrated today, I would like to recall the memory of all the victims of the foibe and the exodus from their lands of the Istrians, Fiumani and Dalmatians in the post-war period.  What has happened imposes an obligation on us to keep our memories alive. Those of us who defend the values of peace, justice and freedom have a duty to honour the victims of that tragedy.  Our Europe is not only a political response to those persecutions, it is also one of the fundamental drivers of the process of integration between democratic countries. I would ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to observe a minute's silence.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the state of play of the EU vaccination strategy against COVID-19 (2121/2541(RSP)). I would like to thank the President of the Commission for being here with us and I would like to thank Minister Zacarias, whom I give the floor to on behalf of the Council.

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, since the start of the Portuguese Presidency, this is the second time that the Council, the Commission and Parliament have come together to discuss our joint efforts to progress on the vaccination strategy to fight COVID-19. Unfortunately, since our last debate, the situation has not improved. Europe is still facing challenging times due to the pandemic. The spread of the virus remains worrisome in most Member States, including my own. New variants of concern have emerged, making it necessary to follow strict measures to contain the disease, while the vaccination of our population has not progressed as quickly as we would have wished.  So it’s time to redouble our work – not to lower our ambition or wish away real practical difficulties. At the same time, we must not forget what we have achieved so far. The EU vaccination strategy has been an example of unity and solidarity in action. It was motivated by – and has achieved – real tangible benefits. It has allowed an equitable and fair distribution of vaccines amongst Member States, so that all EU citizens can now have access to the vaccines in an equal fashion.  We have had three COVID-19 vaccines approved in less than a year and are expecting a few more to come in the near future. We have begun vaccination campaigns across all Member States. All these are remarkable milestones following a path of solidarity. And right now, my country knows better than most that European solidarity is more than just words. It’s action. And Portugal is very grateful for the numerous offers of assistance and concrete support it has received from several Member States. We knew that during the first stages of our vaccination campaigns, the availability of the vaccines would be limited. This is why we had to prioritise certain groups, like elderly people and health care workers, in our national vaccination strategies. But the recent news of delays in vaccine deliveries by some producers is a source of concern to which we must react in real time.  Vaccine production is a complex process, especially on this unprecedented scale. The truth is that companies may have overestimated their production capacities. We need to make sure that companies respect the contracts signed and deliver on their commitments. Countries need to know how many vaccines will become available and by when, in order to plan their vaccination campaigns, and we need this data to work. This is crucial.  Recently, the Commission has also put in place an export authorisation mechanism for COVID-19 vaccines, and this will allow us to understand where the vaccines produced in the EU are being distributed. In both cases, transparency is paramount to increase citizens’ trust in this process.  We, as Council Presidency, are willing to contribute to this endeavour. Prime Minister António Costa, together with the President of the Commission, wrote a letter to all Heads of State and Government inviting Member States to remain united and combine efforts with industry to ramp up the supply of vaccines and production capacity in Europe. They also presented some concrete ideas on how to improve our fight against the different variants of the virus. Also, the European Council will meet on 25 February to continue articulating our joint response to COVID-19. The General Affairs Council will prepare this discussion, and we will continue to work intensively at the technical and political level.  This effort should also help us to roll out the COVID-19 vaccines at global level. Solidarity cannot stop at European borders. Fair access to vaccines for low- and middle-income countries is consistent with our values and is in our own interest. We will not be safe until everybody is safe.  We also need to put more effort into communication. Citizens have the right to factual information, and we need to convey such information as clearly and transparently as possible. At the same time, we need to keep monitoring carefully the vaccination campaigns in close collaboration with the EU bodies in order to be able to address other possible challenges at an early stage and take appropriate action. We all know this will be a long process – longer and more complex than we ever expected, be it at the level of public health or as regards the social and economic repercussions of the pandemic. As the President of the Commission put it: it’s a marathon.  Vaccination is a powerful tool in our response to this crisis, but it will take time before a majority of the EU population is vaccinated. We still have to keep working together for the common good, enduring social distancing, wearing face masks and taking all other protective measures that we can until we finally beat this virus. Walking on a thin path between what has worked since the Middle Ages and the impressive technological achievements of the present, we need to stay together. We need to stay united. This is the only way out.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: Präsidentin der Kommission. – Sehr geehrter Herr Präsident, Frau Ministerin, sehr geehrte Damen und Herren Abgeordnete! In Polen sind bis Anfang Februar 94 % des medizinischen Personals und 80 % der Bewohnerinnen und Bewohner von Altenheimen geimpft worden. In Dänemark sind es in den Altenheimen sogar 93 %. Und in Italien haben wir bis heute mehr als 4 % der Bevölkerung, die eine Impfung erhalten haben. Diese drei Beispiele zeigen, dass die Impfkampagne in Europa vielerorts an Fahrt aufgenommen hat. Insgesamt sind in Europa seit Dezember 26 Millionen Impfdosen ausgeliefert worden. Mehr als 17 Millionen Menschen wurden geimpft. Und wir werden so hart wie nur irgend möglich arbeiten, dass wir unser Ziel erreichen, nämlich, dass wir bis Ende des Sommers 70 % der erwachsenen Bevölkerung in Europa geimpft haben. Dennoch ist es eine Tatsache, dass wir heute beim Kampf gegen das Virus noch nicht da sind, wo wir sein wollen. Wir waren spät dran bei der Zulassung, wir waren zu optimistisch bei der Massenproduktion und vielleicht waren wir uns auch zu sicher, dass das Bestellte tatsächlich pünktlich geliefert wird. Wir müssen uns fragen, warum das so ist und welche Lehren wir daraus ziehen können. Aber lassen Sie mich dennoch zunächst mit drei Punkten beginnen, von deren Richtigkeit ich tief überzeugt bin: Es war richtig und es ist richtig, dass wir Europäerinnen und Europäer den Impfstoff gemeinsam bestellt haben und nun solidarisch teilen. Ich mag mir gar nicht ausmalen, was es bedeutet hätte, wenn einige wenige große Mitgliedstaaten sich Impfstoff gesichert hätten und der Rest leer ausgegangen wäre, was das für unseren Binnenmarkt bedeutet hätte und für die Einheit Europas. Es wäre wirtschaftlicher Unsinn und es wäre das Ende unserer Gemeinschaft. The second point I am deeply convinced of: the same solidarity must also be shown with our partners in our neighbourhood and across the world. This is also a matter of stopping the spread of the virus to reduce the likelihood of mutations. The access to vaccines for low- and middle-income countries is therefore as much about our own interest as it is about solidarity.  This is why we set up COVAX, the facility in which high-income countries can finance the access to vaccines for low- and middle-income countries. As Team Europe, that is the Member States and the European institutions, we have provided EUR 850 million, making us one of the biggest contributors to COVAX, and COVAX start delivering vaccines as of this month. And I am sure that this House will agree that we need more, because our responsibility extends far beyond Europe’s border.  Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, le troisième point que je voudrais soulever concerne notre approche et notre processus. Nous avons fait le choix de ne pas prendre de raccourcis en matière de sécurité ou d’efficacité. Nous assumons ce choix pleinement. Il n’y a pas de compromis à faire lorsqu’il s’agit d’injecter une substance biologiquement active chez une personne en bonne santé, et c’est pourquoi nous nous appuyons sur le processus de contrôle de l’EMA, notre agence européenne des médicaments. Oui, cela veut dire que l’approbation prend trois à quatre semaines supplémentaires. Ce temps supplémentaire est un investissement essentiel pour la confiance et la sécurité. Et oui, il y a également des leçons à tirer de ce processus et nous le faisons déjà. En premier lieu, nous devons améliorer le partage de données des essais cliniques avec l’EMA, c’est pourquoi nous lançons dès maintenant un nouveau réseau européen d’essais cliniques. En parallèle, notre commissaire de la santé, Stella Kyriakides, va travailler sur un cadre réglementaire pour permettre à l’EMA d’examiner les vaccins aussi rapidement que possible. Une autre leçon à tirer concerne la production de masse de vaccins. À juste titre, nous étions tous très concentrés sur le développement du vaccin, mais globalement, nous avons sous-estimé la difficulté liée à la production de masse. Il faut normalement cinq à dix ans pour produire un nouveau vaccin. Nous l’avons fait en dix mois. C’est une grande réussite scientifique. Nous devrions en être fiers. Mais en quelque sorte, la science a dépassé l’industrie. La production des nouveaux vaccins est un processus très complexe. Il n’est simplement pas possible de mettre en place un site de production du jour au lendemain. De plus, ces vaccins intègrent jusqu’à 400 composants et la production implique jusqu’à 100 entreprises. C’est pourquoi nous avons créé une task force pour accroître la production industrielle des vaccins sous l’autorité de Thierry Breton, notre commissaire en charge du marché intérieur. L’objectif est de détecter les problèmes et d’aider à les résoudre. L’industrie doit s’adapter au rythme de la science.  Indeed, industry has to match the groundbreaking pace of science. We fully understand that difficulties will arise in the mass production of vaccines, but Europe has invested billions of euros in capacities in advance and we urge the Member States to plan their vaccine rollout. So now we all need predictability and this is why we introduced the export transparency and authorisation mechanism. To be very clear, we do not intend to restrict companies that are honouring their contracts with the European Union and there is an automatic exemption for exports to the EEA countries, for the Western Balkans and the rest of our neighbourhood, for humanitarian needs and for the 92 low and middle—income countries covered by COVAX. So Europe is always ready to help, but we insist on our fair share.  As far as the mechanism goes, allow me a word on the island of Ireland. The bottom line is that mistakes were made in the process leading up to the decision, and I deeply regret that. But, in the end, we got it right, and I can reassure you that my Commission will do its utmost to protect the peace of Northern Ireland, just as it has done throughout the entire Brexit process.  Honourable Members, the battle against the virus is a marathon and not a sprint. It needs foresight, endurance and stamina. Almost every day we hear news of different variants and how contagious they are. We do not yet have the full picture when it comes to the effectiveness of treatments and vaccines on new strains, but we do know these variants will continue to emerge and we do know that we need to anticipate and prepare immediately.  This is why we are starting our new Health Emergency Response Authority (HERA) project now by launching our preparedness agenda against new variants next week. We need to adapt our regulations to this new challenge. We need rapid sequencing and clinical characterisation of new mutations, and we need systematic sample and data sharing across networks and labs because, to defeat the virus, we need to know as much detail about it as possible.  In parallel, we will tackle a second challenge. As I said, we are dealing with completely new mRNA vaccines never manufactured at scale before. One of the current bottlenecks is, for example, linked to just two synthetic molecules. If we had just 250 grammes more of these molecules, companies say they could produce one million more doses of vaccine. This is why we need more coordination on the supply of key ingredients. We need to improve manufacturing surge capacity and we need to boost cooperation between the public and the private sector. This will be the core task of HERA because we must ensure that, despite future mutants, we will be safe next winter and beyond.  We all know that the information we have on the virus and the vaccines can change by the hour, and this is why we will set up a contact group between the European Parliament and the Commission. I will do my utmost to ensure that you are able to scrutinise all the contracts we have signed because I know that trust needs transparency.  Meine sehr geehrten Damen und Herren Abgeordnete, wir alle geben unser Bestes im Kampf gegen das Virus – in den Familien, in den Städten und Gemeinden, in den Mitgliedstaaten und auf der europäischen Ebene. Und das sollten wir uns gegenseitig nicht absprechen. Wir werden diese Herausforderungen nur bewältigen, wenn wir zusammenhalten. Unser gemeinsamer Feind, das ist das Virus. Es lebe Europa!

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, we are facing an unbelievable stress test for European societies, for the European way of life, for all Europeans. No handshakes, no visits to grandparents, no holidays, no meetings with colleagues at work ... only the home office and always with this terrible mask. The vast majority of our citizens understand the measures introduced mainly by the Member States and each region. This is the only way to protect one other. We have to thank citizens for their understanding and especially those who work in the health sector every day. They are the heroes. Everyone wants to escape, and the only chance of doing so is through vaccination. That is the light at the end of the tunnel, and probably the only light we currently have. And that is the reason for the disappointment. That is the reason for the huge expectations that we face when we speak with our citizens. To avoid further frustration among citizens, I think the most important thing is to tell the truth. First of all, demand is much, much greater than production. We need time. The second message is, yes, the EU made all the mistakes; not everything was perfect over the last weeks and month, and in the coming weeks and months there will be time to draw up a report here in Parliament about what can be learned from the developments of the last few weeks.  Another message is to tell people that many of the decisions we took together were the right decisions. The key decisions were right. First, without the European Union, without our fight for more money, for research, there would have been no chance of developing the new types of vaccine. That was right. It was also right not to distinguish between first and second-class Europeans. To keep Europe together was right. It was also right that we as lawmakers established the principle of liability rules for companies, for distributing products in Europe, and these rules must also be respected by pharmaceutical companies. The Brits gave up. We as the EU did not. And fourth, safety first. It will probably take a little bit of time, but we didn’t initiate a fast track procedure with the European Medicines Agency (EMA). We expect our experts to do a proper assessment, and that was right. Dear colleagues, again, not everything has gone perfectly in the last year, but the key decisions were right, together with the governments, together with the Parliament, together with the Commission. I also want to say a personal word to Stella Kyriakides. As our Health Commissioner, she is currently at the centre of the storm, and I want to underline that she, and the whole team, did a great job for Europe. So thank you so much, Stella, for your work.  Meine sehr verehrten Kolleginnen und Kollegen! Neben der Sicherheit müssen wir jetzt Ambitionen an den Tag legen.  Meine Fraktion hat gestern einen Elf-Punkte-Plan vorgelegt, wie wir die Produktion schnell anheben können. Wir brauchen Investitionen in Produktionen, 10-Milliarden-Programm. Wir müssen verhindern, dass sich die Mutanten weiter verbreiten, uns darauf auch vorbereiten. Wir müssen alle Produktionsanlagen mobilisieren, eine große Pharmaallianz schließen, um die Produktion nach oben zu kriegen.  Wir brauchen als Zweites eine Zusammenarbeit der westlichen Welt, einen G7-Gipfel, wo wir mit den Vereinigten Staaten und Großbritannien reden, um den Egoismus, der dort herrscht, zu überwinden, Produktionsketten nicht zu unterbrechen.  Wir brauchen als Drittes jetzt: ja, die Bereitschaft zur Kooperation mit den anderen Staaten, aber auch nicht naiv zu sein als Europäische Union. Ein Exportverbot von in Europa produzierten Impfstoffen muss aus unserer Sicht nach wie vor als Option auf dem Tisch bleiben. Wenn Großbritannien keinen AstraZeneca-Impfstoff nach Europa liefert, warum sollten wir dann den BioNTech-Impfstoff nach Großbritannien liefern?  Zum Weiteren brauchen wir endlich gemeinsame Einreiseregelungen. Vor einem Jahr hat meine Fraktion bereits gefordert, gegenüber China im gesamten Schengen-Raum eine einheitliche Einreiseregelung zu machen. Wir schaffen es auf der Ministerseite – bei den Innenministern – bis heute nicht, dass wir endlich gemeinsame Regelungen für Südamerika oder für Südafrika bekommen. Das ist das Scheitern der Innenminister auf diesem Kontinent, weil das nicht gelingt. Bis heute warten wir auf Entscheidungen in diesem Bereich.  Dänemark und Schweden haben jetzt angekündigt, einen nationalen Impfpass auszustellen – ein Zertifikat für die Bürger bereitzustellen, dass sie geimpft sind. Täglich werden Zehntausende von Europäern geimpft, und wir schaffen es nicht, einen europaweit standardisierten Impfpass zu Verfügung zu stellen, damit wir die Bewegungsfreiheit im Schengen-Raum besser bewerkstelligen können. Auch eines der Themen, das umgehend angepackt werden muss.  Zu guter Letzt: die Wirtschaft, die Arbeitsplätze. Gestern haben wir das grüne Licht für den Recovery and Resilience Fund gegeben. Grünes Licht für den Wiederaufbau Europas. Auf mitgliedstaatlicher Seite haben bisher nur vier Staaten die own resources—Entscheidung gefällt. Die restlichen Staaten sind nicht in der Lage, grünes Licht zu geben, dass die Gelder endlich fließen können. Es liegt also enorm viel vor uns.  Ich habe vorher von den Mitarbeitern im Gesundheitswesen gesprochen, die eine große Verantwortung tragen. Sie sind im Krisenmodus. Wenn sie Rückschläge haben, dann wird nicht intern diskutiert, sondern dann wird angepackt, dann wird weitergearbeitet, dann wird versucht, das Beste zu machen. Und das sollten wir Europäer jetzt auch machen.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Madam President, I know these are difficult times. Of course we have been fighting COVID-19 for almost a year and we all want to, as soon as possible, return to longed-for normalcy. Precisely because of the seriousness of the situation, I invite all of you to stand for a moment and look at the situation without turmoil, setting aside what can be struggles between one another and also setting aside those partisan interests which are legitimate, of course, in this Parliament, but this is not the time now. This week I've heard of everything: fiasco, disaster, failure... These messages from some, full of criticism and frustration, finally, are in citizenship, in a citizenry that is very frustrating and which is currently expecting a lot from the European Union. Because it seems that at least citizens are clear: that we are not going to get out of this crisis on their own and that it takes the efforts of all to get out of this situation. Let us therefore leave the catastrophic messages and try to see reality as it is because only in this way can we take the necessary actions. Head and responsibility. With the criticisms that are necessary, of course, but also with a constructive spirit and institutional loyalty. Adopting a European vaccine strategy was the right decision. The only one, actually. What we should have done from the beginning. Let's remember the start of the crisis. Let's remember those fights between countries about hoarding respirators or masks. It doesn't look like the save who can be the best solution right now. In the United States, President Biden has proposed, with respect to vaccines, to activate the Defense Production Act, an exceptional measure. And it speaks of a titanic logistical effort to get the vaccine to every corner of the United States. In the European Union we face the same challenge for a larger population than the United States, but with fewer instruments. Yes, fewer instruments, because the European Union has no competence in the area of health and has less perfect economic governance in this regard and more unfinished. And that's why we had to create new instruments on the fly and do it all in record time. We have carried out in record time the implementation of unemployment reinsurance. In record time we have implemented the recovery and resilience plan. And in record time there has been, with everyone's efforts, a vaccine that, under normal circumstances, can take ten years for the president to produce. Nearly a year after the start of this crisis, we are much closer to seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. It has been a collective effort, with many sacrifices and seeking solutions with solidarity. The delay in delivering AstraZeneca vaccines has caused disappointment and mistrust and it is normal for citizens to want to know what is going on. And that is why this Parliament must have the capacity to have a monitoring tool with the European Commission, so that we can have all the information. A follow-up committee to which Commissioner Kyriakides, to which Commissioner Breton, in charge of health and industry respectively, can come to account, which is what they have to do with this Parliament. Because we have invested a lot of public money, EUR 2.7 billion from the European Union and EUR 750 million from the Member States. It's a lot of public money and we need to have an accounting to know what we're doing with those public media. I know that there are other discussions on the table that are also necessary, but what we have to focus on right now is to foster partnerships and consortia between pharmacists from the European Union and third countries to accelerate vaccine production. Let us not fall into European nationalisms either. This is a global problem and requires a global look. The export control mechanism can be used to control where vaccines in the European Union are, but it should never hinder global vaccination agreements. Let's stop for a moment, please. The European Union has purchased 2.3 billion vaccines for a population of 500 million people in the Union. The Union's responsibility goes far beyond our borders. As we vaccinate, we must have a global commitment to all those who also need our solidarity. If the start has been delayed, we are now increasing capacity, and the Commission estimates that supply will grow exponentially. That's what we have to work on right now. The percentage of population vaccinated in the European Union must be increased to also give a message of certainty and tranquility. Let's stop catastrophic that doesn't help at all and let's be able to draw lessons because we're still on time, because it's never too late to learn. And a very important one is that the European Union needs to be equipped with more instruments. Thus, in the face of future challenges, we will be able to react more quickly and effectively. In my group the Commission will always find a demanding but responsible partner to seek solutions and build that Europe of solidarity.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam President, thank you for being here in the European Parliament. My group has insisted that this debate take place, and I think it is very useful at this stage. I have no doubt that vaccination is the project that will most mark Europeans during this mandate, beyond the recovery plan that was voted on yesterday and which is also in itself a revolution. This vaccine affects every European in what is most precious: his health, that of his loved ones and the return to freedom. This is the first time in history that Europe has such a responsibility to European society in the health field. Boris Johnson's attitude gives an idea of what could have happened in Europe if each Member State had been left to face these challenges alone and the Member States had been put into competition. This European responsibility, which is in fact expected by the citizens, must materialis itself in a Europe of health complementary to what the Member States are doing, so that the European institutions and the Commission have clear responsibilities with regard to health. But fully supporting the collective approach does not mean giving a blank cheque. On the contrary, it is a requirement, because Europe has no right to make mistakes. That is why we are so demanding here in Parliament. Each delay must be explained, justified and accompanied by solutions to remedy it.  One day, we will also have to explain what could have been done better in the contracts that were negotiated with the vaccine producers. But now every new challenge must be anticipated, prepared and accompanied by solutions. I welcome the mission you have entrusted to Thierry Breton alongside Commissioner Kyriakides, to also meet the industrial challenge of mass production alongside that of health. This mission must cover the urgency and the medium term: the structuring of a fully independent, European and operational vaccine sector, because it is conceivable that such challenges may arise again.  Europe needs this capacity not only in terms of research, where progress has been made, but also in industrial production and production. Thanks to our research strike force and production capacity, we have a responsibility as the European Union, not only for the Member States, but also for those around us. In the Balkans, on the African continent and beyond, Europe must be able to bring vaccines as quickly as possible. We must continue the COVAX initiative and further mobilize the international community in cooperation that must be established. We must also rise to the democratic challenge by being open and transparent at every step. I am counting on you, Madam President, to set up this contact group with the European Parliament as soon as possible, as you have announced, and we are also organising ourselves in Parliament, so that at every stage this house will be informed in real time of the difficulties, the new challenges and the solutions implemented.  This past year has shown us that it is only through transparency and clarity that we gain the confidence of our citizens in the European project. Today's debates are also part of this process.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs von der Leyen, I am a little surprised today. It is clear that the vaccination campaign was the greatest challenge together with the economic recovery of the European Union for 2020 and 2021 and, as previous speakers have said, the Commission has played a lot of work and a lot of work is being done on this campaign. Whether you wanted to take the stage or not, you promised that joint management would bring benefits and a resolution of the problem as soon as possible, but that was not the case. Today I would have expected you, Mr von der Leyen, to have explained to us in detail what has gone wrong, because it is clear to everyone that something has gone wrong, and to have explained to us in detail what the Commission will do to make up for lost ground. Instead, you began your speech by reminding us of some of the supposed successes of this vaccination campaign, and you also mentioned my country, which was one of the most affected. But these successes are only perceived here, the citizens and governments are not perceiving them. Frankly, the spectacle we have seen in recent weeks of disagreements and disagreements even within the College of Commissioners has certainly not been a recognition of one's mistakes and a start.  I have been here for seven years now and I have understood one thing: in my opinion, the biggest shortcoming of the European Union is the inability to recognise its mistakes and to correct the course in time. Unfortunately, it was done with some rules and with some choices with which we dealt with the eurozone debt crisis in 2010 and today, unfortunately, my impression is that it is also being done on this vaccination campaign.  It is not for me to remind you of the importance, above all, of two aspects. The first is health, which is what we care about most, as my colleagues used to remind us: the faster we implement this campaign, the more lives we will save. The other aspect, secondary but equally important, is that of the economy: we know that those who first vaccinate, the sooner they will emerge from this crisis. The data tell us that compared to our competitors outside the European Union, compared to the United Kingdom, the United States, India, China and Israel, we are currently several weeks behind. A few days ago, some analysts estimated the additional damage from these delays at EUR 90 billion.  I would like to see one thing, Mr von der Leyen: to clearly acknowledge your mistakes, because everyone is wrong, we are not infallible, and that is certainly complex management, and you tell us clearly what concrete steps you want to take. You have set yourself an ambitious objective, which is to vaccinate 70 % of the European population by September, but seeing the state of affairs seems to us to be an unrealistic objective to date.  So, very realistically, tell us clearly what the objectives are, and why an entity such as the European Union, which has so many well-paid professionals and lawyers, is unable to draw up a contract or to be respected by pharmaceutical companies. Because it is clear that there is a problem if a Union, which is a geopolitical power, fails to enforce the contracts it writes from certain multinationals. This is a big problem.  So I expect realism, I expect clear objectives, whatever they may be, and unfortunately we will once again, in my opinion, have to assess the fact that the European Union among the parts of the developed world will still be the last to emerge from this crisis. This is an element of profound reflection.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, four months ago it was still uncertain when we would have a safe and reliable vaccine on the market. Now three have already been authorised in Europe and more are expected. This is indeed a marvellous achievement. However, we must now look at the things that need to be urgently improved and, most importantly, we need to ramp up production – not just by a little, but by a lot! And, yes, that should have been done earlier. And, yes, that costs a lot of money. But continuing in and out of lockdowns for months on end will also come at a tremendous cost. We also need to draw lessons concerning the transparency of the contracts the EU made with those pharma companies. In order to strengthen public trust and allow for democratic control – also of this very Parliament – we need to have full transparency of the contacts. And yes, dear Commission, dear colleagues, we also need to be self—critical. This crisis has painfully demonstrated the value of public research and of good public healthcare systems – areas that have been constantly thrown under the bus in an attempt to save money in recent years. Now we see how lethal such an ideology of austerity can be.  Let’s learn together and invest in our resilience, and in our social fabric of public services, education and digitalisation. But we cannot pay attention to only our own well-being. We have a responsibility in the world. While the rich countries are buying up vaccines and fighting over who gets the doses first, some regions of the world risk being totally left behind and of getting their shots with years of delay. That is a real catastrophe. Nobody is safe until everyone is safe. Vaccines need to be accessible and affordable. We must do everything in our power to scale up production massively and ensure a just, global distribution. This is possible under WTO rules, and I wish the European Commission would be more supportive in using this flexibility. Intellectual property and bureaucratic barriers should not stand in the way of ensuring a more rapid and equal distribution globally. Overcoming the pandemic will unfortunately still take time, and we cannot relax efforts to limit the spread of the virus, especially given the new variants. But reducing cases massively will not happen as long as some liberties are allowed in some EU countries, while forbidden in other countries, like ski resorts or shopping centres. It will also not happen as long as testing and tracing efforts remain highly disproportionate across Member States. Of course, no single approach will work for everyone, but we will not overcome the pandemic while retreating to international egoisms. Yes, the ambition to tackle this crisis together and to deliver the vaccines together, ensuring equal access for all EU citizens, was – and remains – the right recipe. I therefore urge the Portuguese Presidency to continue in this spirit of cooperation and to ensure that Member States come closer together in implementing common guidelines to contain COVID—19.

name: Beata SZYDŁO
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear! Europeans have trusted the European Union and the Member States of the European Commission to effectively lead to a vaccination process. Any European who wants this, who has the will, has the right to receive a vaccine in a timely manner. Our future, our health, our economy depend on it – that's all that unites us in the idea of the European Union.  But the question today is: has the European Commission handled this process?  Didn't she fail? You have set Poland as an example, among other things – as an example of success. Yes, I agree that the government is doing a great job of immunisation and could have vaccinated many more Poles, all those who want Polish to take advantage of the possibility of vaccination. There is only one "but" – there is not enough vaccines. Yet the European Commission, by signing the agreement also on behalf of Polish, taking over this part of the responsibility for the health of European citizens belonging to the Member States, has also taken on the responsibility of effectively enforcing those agreements.   On February 8, another batch of one of Polish was due to arrive on The New York City. It will arrive on 11 February and not 100% as the agreement envisaged, but 20% less. What's next? What will be the next months and weeks? Today, this is the European Commission's most important task – to effectively enforce those agreements that have been signed so that each Member State receives the amount of vaccines it needs. There is no more important task today. Solidarity matters, but effectiveness also matters. A lot of words, a lot of declarations... The Commissioner spoke here about the future. And well, let groups be formed, let teams be formed – but they are to be effective.  Apart from the ritual tools of indignation or declarations, does the European Commission, in addition to the various resolutions that are adopted, have an effective tool to enforce those agreements that I will emphasise have been signed once again? In this agreement, the European Commission has committed itself to the Member States, towards Europeans, that the right amount of vaccines will go to these countries in a timely manner. This is the most important task today and that is what the European Commission must focus on.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the band The Left. Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, I am not going to go down four paths. I have a key question for you today: how could the European Commission agree to go to bed like this in front of pharmaceutical companies? In the management of the vaccine strategy, I have the feeling, Mrs von der Leyen, that the leaders of the Big Pharma have made the law for you.  First of all, on negotiations and contracts: it is opacity at all levels. No information on the negotiations, despite the requests of our Parliament. Only three contracts made public thanks to our citizen pressure. And this is what they look like, for those who have not seen it: all the most important information, such as the price, the delivery schedule or even the details of the liability clauses are hidden. For the other contracts, we will have to wait for the labs to deign to publish them. Because yes, they're the ones who decide.  On deliveries, then, delays in a mess and no schedule met. Without any penalty, of course. Because yes, it's the labs that decide.  On patents, same scandal. These vaccines have been developed with billions of euros of public money, but patents remain the exclusive property of "Big Pharma". As a result, states cannot produce the much-needed doses on a very large scale. Because yes, it's the labs that decide.  And finally, the icing on the cake, 15 billion profits, 15 billion turnover and 20 to 25% margin for Pfizer, which is also delighted with its success, its blockbuster, I quote them. Sanofi did not find a vaccine, but on the other hand, they found 400 research positions to be eliminated and 4 billion euros of dividends to distribute. The labs are taking out the champagne. Because yes, they're the ones who decide.  What an admission of helplessness, Madame von der Leyen! Is it not up to us here in this chamber to make the law? We are able to impose on our citizens an unprecedented restriction of our freedoms, but we would be unable to set the rules for "Big Pharma"? The Commission must be held to account. That is why, on behalf of our left-wing group in the European Parliament, I call for the immediate creation of a commission of inquiry into the Commission's responsibility for this disaster. We have a right to know, because after all, these vaccines were paid for with our money and the equation must be simple: public money, public contracts, patents in the public domain. It's as simple as that. For decades, we have been leaving everything, right down to our health, in the hands of the private sector, and now we are deadlocked. Here we propose a reverse path: to put an end to the omnipotence of laboratories. It is time to drop patents and ensure that no profit is made on the pandemic. This is the only way to be able to quickly vaccinate the entire planet, rich and poor countries, to reassure citizens who doubt, by taking vaccines out of the clutches of multinationals, to hope to relive after a year of mourning, anxiety, isolation, precariousness. This should be your role, Mrs von der Leyen, if you had not abdicated in front of the labs when the population can no longer take it, the insecure are hungry, the young people despair. Let's take back control of the labs, take health out of the market and finally consider vaccines as common goods of humanity, not the cash machine of shareholders.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: Mr President, Madam President, the European Union should defend the lifting of the intellectual property rights of vaccines available on the market, as permitted by the agreement of the World Trade Organisation which governs these issues. There are two good reasons for this.  The first is that all the capabilities of the pharmaceutical industry in all countries of the world must be mobilized in order to speed up the global immunization process, because the health crisis and the resulting economic crisis are global. It would make no sense to vaccinate only a part of the planet. And compulsory licenses under Article 31 of the AGREEMENT on intellectual property aspects are not enough. But there's a second reason. Manon Aubry talked about it, these vaccines were paid mainly for public funds: $8 trillion of the $14 trillion their overall development cost, and $2,000 by philanthropy. As Ellen T. Hoyn said, it was unwise for our governments to return this public money unconditionally. The suspension of the patent should have been a condition for public funding. But now we can correct this grave mistake if the Union accepts the lifting of the patent at the World Trade Organisation and does not oppose it while the countries of the South now demand it.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I understand anyone who is frustrated, who is angry and who is tired, because we still have to comply with these strict measures. But as one expert in Germany recently said, unfortunately the virus is not tired. It has even got a boost from the mutations. And we are seeing what it is like in Portugal: if you loosen up too quickly and too early, things will get bad. That is why we must all stick to the measures. And we also need to protect more at the borders. Mr President of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen! Open borders are a noble objective, but we have a dangerous virus mutation here – three in fact – and that is why it is necessary to put more pressure on us to protect Europe as a whole, but also to look more closely at the regions, that we have controls, that the mutations do not spread too quickly. On the subject of vaccinations, I would like to disasincen two myths. It is always said that Europe has ordered too late. But first of all, the responsibility here lies primarily with The most important vaccine from BioNTech at Pfizer. Pfizer has refused to accept the right of any European to sue if the company makes a mistake, as resourceful journalists have written several times. And I would like to see the person who says that I do not want Europeans to have the right to sue a company that makes a serious mistake when it comes to harm. I want someone to sit down here and say, "I don't care about the law anymore." The Commission has not done that, and it cannot be criticised for that, dear friends. And then they say it wasn't enough money. Only the 2.7 billion from the ESI are mentioned. But if you add up the money that the Member States are already spending to pay for the vaccines with the ESI, you get 22 billion. So not everything went perfectly, but a lot of things are also twisted, and the basic decision was the right one. We must come to Europe together through this crisis, and we should continue to uphold that, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Colleagues, the Council and the Commission, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his We are still in a crisis, a very serious crisis with high levels of infection and new mutations. We do not know how the pandemic will develop or how long it will last, but we have a vaccine and vaccines give hope to humans.  Without a doubt, EU cooperation is absolutely crucial for all EU citizens to have access to vaccines. Eu-wide procurement is important for the Member States, and we now have a vaccine in place, but the problems we have seen are still worrying. I am thinking of Astra Zeneca and their delayed deliveries. I am thinking of the Commission's attempts to use trade and export restrictions as means, as in Northern Ireland. I am thinking most of all the citizens who are now waiting for their vaccine, and I would therefore like to make three clear demands of the Commission. The Commission must ensure that the agreements are complied with, that the agreements are transparent; it's about trust. The Commission must secure supplies, increase production and speed up member states' efforts to carry out vaccinations, so that we reach our goal. And the Commission must take the collective leadership of our common vaccine strategy so that vaccination is equal and fair.  We must all work together at a difficult time. We must ensure fair access to vaccines throughout the EU, but also globally. "No one should be left behind," so many people say. Then we must also help our developing countries to have access to the vaccine. The virus knows no bounds. That is why it is so important that the vaccine is not hindered by any limits either. This is the time to act quickly.

name: Pascal CANFIN
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, we stand with you when you recall that 27 different contracts, 27 different prices, 27 different access conditions instead of a single European contract would have led us to a much more chaotic situation than we have today. We are with you when you recall that in the United Kingdom, fewer British citizens have been vaccinated with two doses than, on average, in the European Union. The European Union's so-called delay with the United Kingdom is simply due to the fact that we have followed the procedures. We have followed the advice of the European Medicines Agency and we are vaccinating with two doses to fully and not partially vaccinate European citizens. While more British citizens are half-vaccinated, they are not vaccinated - when you look at the full numbers, more Europeans are vaccinated than the Average British. We are with you, but we are also demanding, Madam President. That is why, since September, we have been calling for more transparency. We look forward to the contact group you have announced to us. We are delighted that with Stella Kyriakides, Thierry Breton is now working every day with the laboratories to produce more. Because that's what it's all about: producing more, producing more. It is not enough, Ms. Aubry, to put the patent in the public domain to have the technical solutions to produce more. It's obviously the easy way and it doesn't solve anything. Nevertheless, Madam President, we want even more transparency on contracts, of course this has been pointed out. But also on the month-by-month data, on the number of doses expected state by state to achieve our collective goal of vaccinating more than half of the adult population by the summer. These figures are not public. How do you want European citizens to know what is the credible path that will take us to this goal if these figures are not public? Only three states have made them public - I salute Denmark, Sweden and France. What are everyone else doing? It is also a strong demand from the European Parliament towards you and the governments in each of the member countries.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, major crises reveal the effectiveness or inefficiency of an organisation. Failing during the financial crisis in 2008, failing during the migration crisis in 2015, failing at the beginning of the health crisis with no anticipation or coordination of the action of the Member States, the European Union promised us that it would catch up on vaccines. The European Commission has centralised the ordering and distribution of vaccines. But all the countries that have organized outside the European Union are doing better today. The British are 12 million vaccinated when France, Spain and Italy are only two million. Germany was careful to buy doses in addition to the European group order. Hungary had the ability to buy vaccines from Russia and China. But many countries, including France, are tied up in the scheme led by the European Commission.  As always, when the European institutions are in check, technocrats seek to identify culprits. Faced with the slow pace of astraZeneca deliveries, Mrs von der Leyen, you have decided to temporarily re-establish the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland to block exports. You have thus reopened with incredible lightness the wounds of the Irish conflict. And to top it off, you tried to put the responsibility on your trade commissioner. We can also point out the absurdity of the European Union's position towards Russia. For almost seven years, you have been imposing sanctions on Russia, the consequences of which we are suffering, particularly on our agricultural products. Seven years later, at the beginning of the crisis, we are forced to use Russian wide-body aircraft to supply masks by airlift between China and Europe. And now, after expressing doubts about the Sputnik vaccine, we're going to have to beg for it. What about the pitiful performance of High Representative Josep Borrell in Moscow in recent days? He had nothing to offer, so he got nothing. What a mixture of arrogance and ignorance to claim leniency for Navalny and access to the Sputnik vaccine without offering any consideration. Then asking for additional sanctions adds the grotesque to the humiliation. The opacity in the contracts, the inability to enforce them, the delays in deliveries, the ridiculous diplomacy... Unfortunately, your repeated fiascos show that there is even less European strategy because there is no strategist. Europeans did not deserve to suffer this in addition to the health crisis.

name: Diana RIBA I GINER
text: – Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, I would like to begin this speech by recognising the efforts that the Commission has made and continues to make to ensure the supply of vaccines in all Member States. Still, it is obvious that many things have not been done well; we must denounce, for example, the lack of transparency that has existed in contracts with pharmaceutical companies and even with the data that has been obtained through clinical trials. In recent months we have seen how important solidarity and empathy is to overcome this crisis, and that is that no one is safe until we are all safe. Therefore, the inequalities that exist to access the vaccine on the planet is not only a health problem, it is also an economic, moral and human rights problem. While 39 million vaccines have been delivered in rich countries, only twenty-five, I repeat, only twenty-five units have been supplied in poor countries. We must do everything we can to increase production and open up intellectual property rights to meet a global need; Only in this way will we achieve a more just and equal post-COVID—19 world. For all this, the Verts/ALE Group is committed to large-scale renewed investment, both with COVAX and existing pharmaceutical production, and we support a temporary exception to intellectual property barriers under WTO rules.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Under Stefan Löfven, the Swedish Government has given away the right to procure corona vaccines to the EU. The European Commission is now responsible for purchasing the vaccine. Like everything else for which the EU is responsible, this too now looks like a major problem. We see it clearly now that countries outside the EU, such as Israel, Canada and the UK, have access to vaccines from German BioNTech and Pfizer. We already know what the Commission will say as a statement. They will say that we need a health union and that failure was only because europe has too little power, as usual.  It is tragic that Prime Minister Löfven not only supports this Commission but also wants to give it even more power. The European Commission's negotiating strategy on the purchase of vaccines came too late and was too focused on price instead of the terms of delivery. What is amazing is that, on the one hand, the Commission is critical of the price of the vaccine that can save lives, but, on the other hand, is presenting the biggest budgets in the history of the European Union, which go to a lot of waste. Sweden, which is among the hardest hit by the pandemic, will also provide other EU countries with rescue packages that go to citizens' wages in Spain or bridges in Italy. It is lives we should save, it is not the euro.  The Commission wanted to take action against covid-19 but failed to secure deliveries. This is why Sweden today has a shortage of vaccines and is far behind many countries outside the EU in vaccinating its citizens. The Sweden Democrats naturally want Sweden to take responsibility for the vaccine strategy.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Mr President, thousands of people still die every day from COVID-19. However, we now have a vaccine. My common sense says: let's make sure that this gets to as many people as possible as quickly as possible. Let us make sure that this is produced by as many companies as possible. It's about sharing knowledge and technology and spreading the vaccine faster than the virus. Instead, however, we see that the big pharmaceutical companies are refusing to cooperate on patents and intellectual property. We have paid european money for basic research at the university and for the production and development of the vaccine. We even took an investment risk: 'de-risking' was what the Commissioner called it so nice. And yet these companies refuse to share. Billions of profits for them, too few vaccines for us. In Belgium, the vaccination strategy is stalling today because the companies are not delivering. The hunger for profit from shareholders costs lives. Let us please oblige the big pharmaceutical companies to share their knowledge, Commissioner. Fewer dividends for shareholders, but more vaccines for all of us. No profit on pandemic!

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Madam President, following the historic establishment of the EU recovery fund last year, the EU has received once again a golden opportunity to demonstrate strength and solidarity in fighting an unprecedented crisis by making vaccines available for 27 Member States, regardless of whether they are rich or poor, powerful or small. There would have been a double benefit: providing protection for 450 million citizens and demonstrating European unity, but by now it is quite evident that the Commission’s management was far from perfect.  The announcement of export controls on the vaccine effectively triggered a hard border in Ireland, something which we have been trying to avoid for three years. And the EU lags behind for whatever reason: only 3% of our population is vaccinated. How on earth do we want to champion COVAX if we can’t even get our own population vaccinated? Even with all the blunders you are quite right, Madam von der Leyen, it is still better that we have the Commission in the driver’s seat, but, all those that have faith in European cooperation are losing hope, and all those that are happy to see it stumble are getting a boost.  There are two questions that are arising. What are the lessons learned? Some of that you have answered already, but who is responsible? I hope to receive an answer to that question.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: – Voorzitter, wij zijn vanochtend naar het Parlement gekomen voor nog een vaccinatiedebat. We zijn ongetwijfeld gefrustreerd dat niet alles gaat zoals we willen. Denk echter eens aan de tienduizenden verpleegkundigen in de hele Europese Unie die vanochtend weer naar het werk zijn gegaan, wetend dat ze zich aan het voorbereiden zijn op een nieuwe “code zwart”, op de muterende versie van het virus die grote gevolgen kan hebben voor de opnamecapaciteit van ziekenhuizen. Zoals zij volhouden, moeten ook wij volhouden en bijsturen waar dat nodig is. Ik denk dat de voorstellen van de Europese Commissie van vanochtend in die zin goed zijn. I listened very well to the European Council and I heard one omission and one understatement of the year. The omission Manfred Weber has already mentioned, it’s our external borders. It’s unacceptable that one Member State has closed off its airspace for South American flights, yet you can easily still fly to Madrid and then have free access to the entire European Union. We asked a year ago to fix this and to have a common approach, and we insist on that today. The understatement of the year was of course the remark that companies may have underestimated their capacity to produce. Yes, hiccups are normal, and then together we try to fix it, like with Pfizer, and I think we did. But some companies give the impression that they are acting in bad faith, and there the EPP believes that with regard to pre-financing that was given up front to set up production, we should be able to take that away, take it back if companies don’t deliver. And I know I’m over time, but I want to make one important remark when it comes to ... [...] papier dat heel erg geduldig is. Wat op papier staat, wordt niet altijd geleverd. And with the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, we need to be careful that if fill and finish is done in the US, we get it back. Ook premier Rutte moet nog met president Biden spreken. Dit onderwerp hoort bovenaan zijn lijstje te staan.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, Madam Minister, the stakes are high. To combat the pandemic, to minimize the health, social and economic consequences as much as possible, we all know that vaccination is certainly the best solution. To do so, Madam President, you have chosen the Community approach and the joint acquisition of vaccines at European level, and we can only praise your decision. To secure European citizens, you have taken responsibility by turning your attention to safe and effective vaccines authorised by the European Medicines Agency, at a time when others were making different safety choices. Thank you for these choices. But today, there is an urgent need to vaccinate, especially the most vulnerable. First of all, we must win the trust of European citizens in the vaccination process and there can be no confidence if there is no transparency. We must have access to the contracts signed between Europe and the Big Pharma - access to all contracts, access to liability clauses. We must be able to play our full role as a defender of the rights of our fellow citizens, and thank you for your proposal to create a contact group between the Commission and Parliament. Then, Madam President, you told us that the vaccine is a global common good and I agree with you. But if that is really the case, we need to be able to produce the necessary vaccines as a whole as a whole. Mobilize all the tools you have at your disposal to force pharmaceutical companies to honour their contracts! It is not conceivable, at the heart of the pandemic and the progression of variants, that we are blocked by the inability of laboratories to produce sufficient vaccines. The scientific miracle of creating these vaccines cannot be sabotaged by logistical chaos. And even though production is complex, the sharing of patents by industry through voluntary licenses to other laboratories is essential. It is imperative that we increase the production of vaccines on European soil in order to respond to the emergency and continue to develop our solidarity at the international level, whatever the cost. This must be the meaning given to Europe of health, because there will be no way out without solidarity.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, I strongly support a joint European approach in vaccine procurement. It shields us from toxic divisions and helps smaller Member States like my own.  But, colleagues, we have been calling for transparency of vaccine purchases for half a year now. It is very good to have a commitment on this, but, Madam President of the Commission, we should have heard this speech last June. It was clear from the very beginning that extra efforts need to be made to increase transparency. What we have heard until now was a lack of clear communication, avoiding parliamentary scrutiny and refusing questions from journalists. In a crisis it’s a recipe for disaster. Uncertainty is everywhere these days, and our citizens expect to have all the information about timelines, production, delivery, what they will get when, and how. If something goes wrong, they also deserve to know why. Who took the decision to refuse millions of extra doses of the frontrunner vaccines? Who negotiated? Which Member States were dragging their feet? We need to know that because accountability and scrutiny are not unnecessary nagging, but are the cornerstones of democracy and our number one job as parliamentarians. We will fulfil this role in the future as well.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very The President of the Commission continues to confidently sell this disaster, which she is responsible for, as a vaccination strategy. To want to sell this chaos as a strategy is a mockery of the citizens of the EU.  Unfortunately, this is not a strategy, but an unreasonable incompetence. This failure has severe and concrete consequences: millions of citizens fear more than ever for their health and economic existence. Vaccinations should, according to all policymakers, show the way out of this pandemic – without, of course, any vaccination requirement. They are therefore crucial.  But there is a massive shortage of vaccines in the EU. It is not enough for even the most vulnerable groups. Others, on the other hand – I am just mentioning Israel, the United States, and the United Kingdom – are making considerable progress in vaccinating their populations. These countries provided vaccines early, independently and successfully. Happiness that was denied to the citizens of the EU. The EU, on the other hand, has once again failed: the Brussels Eurocrats ordered too late, too little and completely inadequate.  They have not been able to obtain even the cheapest and presumably weakest vaccine, which is not even approved in Switzerland, but they have excluded the apparently highly effective vaccine from Russia from the outset – presumably out of simple political aversion.  It is no wonder that you, Mrs von der Leyen, are now looking at Britain with disapproval. The British Government has done its duty to order and pay for the vaccines on time, and has proved how to do it without the EU.  We remember that the EU used the Good Friday Agreement for years to put pressure on the British side in the Brexit negotiations. Now she did not hesitate at first to break this for her own benefit. It was only the public pressure that led them to continue to allow vaccine exports through Northern Ireland in the first place. This is a declaration of bankruptcy. The hastily enacted export ban is nothing more than a helpless attempt to somehow conceal one's own total failure. The EU Commission, let us be honest, never had a strategy. And she still doesn't have it.  Mrs von der Leyen, as German Minister of Defence you have sent soldiers with broomsticks into the manoeuvre. Even then, they did not have the decency to draw personal conclusions.  Here from Brussels, the consequences of its incompetence are becoming increasingly fatal: it is costing lives. It is destroying the economic existence of millions of citizens on a large scale, as a result of the lack of vaccines.  Stop blaming everyone else. Stand by your responsibility. Do Europe and yourself a favour: finally step back, it is overdue.  Mrs von der Leyen apparently preferred to leave the sitting a minute before I spoke – because she had to expect me to say that.

name: Tilly METZ
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, first of all, congratulations on the publication of a third contract. However, at the risk of repeating myself, I would not characterize this as transparency when essential clauses are blackened. Why not respond to the formal request for access to all contracts filed in accordance with the treaties by the Greens? This would allow you to stand on the side of the citizens. There is so much uncertainty and criticism of the Union on such an important issue that I do not understand why you are staying on the industry side for the time being. What about the clauses of the contracts, precisely? Are the Commission and the Council so confident in the pharmaceutical industry that they have not seen fit to set specific production capacity targets? And what about the inclusion of the most vulnerable in clinical trials? These are all legitimate questions, and it is clear that industrialists are playing a contractual game that has nothing to do with the public interest. I am convinced that the Union has done its best, but I would like to be able to prove it to the citizens, and for that we need transparency.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr President, Mrs Von der Leyen, in your state of the Union speech, you declared the European Union a health union. The joint procurement of vaccines would be the first test and, above all, it had to be in solidarity, only through the EU. It sounded like you had faith in that. Member States waited while countries such as Israel, the US and the UK bought in. The EU did not move forward and three months were lost. Vaccination programmes are now delayed everywhere, causing more people to die. You are politically responsible for that. I worked at the Commission for seven years. The Commission is a policymaker, not a deal maker on the free medicines market. You then ordered an export ban, creating a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland. Very stupid, as you said yourself. As chairman, you blame other Commissioners. Very weak. I did not vote for you because I was familiar with your work as Defence Minister in Germany, with similar problems with regard to procurement and lack of collegiality. In short, you have failed. You're politically responsible. That is why I am asking you to resign as President of the European Commission.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Madam President, President of the Commission, unfortunately, since our last debate, the vaccination situation has not improved. We had the opportunity to read three contracts on the purchase of vaccines, but what we read from them rather worried us and I will be specific. Thanks to a poorly written contract with AstraZeneca, this company is simply making a "good day" of us. How is it possible that the Commission has concluded contracts which do not contain any penalty mechanism for producers who do not fulfil their obligations? In a normal state, the government would be politically responsible for this fiasco. And I'm asking, who's carrying it here? The President of the Commission looks as if nothing is wrong. It's not the only contract bluff. We know from the treaties with CureVac and Sanofi that agreements often prohibit the export of surplus vaccines to third countries, even in the case of donations for humanitarian reasons. At the same time, the EU is planning to provide its surpluses to poorer countries, we have heard it here, we have to help developing countries and so on. How are you going to do that? Are you going to break your contracts with these companies? All right, I applaud you. But in that case, break patent contracts, saving hundreds of thousands of lives.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the third wave of the pandemic is also just around the corner in Greece, with workplaces, transport and schools without shielding and with the public health system stripped. Here and now we demand protection measures and real requisition of private structures without compensation and their inclusion in the state plan. The European Union and the governments that have put forward the necessary vaccine as a panacea have been disproved in order to keep the public health system and primary care in a miserable state and to speed up commercialisation in order to treasure clinicians, to multiply private-public partnerships and to pay very expensively. A condition that also undermines mass vaccination. The shortcomings and delays lead to economic and geopolitical competition between imperialist centres between pharmaceutical companies. The European Union's intervention criterion is group profits. The patent means ownership and only its abolition meets popular needs. Against the exploitative system we claim the supply of vaccines from any approved source, as well as all medicines that can contribute to the treatment of the disease.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Madam President, a year ago the start of the COVID-19 crisis. From the outing of the outing, the European institutions were clear that whatever it took to deal with it had to be done, but being together. It was imperative to move away from health nationalisms if we wanted to win this battle for the virus in the shortest time possible. The Commission, with Parliament's support, was therefore right to lead the strategy to accelerate the research, manufacture and deployment of safe and effective vaccines, with the public and private sectors collaborating.  It also succeeded in the implementation of a centralized purchase, with equal and equitable access for all Europeans. And in European solidarity, participating in COVAX to support developing countries, to win this fight across the globe.  It is now up to us to get it right and meet the stated goal of 70% of Europeans being vaccinated and immunized by the end of summer. And so we have to get ahead of the future. To do this we need absolute transparency and compliance with contracts by the pharmaceutical industry. We must monitor the supply chain and ensure that the entire pharmaceutical industry in Europe with the capacity to produce vaccines and also its supplements reddoble production. We need to use vaccines more efficiently, and I'm talking about dosages. We also need to fund permanent funding for research against virus variants. And increase mass tests to stop these new outbreaks, also at our borders. To protect our freedoms we must improve and homogenise processes and that is why we must also require each Member State to require transparent national vaccination plans, infrastructures for mass vaccination, contingency plans and that they comply with the transmission of data to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control. We will achieve this, together, with transparency and in a constructive spirit.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: – Madam President, we are still in a critical phase of the pandemic and Europe’s challenges are far from over. There are worrying signs of a third wave, and we also see different mutations rolling across our Union. It will hardly come as a surprise as there are concerns that the roll-out of vaccines is not proceeding fast enough. Recent setbacks in terms of delay and insufficient production capacity from the company AstraZeneca have mercilessly shown how fragile the situation is. The setbacks raise important questions about production capacity in the EU and how we as a union can avoid being too dependent on one single actor, especially when that actor fails to deliver. I would welcome more clarity on how this situation happened and how the Commission intends to adapt its strategy accordingly to avoid this occurring again in the future. We also need more data on the transparency and the efficacy of the different vaccines in different age groups. I would like to hear more about what the Commission is doing about that.  It is clear that our action needs to be stepped up. The Union needs to ensure that the amount of vaccine is enough for our citizens in our Member States. The public has the right to know what the Commission is doing and to know that the Commission is leaving no stone unturned. Access continues to be crucial for the success of this strategy. We expect to see concrete action from the Commission to boost the production of vaccine in Europe and the EU because this is the bottom line. We need to ramp up a stable production for Europe’s joint and cooperative strategy to be a success and to reach the necessary vaccine coverage in our Member States. The S&D Group stands with the Commission a hundred per cent on this, and you have our full support for the joint procurement process and for making sure that the vaccine is safe and efficacious for citizens.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Madam President, from debate to debate, and we have had a few now since the beginning of the pandemic, all questions are asked. Solidarity, protective equipment, vaccine ordering, squeals, delays, patents, which we are still talking about this morning... These are key issues, but they are not the priority. The urgency today is to vaccinate. Point.  A small 3% of the European population is vaccinated, 40% in Israel, 10% in the United States, in a complicated climate, but this is another debate. What is this recipe, the American recipe? It is the sacred union. It's the private and the public, it's all the living forces, it's defense, agriculture, health, it's the CDC (centers for disease control) around the BARDA (Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority). To quote Moncef Slaoui, Mr Warp Speed in the United States, "RNA was being killed while factories were being built." And then the bottom line is this massive investment of $15 billion.  All this, mutatis mutandis, is the specifications of our future European agency: HERA is for tomorrow.  In the meantime, subcontracting, licensing, cooperation between the labs, all of this is in the contracts - Article 5, paragraph 4, for example, for the AstraZeneca contract - and we are now, with Thierry Breton, jumping the deadlock.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Mr President, vaccination is still the best way to limit the economic damage of the pandemic. The Decision of this Commission to abuse corona vaccination in order to infringe the health policy of the Member States is therefore quite a mistake. Member States that have already been quite far along with their own initiatives, such as Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and France, are now complaining that their naivety towards the European Union has driven them far too quickly into the gripping, slow, bureaucratic arms of the Commission. The quasi-religious dogma that all the powers exercised at EU level lead to better results is once again obsolete by the facts. The idea that small Member States would have been worse off in the field of vaccines without the intervention of the European Commission amounts to a lack of confidence in their own ability. This is perhaps only true for Belgium, where the administrators are even more inept if possible and have even decided to destroy the strategic stock of mouthcaps, allegedly to make way for more reception for would-be refugees. This, in turn, is the result of another blunder by the European Union: mass immigration. The issue of the export ban was the highlight and only made the situation worse: a perfect example of the blind amateurism in which the Commission seems to be falling away when it comes to the United Kingdom. The conclusion is that the vaccination issue is not the commission's first blunder, but certainly the biggest to date. This second-class Commission should resign so that the European Union can be given a whole new approach.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, we have tried to speed up the virus, but we see that the virus is moving faster than our technologies. As a result, where the first clinical trials of vaccines began, the variants multiply and thwart the efficacy we expected from vaccines. The mutations will continue. Living innovates faster than biotechnology. This shows the impasse in the current European vaccine strategy, which has relied heavily on new types of genetic vaccines. This means that research on perhaps more traditional vaccines will have to be increased, to increase the immunity they can cause, and above all to develop national health infrastructure. There is an urgent need to strengthen virus sequencing and to develop rapid and reliable tests, including salivary, that can identify variants in order to better track their spread. Madam President, in these circumstances, how do you plan to reorient the vaccine strategy in Europe? Finally, there is a lot of talk about transparency, but you still haven't published the contracts with Pfizer and Moderna. We also want data to be accessible in clinical trials, especially since these contracts are available in the United States and not in Europe.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Mr President, I have been a Member of this Parliament for over a year and a half and I have gained 25 years of experience in various other parliaments. I've never seen such a flawed right of control as here. I immediately requested access to the contract with AstraZeneca. This request was refused after the reply period was repeatedly postponed. I have appealed to the Commission, but I have never received an answer to that either. The appeal dates from 29 October and is of course now obsolete by the facts, as the contract has been published due to circumstances. I, like several colleagues, have made several written requests for access to the Commission's vaccine purchase policy and vaccination strategy. These, too, have produced no or disappointing answers.  President Von der Leyen has said that trust is based on transparency. I would therefore ask her to answer the following pertinent questions: Have the drug manufacturers merely made an effort commitment or have enforceable agreements been made? What quantities and delivery dates are involved? Should the Member States fully safeguard the manufacturers of medicinal products from their liability? In the light of the export ban and the deply, albeit temporary, extension of a border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, with which the withdrawal agreement has been breached: do the contracts contain a priority clause or a clause concerning the most favoured nation, in favour of the EU?  How does the EU intend to increase supply at a time when the export control system is causing a delay in the chain? I am thinking, for example, of the complex project for multiple supply of Johnson & Johnson. Finally, how does the Commission itself intend to comply with the commitment it has made with AstraZeneca and to make every possible effort to help with the production difficulties, as has been contractually stipulated?

name: Chris MACMANUS
