text: – Madam President, it is unacceptable that the Commission didn’t see the potential of destabilising the Withdrawal Agreement and the Good Friday Agreement by proposing the use of Article 16 of the Irish protocol. Now we must ensure that the fiasco isn’t repeated, and part of that is picking up the phone to Dublin and Belfast. But it also needs a structural commitment with the north of Ireland at all levels, recognising its special status as defined by the protocol. Alongside consistent dialogue with the joint First Ministers, there also needs to be a systemic engagement with all levels of citizens, communities and their elected representatives. We must find a way to ensure that EU decisions that directly affect nearly two million people in the north of Ireland, currently without their input, is addressed and resolved. There must be no democratic deficit.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, one question for Commission President von der Leyen to begin with. Mrs. von der Leyen, do you think it's in the interest of pharmaceutical companies that this crisis ever actually ends? This whole crisis doesn't revolve so much about health as it revolves around control and money. If it were so much about health, it wouldn't be allowed to use diagnostic techniques that give us unreliable numbers of infected and dead, it wouldn't delay tens of thousands of cancer surgeries. Many diagnostic examinations that would detect the disease would not be delayed, and lockdown and fear campaigning would not devase the mental health of our citizens especially the youngest. There's so much talk about developing vaccines, putting the focus on the vaccine. Why not put at least a little focus on the development of the drug? Some countries around the world are developing a cure. Isn't an inexpensive and effective drug in the interest of the pharmaceutical industry or is there simply no money. As far as control in Croatia is concerned, let's say we have a situation that pensioners refused to get vaccinated with Astra Zenec because there is simply not enough information. Now there's talk of control, about Covid passports. Are you going to restrict the travel and movement of these people because they refuse to put something in their body that you don't even know how to tell them what it is that will affect them. Is that ethical? Citizens must be able to choose their own treatment.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Madam President, the European Union is facing a very great pressure. The vaccine is the only solution to minimise our medical crisis and give us the chance to restart our savings and get back to normal. We do not yet have clear answers on effectiveness to existing mutations, and we do not know whether vaccines will be effective for future mutations.  It is worth noting the rapidity with which researchers and pharmaceutical companies discovered vaccines against COVID-19. At the same time, they signed some agreements with the European Union, and the EU has not only provided financial support for research and the discovery of a vaccine, but has been a fair play partner with the pharmaceutical industry in recent decades. It is now time for the pharmaceutical industry to be fair to European citizens and those companies that have signed a contract with the European Commission to comply with the contract.  We will have to invest in increasing production, to continue to invest in research to have a weapon against mutations. We must also resist some temptations, such as banning exports of vaccines produced in the European Union, but also being vigilant, not allowing the vaccine to become a geopolitical weapon, as in the case of Sputnik. United and not divided, firm and not wavered, solidarity and not selfish, we will succeed.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we must start from one point. The Union's common strategy has made it possible, less than a year after the first case of coronavirus in Europe was identified, to have a safe vaccine in record time to combat the pandemic and equal conditions of access in all Member States. Does that mean everything's going well? No, but we would be making a mistake if we did not recognise the important progress europe has made in recent months, without which we would not be able to talk today about the objective of vaccinating 70 % of europe's adult population by the summer. The first mass vaccination, with all the problems that this entails. I'm going to face one. In recent weeks, the plan has been severely affected by delays in the production and delivery of vaccines by the pharmaceutical companies with which the Union has concluded contracts. This is a serious incident which prompts us to act on two fronts. Firstly, the transparency of all contracts, an instrument for imposing compliance with obligations. Secondly, the increase in the production of vaccines. The task force set up by the Commission to encourage pharmaceutical companies to cooperate, using industrial plants already able to contribute to the production effort, is a step in the right direction. Now, however, concrete numbers and prospects must arrive on this front. In the situation in which we are, delays or taboos are not acceptable, including that of dealing with the issue of voluntary or compulsory licences. If it is true that we are at war, take every useful initiative to have the vaccines necessary to save lives and get out of this pandemic as soon as possible.

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: Madam President! There is no doubt that the corona crisis requires common solutions. Nor is there any doubt that the Member States have been best served by the joint purchase of vaccines, especially small Member States, such as the one I come from. However, the Commission and the rest of us need to recognise that the last few weeks have certainly not been pretty. I would therefore like to ask the Commission whether it is not time to show a little bit of self-criticism. Recently, the President of the Commission admitted that the challenge of mass production of vaccines should have been tackled much earlier. And I would like to ask: why would it take so long for the Commissioner, the Commissioner responsible for the internal market, Thierry Breton, to be involved in this? We would have liked to have seen him on the pitch earlier, and one has to ask yourself – and I would like an answer to that – why it has not happened. On the whole, one has to ask: what could the Commission have done differently? I think we are owed answers to that, because self-criticism is necessary for us to move forward properly.

name: Peter KOFOD
text: Madam President! There's good news and bad news right now. The good news is that vaccines have actually been developed to combat corona, get us out of the shutdowns and into freedom. The bad news is that it is the European Union that is responsible for getting us the vaccines we so desperately need. While they are vaccinated in the UK, in the US and in Israel, Europe is at a terown. There is otherwise no limit to how much the EU system has mocked the British or shaken the heads of the Americans in recent years. But now the EU system is losing to the very same people in this house who have been completely counted under the floorboards. The Eu's role in this matter is straightforward. I think a lot of people in here will remember Comical Ali. The former Iraqi Information Minister, who during the Iraq War boasted to all the media how strong and how victorious the Iraqi army was, even if the reality was a total collapse. When it comes to vaccine strategy, I think the President of the Commission reminds me a little of Comical Ali. They have the self-praise in common, but unfortunately they also collapsed. Because in the European Union we are at a standstill. In the European Union, we have far too few vaccines and we have started too late. This means more sick and more dead and needlessly harsh and pro-economic restrictions and shutdowns across the continent. On the day we started vaccinations, we should even hear from the President of the Commission that vaccinations were the symbol of unity and a European success story. If the EU's view on vaccine purchases is that it has been a success, Then I dare not even think about what the disaster scenario would have looked like.

name: Jutta PAULUS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done I do not join the chorus of those who denounce mistakes or complain of a lack of transparency. On the contrary, I call on you to do everything you can now, to pursue every possible hope! Specifically, Harvard scientists have developed a cost-effective and simple approach to a vaccine. It is based on peptides of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which are applied by nasal spray. All information is published under a Creative Commons license, which means that everyone is free to use this knowledge. So far, however, only a few hundred volunteers have been tested. Without patentability, no manufacturer will invest hundreds of millions of euros in clinical trials. Can we afford to give up a chance just because we cannot make a profit from it? On the contrary, would it not be wonderful if we could create a public good with public funds? I urge you to get in touch with this project! Let the experts of the EMA check the vaccination procedure! After all, a public service vaccine would really be a dream!

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Madam President, the contracts concluded by the Commission with vaccine suppliers should have been published a long time ago, as is the case in Slovakia, for example, with all contracts with the state for a decade, and nothing terrible has happened. Finally, the Commission published the contract with Astra Zeneca, showing that it would publish the contract when appropriate. Contracts should always be published, so it is in the interests of the citizen and the public. The Treaties could also include a clause on the order in which the Union will receive vaccines and adequate sanctions for non-compliance with agreed conditions. I believe that in future the European Union will be more transparent in any procurements, it will certainly result in a better result.

name: Petros KOKKALIS
text: – Madam President, years ago, the best available science warned us of an upcoming pandemic, and yet our governments failed to prepare. As we enter the third wave, hundreds of thousands have died, our economies are devastated, and inequality has exploded.  The best available science, including our very own parliamentary research services, explicitly links the increased periodicity and intensity of zoonotic epidemics to anthropogenic biodiversity loss. Madam President of the Commission, you have rightly said that we have now entered the era of pandemics. Your Commission has greatly enhanced the remit of European integration by establishing the Recovery and Resilience Facility and achieving the common provision of vaccines. For years, however, best available science has been warning us of the apocalyptic consequences of anthropogenic climate change.  We cannot afford to fail to prepare again, for there is no vaccine for climate catastrophe. It is now clear to all, Madam President of the Commission, that the invisible hand of the market has proved impossible to regulate nature and ensure people’s health and well-being. You must obtain the IP rights and make sure every person on the planet is properly vaccinated. Do this and you will have the support of this House and the respect of history, or you risk both.

name: Dorien ROOKMAKER
text: Mr President, even Mr Borrell's ill-considered, amateurish visit to Moscow still contrasts positively with the Commission's action on the procurement of vaccines. I am referring to the soap opera surrounding the conflict with AstraZeneca. The Commission went into a fight with a supplier on which we are largely dependent. In fact, the Article 16 border arrangement with the British over Ireland was unilaterally cancelled, causing an international uproar and seriously harming the EU's standing. However, the citizens of Europe, who depend on you for their vaccination, want perspective. Full vaccination is the only real solution to a normal existence. It is a pleasant thought that the Commission has ordered enough vaccines to vaccinate everyone, but much more important to know when these orders are delivered and how many have now been delivered.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Chairman, millions of our fellow citizens have been vaccinated in the European Union since New Year's Eve, mainly older people and healthcare professionals. Replacement procurement avoided rivalry between Member States, allowing economically less developed Member States equal access to the vaccine. In doing so, the Commission has shown that there are no first and second class citizens in Europe, which is an extremely important message. The European Union has already approved for the use of three vaccines without gambling with the health of its citizens, respecting more rigorous safety standards than anywhere else in the world. We have this in mind every time we hear complaints about the European Union or the Commission. Of course things aren't ideal. We would all like vaccinations to progress faster, but that is why we must look to the future. To this end, I particularly welcome the transparency mechanism presented by the Commission. We need to know if someone is trying to export vaccines outside Europe while delivery difficulties persist in the Member States. Furthermore, in the event of a need, an export ban cannot be excluded as a last resort if public health reasons so require, and world trade organisation rules allow it. What is crucial is that the European Union acts more uniquely than ever. It further invests in the production and research of new strains and sanctions in the strongest possible breaches of contractual provisions in order to protect the interests of its citizens and its own credibility. I support the efforts of the European Commission, the Commissioner and everyone else so that we can overcome this vicious disease together along the way.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report When we were at the height of the eurozone crisis almost ten years ago, there was a memorable sentence. A memorable phrase, spoken by Mario Draghi, then president of the European Central Bank, at a conference in London: "Whatever it costs." That's the bar, let's get out of the small. I am not here to attack the Commission, but I am not here to defend it either. I want us to save lives, and that is the discussion that must be at stake.  When we talk about mistakes, we talk about mistakes, because we have to put them right. Of course, it was right that we in the European Union should order together. What else? No reasonable person would have proposed anything else.  Yesterday, however, we gave the green light to a reconstruction programme of EUR 750 billion. 750 billion to rebuild the European Union after the Corona damage. What is 2.7 billion in the face of a crisis threatening humanity? That was not enough and it needs to be corrected. That is why we need to take action now and change the tax. We are blocked because we do not have the capacity we need. Yes, indeed, it is about Europe, but it is also about the global south. Only when everyone is safe are we safe. That is why we must share patents. We must be pleased to see cooperation, cooperation. But we must also issue licences so that humanity can overcome this crisis as quickly as possible in the fight against time, in the fight against mutation.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Commission's vaccine procurement strategy has not met our expectations; our fellow citizens are disappointed and have reason to be: slowness is desperate. Those of us who have examined contracts have suffered a real shock: pharmaceutical companies do not commit to a fixed number of deliveries, but promise to do their best. The Commission has given too much importance to the price and pharmaceutical responsibilities, Commissioner, and acted frightened by anti-vaccines. The Commission has negotiated hard, but with the wrong objectives. Cheap, Commissioner, it's expensive. The emphasis on price and responsibility is a serious mistake. Huge loss of life and jobs is much greater than the few billion spent. Commissioner, there is only one priority: to vaccinate all countries in the world a lot and to vaccinate Europe quickly, not just Europe. COVAX does not have enough resources, they are 27 billion euros short. The world will not be free of the virus until all countries are. The time to invest is now.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Madam President, unfortunately Ms von der Leyen has already left the chamber, but anyway. First of all, we need to assess the work of the Commission in implementing the COVID—19 vaccination plans together with other issues on the economic side and foreign policy. We must then assess the responsibility of the President of the European Commission when it comes to dealing with these issues. As of Monday morning, for example, 3.7 out of 100 people have been vaccinated in Germany, 3.6 out of 100 in Belgium and 3.1 out of 100 people in France. Let us now compare that to the country that left the EU, the UK, with a rate of 17.6 per 100 people. That is five times more than the EU average. In the US the figure is 11.7 and in Iceland 5.1 people per 100 inhabitants have been vaccinated. In Israel, which is number one in the world, 63 people per 100 people have been vaccinated. The EU has often wanted to see itself as a powerful federation compared to other world powers, however, given this incompetence and confusion, it is an overregulated organism imbued with bureaucracy that is absolutely unable to deal with crises. I’ve often heard how countries are unable to deal with crisis-resolution on their own, and that is why we must all rely on the EU. The fact that the European Commission has been given a mandate to pursue vaccines will cause even greater economic damage to the Member States. However, in order to solve the economic crisis, the European Commission’s ingenious solution is to taking a huge joint debt, the real reason for which is the desire to move toward taxes across the EU. In this case, the question arises as to whether the European Commission is enjoying the ongoing crisis, as it is an excuse to offer a solution to the Member States, which is the granting of even greater powers to the EU. Is it not just a deliberately infected panic where people are being frightened by a virus that is killing everyone, even though we know today that the number of deaths is marginal compared to the total number of people infected? It is no secret that the European Parliament and the Commission are largely socialist formations, embodying an ideology in which the central government must guarantee unnatural equality and where the nation states should have nothing to moan about. To top it all off, the European Commission is also unable to cope with foreign policy, as evidenced by the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy going to Moscow, making a fool of himself, and allowing the Russian foreign minister to mock him, after which the President of European Commission fails to make any comments. However, the Member States are being told that we are united! We will have a common foreign policy, but our foreign policy will be dictated by Germany, France and the Spanish socialist Josep Borrell, who has become detached from reality. In this case, there is no other solution: the President of the Commission has to resign.

name: Kim VAN SPARRENTAK
text: – Madam President, we need to produce more vaccines, we need to do it quickly, and we should be able to do so. The COVID-19 vaccine is a vaccine that should belong to all of us. Years of public funding, public education and public research are at the core of it. And yes, it is true that pharmaceutical companies developed a vaccine very quickly, but should that be a reason to let them have a monopoly on a vaccine that is our only way to save our economy, save our health systems and, most importantly, save millions of people’s lives?  I think it’s very clear that Big Pharma is exercising its control over the vaccine, as we would expect any big corporation to do. AstraZeneca is not delivering on their contractual obligations. Pfizer is happily forecasting more than EUR 3 billion in profits thanks to the vaccine and there are hardly any license agreements in place with low—income countries.  It has already been said several times: ‘no one is safe until everyone is safe’. If this is taken seriously, I call upon the Commission and wealthy countries to stop blocking the proposal for a Trade Related Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) waiver, which would ensure that everyone in the world can have fast access to vaccines.

name: Joanna KOPCIŃSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The lack of general drug safety in Europe is not a new problem. For many years, there have been no clear recommendations and instruments that would actually support national drug safety plans, and the inability to meet the necessary vaccine production indirectly demonstrates the lack of innovative manufacturing facilities for our continent.  How does the Commission intend to provide real support to stakeholders in the vaccine production and supply chain and does the Commission take into account additional negotiations and discussions in the context of consistent security building at EU and national level in a spirit of subsidiarity in order to ensure real security across the continent?  Yes, it is true that together we are stronger, but the strength of the chain depends on the strength of its weakest link.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, it is less than a year since the virus landed in Europe in earnest and now we already have several vaccines that are already being vaccinated. This cannot be regarded as a complete failure, even though we now have a problem on our hands: production volumes and their deliveries, companies that do not keep what they promised. All possible production capacity must be made available and therefore companies must be required to be fully transparent. They must share knowledge and technology. The temporary breach of patent protection and/or the use of forced licences must be included immediately in the range of means. At the moment, the lack of transparency is a problem. It is a mistake to say that three agreements have been published. They have been concealed in such large parts that they do not allow democratic control of the Commission's activities, which is parliament's task. More than 2.7 billion public funds have been put into vaccine research and development. Without taxpayers' money, these companies would not have these vaccines and that is why we have the right and the duty to demand full transparency. Finally, Mr President, the EU must assume its global responsibilities and ensure that poorer countries also get vaccinated.

name: Bartosz ARŁUKOWICZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are all talking about vaccine deliveries in the second, third and fourth quarters of this year. But we cannot be short-sighted, because the pandemic will not end in the fourth quarter of this year, because we have decided so. It may continue in the first, second, third quarter of the following year – and we have to think about it already.  Perhaps the virus will mutate.  We may have to vaccinate people again. So we're going to have another negotiation with the companies, and negotiating with the companies is not fun, it's not diplomacy - it's a tough game of interests. I know this because I have been doing this on behalf of the Polish Government for many years. There, every record counts, every comma, and especially the consequences in case of non-compliance with deliveries.  We hope that the President of the Commission will use all the tools she has to ensure that the companies deliver. We are also hearing that there are Member States that are in a state that is in a state of community law and is already buying vaccines from other countries. So I ask the Commission and I would like to get an answer directly. Is the Commission negotiating today with the manufacturer of the Russian Sputnik vaccine? Is it considered that it could be introduced to the European market?  It is pleased that the President of the Commission announces the establishment of a joint parliamentary and commission committee to scrutiny the purchase and procurement of vaccines. This is very good information. Madam President von der Leyen, we want to stand by your shoulder so that you can do what is very difficult today. Corporations cannot be the dictatorship of Europe, we must have an engine. You must have the tools to fight and we want to help you. You are fighting today for the health and life of Europeans, and we want to help you.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: – Dear Chairman, today we are having a difficult but very necessary debate - why is the European Union lagging behind in vaccinations? Nevertheless, it would be much worse for the Union to discuss why some of the Member States have grabbed all their vaccines, while the smaller and the poor have been left with nothing. That's why I still think that getting a vaccine together was a good idea. But it is clear that it could have been implemented even better.  Where's it stuck? If the problem is the human factor, it is simply solved. But if the problem arose because of the limitations of the structures of the European Union, then it requires systemic solutions.  It must be asked whether the Commission is sufficiently equipped with professional people and the power to lead procurement? Did the Council's decision-making system contribute to the delay? Should the EMA have approved vaccines faster? The last question has a clear answer - when you vaccinate half a billion people, with vaccines being developed in record time shortcuts and gambling are not an option. A serious defect of one of the approved vaccines would have catastrophic consequences, not only as far as the current situation is concerned, but on citizens' general trust in science, vaccination and democracy. In conclusion, I think there is time to improve the situation and speed up vaccinations. But if a lockdown happens again in the autumn due to delays to the European Union and the rest of the developed world does not work, the consequences could be devastating.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: – Madam President, the EU’s vaccination strategy is a tale of two starkly different halves. I mean on the one hand it is a testament to the importance of the European Union that we have successfully managed to avoid a bidding war between Member States. A European battle for vaccines would have had catastrophic consequences, especially for smaller Member States like mine, Slovakia. On the other hand, it is now quite obvious that the Commission has committed a number of serious mistakes in negotiating the contract and managing the supply of vaccines. And pondering an export ban to Northern Ireland, whatever the technical details, has been a PR disaster that the UK Government is now trying to exploit to blame all Brexit problems on the EU. I really hope that the Commission will learn from these mistakes because the coming weeks and months, and whether we are able to step up production, will be a make—or—break moment for citizens’ trust in the European Union.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam president von der Leyen, I would like to remind you of some data on vaccinations in the world. In England, ten million people have already received the first dose of vaccine; there are three million people in Israel, practically a third of the population. For comparison, Britons administered 12.5 doses per 100 people, the US being 8.8 doses per 100 people. What about Europe? Europe is only 2.5 doses per 100 people. The European disaster is recognised by everyone. In recent days, the Commission you have chaired has been the subject of much criticism from authoritative European newspapers. For all, the European Union has been unprepared for the negotiations, purchases and distribution of vaccines. In Italy, also because of the government that has just fallen, there are very serious slowdowns and the elderly do not know if and when they will finally receive the vaccine.  Meanwhile, after months of publishing contracts with pharmaceutical companies, but with pages full of omissis, parts that therefore remain secret. It is hard to see why, what you want to hide, why there is a lack of transparency. There is no clarity on who is responsible for delays in deliveries and, above all, on compensation in the event of vaccine-related problems.  I'm sorry to say. You had apologised, you apologised to Italy for its poor response to the pandemic, but unfortunately, I am sorry to say, even in the vaccination phase, the European Union is a disappointment to European citizens.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Madam President! Much of the criticism of the European Commission is unwarranted. We couldn't have gotten a safe vaccine any faster. But it's hard not to be able to count on the deliveries. Nor has the Commission's closure on the contracts been helpful. Worst of all, however, is that global access to vaccines is not being seriously addressed. Not one has been vaccinated in 130 countries that are already having problems in obtaining protective equipment, medicines and personnel. Now it even suggests that the Astra Zeneca vaccine, which many are betting on, has little effect on the South African variant. In other words, the COVAX model is totally inadequate. The EU should renegotiate contracts with industry so that we can give others access to know-how, clinical data and technology. We know that many countries have spare production capacity. 100 countries in the WTO support the proposal to temporarily suspend patents. If industry does not want to be involved, the EU must support this suspension. Everything else is on the moon, both in terms of health, economic and moral.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Europe today is paralyzed by fear for health and many limitations. Vaccination is the only chance to return to normality, to defer the economy and to get out of recession. The attitude of pharmaceutical companies that do not comply with the delivery schedule is disappointing. Many Member States have prepared vaccination plans, trusting the Commission's assurances that joint purchases are the best possible solutions. Today, these plans need to be changed and the vaccination process postponed.  Is the President aware of the real reasons for the notorious delivery delays? What consequences does the Commission intend to draw for the concerns? Are vaccines to be sold to other countries at a higher price? What safeguards do signed agreements provide for in the event of such a situation?  Ladies and gentlemen, the answers to these questions are the last chance for the Commission to regain at least some of the trust of citizens and governments lost during the pandemic.

name: Giorgos GEORGIOU
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, dear Stella, the pandemic has unfortunately provided an opportunity for Europe to regain some of its lost credibility. However, and without zeroing in on what has happened and is happening, I believe that this hope has proved to be a fruit. The common vaccination policy, which you have well drawn up, is unfortunately being circumvented by several Member States. Everyone goes their own way and eventually works the "saved self". We are already faced with vaccination nationalism. You have given many billions of public money to the big pharmaceutical companies, which are now privatising both the vaccine and patents and profiting unashamedly. European citizens have been left by the millions under very harsh restrictive measures. The dead are unfortunately stacked and close to two and a half million. I strongly ask — and I would ask Mrs von der Leyen — to finally put life above the blood-covered gains. Can you do that?

name: Nathalie COLIN-OESTERLÉ
text: Madam President, Madam President of the European Commission, this is one of the greatest health challenges we face today. I am convinced that only a coordinated European response was and remains the right approach, and it was essential to avoid unbridled competition between 27 Member States, 27 different prices and each for itself.  However, in the face of such a crisis, there is a demand for truth and transparency that we owe to European citizens. Of course, we can understand that certain elements of the contracts between the European Commission and the laboratories are an industrial secret and that certain clauses are confidential.  On the other hand, transparency must be complete with regard to the purchases made by the Member States and the timing of past and future deliveries. European citizens are asking many questions today: where are the promised doses? Why don't they come? These questions must be answered. It is about the credibility of the European Union. There is an urgent need to publish a precise timetable for deliveries and to specify the number of doses delivered by each of the laboratories in each of the Member States. It is also essential that all our available production capacity in Europe be mobilised in order to accelerate vaccination, which alone will enable us to achieve collective immunity and emerge from this pandemic. Finally, we must be concerned about the psychological and economic suffering of our youth, which is falling into precariousness. Images of long queues of students for food aid have left their mark. Common actions must be taken by the Member States. It is about our future and that of future generations.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, I am Belgian and i am therefore very relieved that today in Belgium, thanks to the European approach and your approach, we have proportionally the same number of vaccines as, for example, in Germany, at the same conditions and the same price. We just couldn't have done that. However, this does not mean that it cannot and must not be improved. If the contracts had been more legally and, above all, more transparent from the start of the negotiations, we could have avoided a great deal of misery. I therefore think it is a bad thing that this legal impotence is now being cited as the reason for the export measures. That's putting energy into the wrong measure. If we're not careful, Canada and the United States will soon be producing fewer vaccines instead of more. In addition, China and Russia are already spreading their vaccines in the rest of the world. We cannot continue to refer to COVAX. We need to take more responsibility in the world. We may not have surplus vaccines, but we can ensure that production is started in the rest of the world. Why, for example, do we not support South Africa to produce ourselves? We cannot say, on the one hand, that all vaccines in Europe are ours and, on the other hand, that the patents are ours and that we must stay away from them. I find that unacceptable. We need a different approach.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, President of the Commission, you mentioned that vaccination is a marathon and that we are at the beginning. Yes, we're running a race, a race against time, a race to save people's lives, and we're definitely not winning yet. I give a big plus for buying vaccines together, but I give three minuses – minus for communication, for transparency and for speed. Moderna arrives in the Czech Republic a week later and in half a dose compared to the agreement – this is the headline of an article read yesterday by czechs. Another one of many. No wonder frustration and disillusionment are growing. Yet Europe is the largest producer of vaccines in the world. Three quarters of the vaccines produced worldwide annually come from Europe. So, please, let's start sprinting, employ our production lines by fighting COVID-19. We have to win this race.

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Madam President, since the beginning of the health crisis, the European technocracy has exposed blatant incompetence and disconnection.  After failing on mask orders, test orders and border protection, the Commission seized on the order for the vaccines, but did not have the necessary skills. Added to the French bureaucratic burden was the Brussels debacle. The opacity in which you have led the negotiations will only reinforce peoples' distrust of one of the exit doors of this interminable crisis they are going through. Meanwhile, the UK, freed from the shackles of Brussels, has already vaccinated more than ten million people. Hungary has chosen to override your injunctions by directly pre-ordering two million doses of the Russian vaccine, which you have chosen to ignore for sad ideological reasons.  Mrs von der Leyen, every minute of delay taken by Brussels is another French company that files the balance sheet and with it, its share of social and human consequences. Because all too often, your Union, moreover in this crisis, has caused weakness.  This period we are going through calls for a very broad questioning of your broad political and economic orientations. National sovereignty is not a despicable idea, but a good, the most precious of peoples, which you have taken over for too long and which you must give back today to the nations of Europe if you want a European construction that retains meaning.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: – Madam President, a global pandemic demands a global response. Only 73 out of 195 countries have started the COVID vaccination. This is not good enough. Only the richest countries have access to the COVID vaccines.  Instead of protecting the interests of pharmaceutical companies, we need to protect all people. Health care should be a global human right.  Dear European Commission, dear national governments: don’t block the patent waiver. Share intellectual property rights and support compulsory licenses.  Auch in der EU sind die Baustellen groß. Das Ziel, bis zum Herbst 70 Prozent der Europäerinnen und Europäer zu impfen, werden wir nicht von alleine schaffen. Und bisher bleiben Sie, Frau Kommissionspräsidentin, uns einen konkreten Plan schuldig. Ausschließlich auf die Hersteller zu hoffen, reicht nicht aus. Wir müssen alle Produktionskapazitäten ausschöpfen und mehr Haushaltsmittel mobilisieren. Wiederholen Sie nicht die Fehler der letzten Monate! Machen Sie Ihre Pläne transparent und arbeiten Sie mit uns zusammen.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Minister, i would like to thank you very much for Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Dear! The pandemic stopped the whole world. Member States have taken a joint decision on joint purchases. This task has been entrusted to the European Commission by the President. And how has this task of jointly purchasing vaccines been accomplished?  In the first phase, the European Union allocated funds for the development of vaccines. The next phase was the conclusion of contracts with pharmaceutical companies. And that's where the problems started to come in. It turned out that the Commission had started concluding contracts too late. Secondly, the contracts concluded did not guarantee certainty of supply. And today the President of the Commission is speaking, saying that, in principle, we will set up a joint committee of Parliament and the Commission and everything will be fine, and long live Europe. Of course, long live Europe. But, Madam President, you must at least be able to learn from your mistakes. We have a third, fourth wave of pandemics ahead of us. We must have a coherent, clear system for ordering and distributing vaccines so as not to lead to a health catastrophe.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, as António Guterres said, the vaccine is a success for science, a failure for solidarity. The monopoly created has generated inequality and a huge global imbalance. What was, a few months ago, the European Union's greatest hope is rapidly becoming the biggest fiasco.  There was an unprecedented effort to obtain resources and science responded. All this is true, but where are your words, from April 2020, that vaccines for COVID would be our universal common good, Ms von der Leyen? Citizens understand investment in vaccines, but do not understand how ownership of the vaccine is entirely private. They do not understand how the pace of production is fully managed by pharmaceuticalcompanies, how all responsibilities are public and all private profits.  None of this is new. The lack of transparency, the need to release the patent, were discussed from scratch and the Commission ignored it. More than 2 million people have died from COVID and there will be more that do not fit the statistics. We pay to save lives, not to generate profits, Madam President.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Information about the start of vaccination against SARS-CoV-2 caused a wide range of emotions, especially the hope of ending the pandemic and returning to normality. Unfortunately, in the past weeks there have been problems with the supply of vaccines. This resulted not only in the disorganization of the work of medical centers, but also a huge stress on patients enrolled in vaccination. All the more so because it is a group of the oldest people who deserve special treatment. Seniors enrolled in vaccinations are not a list of names in tables, but people – often single, sick, in need of help from loved ones. Changing the deadline at the last minute, often on the same day, acts as a domino effect, disorganizing the work and life of many people. Let us remember that the virus does not respect borders, nationalities, nor does it respect the national selfishness and vested interests of global corporations. That is why I appeal to European leaders and vaccine manufacturers: we now have a powerful vaccine tool. Now it is only our shared responsibility that determines whether and when we end this pandemic. To save lives, it is not enough to invent a vaccine, it still needs to be given.  I therefore ask the European Commission to rigorously enforce the provisions of the agreements with vaccine manufacturers and to analyse in depth information on delivery delays.

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: – Mr President, the fact is that we are in competition with time for the supply of vaccines. It is very important that the promises made on the delivery of vaccines are kept and that vaccines are quickly made available to the public.  The new British conversion and other variants pose an increasing threat to the rapid re-spread of this wretched disease and all the problems it poses to the health and life of its citizens. That is why the Commission must do everything possible to speed up vaccine production. I am also dissatisfied with the fact that we have not been able to obtain sufficient information for Parliament on what agreements, in what way and on what terms with the companies have been concluded. There is a need for more transparency. Less than half of the promised number of vaccines has arrived in Finland. This is unacceptable, not for Finland or other countries. The Commission is also expected to review whether agreements and patent protection with pharmaceutical companies can be reassessed or whether, for example, licence production can be used as a solution for additional supplies. We must therefore look at all possible paths in order to spread the vaccines during this spring.

name: Nicola BEER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Madam President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President-in-The At last! Parliament has been waiting for this exchange with you for a long time, and it has been postponed for far too long.  They stand for the EU like no other. Polls reflect massive loss of confidence. The damage is there for the citizens, for the EU. They must now – we all must now – pick up the shards, painstakingly restore disappointed trust. Lost time that we could have made better use of.  Now it's time to be honest. And precisely because we believe in Europe: create transparency, Madam President – completely. The truth comes to light anyway. Now is not the time for big declarations. In the crisis, it says: lead. That means leading by a credible example, not running behind, swimming in front of the wave.  To Thierry Breton: He shows how to do it: use and network capacities, create maximum production and delivery, keep an eye on, recognize mutants, analyze, adjust vaccination research, develop vaccines. Finally, regional exchanges in the EU: what works where, why, and when best?  This is something that is necessary for an opening-up strategy, and we owe it to the citizens and the economy of Europe.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: – Madam President, let me be very clear to the Commission President. I really support and defend the common European approach on vaccines. It is really good that we do not have a harmful race between the different EU Member States on who gets the vaccine first. But the EU’s strategy is really turning a blind eye to the global dimension. COVAX and the WHO patent pool do not deliver in securing a fair distribution of the vaccine around the globe. When the smallest part of the world’s population secures the biggest share of the vaccine doses, something is going wrong.  We need to increase the production capacity. You said it yourself, but that means that also countries like India and South Africa need to be enabled to produce the vaccine, and the EU must use its leverage to get the pharma companies to share their technology and know-how with developing countries. We can only win against COVID if we act together, and we have to act now.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Minister, i would like to thank you very much for Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Unfortunately, the good decision to have a common vaccine strategy for the 27 Member States has been seated by the mistakes and omissions of the European Commission. As a result, the vaccination rate per 100 citizens is one of the lowest in the world, because we are clearly ahead of countries such as Israel, the United Kingdom and the United States.  In the absence of time, only three issues. How is it possible that the Commission has supported pharmaceutical companies with more than €3 billion and does not have access to vaccines such as third countries that have not supported such research? How is it possible that the President ensures that there are hard delivery times for certain quantities and deadlines in contracts, and at the same time when they are not respected, and blatantly, there is no reaction on the part of the European Commission?  Madam President, without a significant increase in vaccine production and without speeding up supply, the EU strategy of vaccinated 70% of citizens by the end of the summer will be ruined. At this rate, only 15% of Europeans will be vaccinated by then.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, ... (words not heard) ... which it has demonstrated by giving European citizens equal access to vaccines. The responsibility for the delay that costs human lives is the great pharmaceutical industry. In other words, the first ones took money, but the last to comply with contracts.  With huge profits in the pandemic, these global companies are refusing to give up their intellectual property rights. Such a waiver, Madam President, would allow many states to produce their own vaccines. I have said it before and I repeat it: global companies increasingly tend to act according to their rules and not according to the laws of the states in whose territory they make huge revenues.  It is mandatory that in the coming period, through the World Trade Organisation, within the G20, uniform measures should be discussed in an attempt to shape the process of globalisation which, at least in the case of the pharmaceutical industry, becomes inhumane, primarily geared towards profit and with minimal responsibility for people's lives.

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: – Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, the Socialists support this vaccine strategy because it is on the path of European equality and solidarity, with high objectives: to bring the vaccine to hundreds of millions of people without distinction. That is why we demand transparency, for good compliance control. Strengthen democracy. To criticise mistakes made is not to criticise the Union. Don't let anyone fool you. We defend our institutions. We see vaccines as a common good. Science has achieved a milestone that less than a year ago seemed impossible. We have supported the pharmaceutical industry, crucial to the fight against this pandemic. Now we demand compliance to regain trust. We welcome agreements to increase production. But, Madam President, do whatever it takes to get around the supply bottleneck. Right now a release of licenses can delay our goals, but if the industry is not able to, we must reserve that option. Ladies and gentlemen, let us also make it clear that EU mailboxes do not accept vaccine propaganda. Welcome to all those approved by the EMA. Citizenship is exhausted; restrictions, family and friends in hospitals, toilets waging a titanic battle... This strategy is our hope. A historic challenge. I'm sure it will mark the future of Europe. Let's get him together.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: – Madam President, we had some frank exchanges of views earlier, so I think it’s time for conclusions and not for being too angry. And the conclusions could be actually summed up by ‘what did you learn in school today?’ ‘What did you learn in the EU today, dear Commission of mine?’  One, we needed to have had the Parliament with us from the very beginning, and the contact group is a very good step in that direction. Two, when we spend the amount of money we are now going to spend, we need an open-source approach. And when Linux started to do open source, the big companies came against, among other persons, my son.  And then today they have learned that open source was something which was actually in their interest also and in the interest of mankind. Third, we need a European law on transparency, and when this comes from the Commission, I will say: ‘yes, we did it’.

name: Katrin LANGENSIEPEN
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Many who live at home and organise their own care through assistance or relatives have been forgotten since March. At the moment, the vaccination offer is made first to the particularly vulnerable groups, and that is right. But what does this mean for the 40-year-old family man who has ALS or the parents who care for their child, who has a chronic lung condition? There are 80 million people with disabilities in the EU. Not all are over 75, and not all live in institutions. People's desperation here is very great. Do not misunderstand me: this debate must not be about pitting groups in our population against each other. No, the simple answer is: more production capacity, more vaccine and faster action. The debate on supply bottlenecks and transparency of contractual arrangements between the EU and pharmaceutical companies is both right and wrong. Likewise, the dispute over states that have dual strategies: right, because these things basically need to be clarified, because the time is missed. Political blame games don't produce a vaccine! I therefore expect the Commission and the Member States and all of us here, who have the influence, to ensure that, in this situation, we do not argue about what has been done wrong, but that we will focus here today with our united stride on how we get more vaccine.

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President von der Leyen, it is true that those who do not do are not mistaken, but those who do and then make mistakes must take responsibility for it. All the more so when dealing with the health of hundreds of millions of citizens. We say this with the serene conscience of those who firmly believed that at least on vaccines the Union would be able to show its added value, avoiding a race to raise prices and to hoard doses by the Member States.  Instead, the Commission has made two crucial mistakes: it has signed unclear contracts with pharmaceutical companies and waited too long before signing them, thus overtaking itself and demonstrating, once again, its geopolitical weakness. Now we are in the midst of a contradiction: on the one hand, try to remedy it clumsyly with a kind of vaccine sovereignty and, on the other hand, you continue to say that we must distribute vaccines in half the world outside our borders.  Meanwhile, however, the target of 70 % of europe's population vaccinated before the summer seems to have become a utopian dream. Mr von der Leyen, you have made a political bet on vaccines and you are not winning it to date. That should make you think. Instead of calling for more health expertise, the EU should start doing very well but really important things.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Council, Madam President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Council for her work on the First of all, to your address, Madam President of the Commission, thank you for your honest analysis of where we are at the fight against the pandemic right now and what the next steps we must take now are.  Last year, the euphoria was great at the end of the year. In record time, we have succeeded in producing not one but several vaccines. But as far as mass production is concerned, the reality has caught up with us in recent weeks, because vaccines are not as easy to produce and bottle as mineral water or beer.  The production and transport of millions of vaccines is a highly complex process, a highly complex undertaking and production capacities naturally depend on many different factors, including external ones. This has been mentioned.  I think the fight against COVID-19 is far from won and we must now focus on what is to be done next. I think it is right , Madam President, you pointed out – that we must fight the mutants, which is very, very central. And I think it is also very important that we develop a therapeutic strategy, that we consider how we can better support the disease progression, the severe disease progression of COVID-19 patients with medicines. I would ask the Commission to draw up a strategy here.  My final point is that I believe that we also need more European coordination when it comes to entry and quarantine rules.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: – Mr President, President, Madam Secretary of State, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I bring three issues here. How is post-vaccination and post-infection immunity being assessed? We need to know if, with vaccination, we are protecting people and for how long. My question is: when will we have these results available and, if these studies show that an annual strengthening of the vaccine will be necessary, how is the Commission preparing for a scenario where it is necessary to acquire sufficient doses for Member States to be able to repeatedly vaccinate their population to ensure immunity?  Last month, they had ambitious targets to vaccinate 70% of the adult population by the summer. Considering the problems of scarcity and production capacity by the industry that have already been addressed here, what are the strategies they will implement to achieve these goals or whether these goals will be changed to be aligned with current production capacity.  And I end my speech here with an appeal from the citizens. The European Union has made a structured and coordinated approach to this vaccination process and has set up a platform for monitoring the whole process in the Member States. I call here for joint dissemination work between the Council and between the Commission to reach all citizens. For them and for a genuine European Union for Health.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Mr President, vaccines consist of three to four hundred different ingredients. However, due to the high demand for vaccines, a shortage of these ingredients has arisen. How has the Commission prepared for this before vaccine production started? This is not a new phenomenon. For the corona pandemic, it was already clear that the security of supply of ingredients for vaccines and medicines often leaves a lot to be desired, resulting in serious drug shortages. Why has the Commission not yet made concrete proposals, for example in the pharmaceutical strategy, to improve the security of supply of ingredients and medicines? Is that going to happen now?

name: Ville NIINISTÖ
text: – Madam President, I have spoken with a lot of young people in Europe and they have a strong message to deliver. The continuing coronavirus crisis is having a huge strain on the health of the youth of Europe. I’m not just worried about the health effects on the elderly and the risk groups, but of the effect that one year, or even two years, of this continued crisis is having on the mental health of the youth. For young people forming their future, that is a long time without the proper chance for social contacts and learning.  If there is a generation growing up without a chance to pursue their dreams and visions, it affects our whole youth future. It is a Europe without dreams and visions. And this crisis affects the youth of the whole world. It is not just limited to Europe. So, therefore, I urge the Commission to do its utmost to ramp up vaccine production in Europe and globally. There needs to be a compulsory licensing of the vaccines to speed up production. We need all hands on deck. But there needs to be carrots and sticks to enforce public interest above the interests of a few private vaccine companies. Vaccination has yet to start in the poorest countries, so there needs to be a global strategy here. I urge you to action.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Madam President, I am not surprised by Mrs Von der Leyen's central argument, which is basically to say that the European Commission has done so fatally, but that is still better than if the Member States had acted on their own; it is better for the ship to sink with everyone inside than those who find a lifeboat or swim better than others can be saved: all sunk and so no one is offended. Blessed federal Europe! Today all the governments of the European Union blame you for the fiasco of vaccines and it is perhaps not entirely fair, but the truth is that you became conductor of the orchestra without entrusting yourself to God or the devil. And that's what globalism has, isn't it? Nobody here is responsible because no one knows who makes the decisions. States point it out to you; you point to pharmaceutical companies; pharmaceutical companies, the states themselves, and if everything else fails, we blamed the British strain, even though the virus was not Chinese. In Spain there is the same fight between the regional administrations and the central government. The problem is obvious: everyone wants power, but no one wants to take responsibility. If you, Mrs Von der Leyen, were in any government of a Member State, you would have resigned. I ask you that: dignity and resignation.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, were it not for the Commission's mass purchase of vaccines, many European countries , my own, for example - for lack of political weight or budget, would not start receiving vaccines until Germany or France had finished their vaccination processes. Maybe after the summer. The European decision to centralize the purchase of vaccines has saved us shameful upward competition for the price and drama of not having millions of Europeans in many countries to protect. When it came to criticizing the frugals for being reluctant with the recovery fund, either that voices were heard under this lack of solidarity. However, now that, if the purchase consortium were to be broken, the northern ones were not going to have supply problems, but the southern ones did, our thanks to the Von der Leyen Commission are not heard equally well. You only hear selfishness in the north and south. Another effect of COVID-19, it sees, is nationalism. Now that Hungary is buying vaccines from Russia on its own, that Germany plans to purchase 600 million doses outside the Commission, that Russia is looking to divide us by offering its Sputnik to each other and not to others, that the UK has turned the vaccination process into the first post-Brexit political pulse, which Serbia vaccinates faster than the European Union thanks to the Chinese , is the worst time to show disunity. European solidarity is working and on a continent without borders only solidarity can save lives and economies. If we don't all get vaccinated, it's like no one's been vaccinated.

name: Sándor RÓNAI
text: "Dear Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support," he Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Please recall the beginning of the pandemic, when wealthier countries, wealthier Member States, were able to obtain better quality equipment more quickly, while poorer Member States had the leftovers, most at more expensive prices. However, the Hungarian Government was also able to make this situation worse. They bought enough ventilators from China that would have been enough for Germany. To this day, they lie in a warehouse, probably with the mandarin instructions. I am therefore particularly pleased that we are now doing the authorisation, production and whole process of vaccines together at EU level.  This is not an easy task, as 500 million people have to be vaccinated. Please do not forget for a moment that vaccines have been created and authorised with european taxpayers' money. Nevertheless, this whole process is still much more transparent and traceable than in some Member States, which, for example, authorised the Russian and Chinese vaccines in Hungary before the dossier was known.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, we do not expect words but actions in the pursuit of the objective of vaccinating 70% of the European population by the summer. We, as the world's largest vaccine producer, should be able to do that. Nevertheless, we are at the back of the queue and vaccination is accelerating in Canada, the United States, Israel and the United Kingdom. That is why Europe is under attack. You rightly said that this is not a sprint, but a marathon. I think, however, that it is time for an intermediate sprint in Europe. We need to increase our pace, increase production capacity, monitor supplies and compliance with contracts more rigorously and, if necessary, renegotiate them. Europe must deliver now. I would find it very embarrassing if we had to be helped out of the fire by the Russian Sputnik vaccine. You still have my full support, Madam President of the Commission. We have no choice but to deal with this at European level. However, the Commission must take action and be transparent so that the citizens know what they are up to.

name: Sara MATTHIEU
text: Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, cooperation is the strength of the European Union. Some may be quicker, but together we are giving all European citizens the best and safest vaccines. Confidence has to go up. I therefore call for all contracts concluded by the Commission to be made transparent and public. This ensures greater support and thus a higher vaccination rate. However, Europe is not an island. The only way to stop the pandemic is if the whole world is vaccinated, and that requires a huge number of vaccines. Unfortunately, the large-scale production of vaccines is currently being hindered by patents. I would therefore ask you to stop referring to the COVAX initiative as if it were a solution for vaccines in poorer countries; it is no more than a wipe for bleeding and will also be late. Support india's request, among other things, to remove property rights at WTO level. After all, we are only safe when everyone is safe.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, Madam Secretary of State, Madam President of the Commission, as elected representatives of European citizens, of course the European Union's action to have the vaccine for all Europeans deserves our support and thanks, and I do so here personally to President Von der Leyen and Commissioner Kyriakides. There is, however, a clear point. We need more vaccines now. We need to acquire more vaccines and produce more vaccines urgently. And I say here something that is politically incorrect: if we need to pay more, we pay more. There's an old Portuguese that says: the cheap comes out expensive. Because if we don't pay now, we're going to pay a lot more in our savings and on lives that are priceless.  If the vaccine is here to stay, it is essential to ensure production and distribution in Europe. Not just for this emergency now, but for the next few years, and not only for this pandemic, but also for other diseases that come in the future. That's what the Health Union is all about. The pandemic, from the first moment, from masks to fans, which taught us that we must have productive and distribution capacity within Europe. This goes for the drugs, it goes for vaccines.  And finally, I say here to the Commission: let us learn the lessons when we present the new Schengen strategy. There is a lot to do in Schengen that can save lives and that can save savings and the pandemic was the best lesson on the reforms we must make.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Madam President, for several months now we have all been engaged in this fight against the virus, but let us admit that we are still with our heads in the handlebars. I share a lot of my colleagues' demands, but I add two things. As a corollary to the concept of European independence or health autonomy, the idea of a Europe of health has burst into the picture, but it is still in the state of an idea. Even if this already succeeds in upsetting national preventions, the concept must now be strengthened. For example, if there is agreement that ECDC is a good tool, it needs to be strengthened in terms of resources and role. Secondly, relations with the "Big Pharmas" must be seriously revisited. It is unimaginable to attend the show given by the big labs, with actors who sound so wrong and especially for so long. At a time when our companies are facing excess mortality with all the anxieties that this represents, seeing THE CEOs of labs lying, quibbling, focusing on the amount of profits and dividends, like Sanofi, continues to sicken even if it does not surprise. Be sure that Parliament intends to be an actor in this regard.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to President von der Leyen that, in her address this morning, she said, ‘The bottom line is mistakes were made in the process leading up to the decision to invoke Article 16. I deeply regret that’.  President von der Leyen, I wish to acknowledge your regret, but I also need to ask you three questions. How was the decision arrived at, who made the decision, and why? And these are fundamental questions because we do need to put in place mechanisms to ensure that Commissions in the future would not make similar mistakes. We are playing with a very sensitive issue on the island of Ireland so I would greatly appreciate answers to those three questions: how, who and why? Beyond that, I would also say that I very much support the concept of the European Commission’s purchasing programme for vaccines. What we need to do now is to ensure that there is strong collaboration and cooperation between the pharmaceutical companies to enhance capacity across the euro area and the European Union to ensure we have vaccines for our citizens and citizens in the COVAX programme as well. We also need to ensure that the authorisation programme is fast, effective and efficient, and that it cooperates with other international bodies in terms of assessing the efficacy of vaccines.

name: Grace O'SULLIVAN
text: – Madam President, recently the Commission made the grave mistake of almost invoking Article 16 of the Northern Ireland Protocol. President von der Leyen, you said this morning that, in the end, you got it right. President, you did not get it right. What concrete steps will you put in place to assure the people of Ireland, north and south, that the delicate situation on the island of Ireland is never threatened like this again?  Yesterday, Ombudsman Emily O’Reilly’s inquiry revealed alarming resource and information gaps in the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) in the crucial early weeks of the crisis. President, can you assure us the ECDC and similar agencies will be properly resourced? Can you now guarantee us action and transparency in the distribution of vaccines not just throughout Europe, but to the far reaches of the developing world? As we all say, no one is safe until everyone is safe.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, perhaps a bit of a retrospective at the beginning. Forward-looking policy is not necessarily a gift from our Member States. When, three years ago, in a very different discussion, I raised the issue of pandemics, cooperation between laboratories, specialisation in drug production, the production of new medicines, vaccines and antidotes, the Member States replied that this was out of the question, that this was a Member State competence. I believe that we must stop this egocentrism and not always start acting in the crisis and then start with the typical bashing game: the Member States are to blame, the Commission is to blame, and we also have a President and a Commissioner, whom we can then scold. We are not perfect. We are making mistakes in this crisis and we are learning from this crisis. But what we need to learn is to act more quickly geostrategically, to make the production and production of vaccines, but also of medicines again in our own countries, in the European Union itself, and to provide us with strategic supplies. We must also ensure that there is not only a fundamental mistrust of pharmaceutical companies. But they must also invest in the future again. There would be no vaccine today without the European Research Council, because it has accordingly supported the production or scientific activity in the field of mRNA vaccines, when the pharmaceutical giants did not want to do so. We should not insult each other in the crisis. And one final sentence, please, Madam President, that is particularly close to my heart: dear Stella Kyriakides, I very much regret the incitement campaign against you in my country. I really apologize. That simply does not belong in such a crisis. Everyone is allowed to make mistakes, but that is not possible.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President von der Leyen, Europe still has too many deaths as a result of the pandemic, but thanks to science we have launched the largest ever mass vaccination campaign. However, the quantities of vaccine made available fail to meet the needs and Europe must therefore promote concrete cooperation between companies and the exchange of virtuous practices in order to speed up the large-scale production and delivery of vaccines, overcoming the restrictions on patents and intellectual property and using clauses already present in international treaties.  We have seen how important it is to be united and to work together towards a common goal, overcoming vetoes, suspicions and party interests. Making vaccines and pharmacological treatment available to everyone, as soon as possible, is a moral and political duty that concerns us all, and we do not have time because the virus circulates, mutates and kills too much. I have a lot of confidence in you, Mr President, and I am convinced that together we will be able to overcome this challenge.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, I think a lot has been said about the need to procure the vaccines rapidly in order to restore trust, but I think more needs to be done because it’s not just the result that counts for trust, it’s also the process and the way there, and there I think we still have a few steps to take.  President von der Leyen, I heard you say ‘We must learn lessons. Things went wrong’. I think it is important that those in the Commission who are responsible actually assume that responsibility. I think, in order to get there, we need transparency, not just on the contracts, but also on the whole process of negotiations, including the role of the Commission, decisions that have been taken and the role of the Member States, who have been very, very quiet so far.  I think responsibility is a wider issue in the Commission. We have now witnessed for a couple of weeks the mess around the vaccine procurement. We have seen the mess around Article 16 and last week the mess around ‘Borrellgate’. I note – with some bitterness, I have to say – that, last year, Commissioner Hogan was made to step down very rapidly for much lesser offences. Where does the bar lie, Madam President?

name: Manuela RIPA
text: Madam President, Madam President von der Leyen, I would like to thank the President-in-House for the work she has done. Unlike the first lockdown, Europe has now acted together. It has supposedly learned from its mistakes, but success has not abated again.  This time, however, it is not the Member States that are to blame, but also the greed for profit on the part of companies, despite the fact that billions have been poured into research and vaccine contracts by the EU. But making money from the pandemic shows once again the weakness of the system. This is about the common good of health, which must give way to profit.  Last week, I put an official question to you, which I repeat here: what if this pandemic had been tackled not by the rules of profit maximisation, but by the economy of the common good? What if we were solely in the best interests of the Community? Corona is a turning point in many areas and must also be in the health sector.  Therefore: an end to the profit economy, to the pressure to profit in the health sector. Let us fight together for the common good economy, also and above all in the fight against this pandemic.

name: Adam JARUBAS
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab A broad vaccination is a matter of life and death today, but it is also the economy, the maintenance of European families and the rescue of failing businesses. A common European vaccination strategy is the only way if the Union is to return to the Union of freedoms, movement of persons, capital, goods and services. We need to achieve resilience at European level. Returning to normal requires defeating Covid-19 also in our neighbours, whether in the UK, Ukraine or North Africa. Separately, no European Union country would have such a negotiating position, a price preference, and many countries would not have access to vaccines in such a short period of time.  The Union's pharmaceutical strategy is about regaining drug sovereignty. The response to this unprecedented Covid-19 crisis must therefore be to develop the Union's internal capacity, not to further deepen its dependence on others. Contracts must be kept. The European Union cannot therefore pay credibility for the mistakes of companies. The threats of hundreds of thousands more victims in Europe therefore justify, for example, an ultimatum to take over patent rights. If a company is unable to meet its obligations, it must find a partner to do so and bear all the costs involved. The European Commission and the Member States must enforce this and prepare measures to support the rate of vaccination.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! We cannot expect to get through this coronapandema, completely flawless. This is the biggest crisis eu-cooperation has ever faced, and it is the biggest crisis on our continent since the Second World War. I do not expect freedom of error from the European Commission either, but I expect real openness, and we have not had that so far. When the Commission keeps the cards close to your body, you are not only gambling with your own credibility, but with the support for the entire EU vaccine strategy, and that could have consequences. Vaccine deliveries have been delayed and this is delaying the reopening of our society. But we have not had enough clear answers as to where things have gone wrong. Today you've opened up a little more. But more needs to be done so that we can learn and correct the mistakes, and that requires real openness. It is about getting more vaccines as quickly as possible, the citizens they are suffering. Open up so that we can improve the strategy, restore confidence and get the whole of Europe both quickly and safely through the crisis.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Let's start with the good news from last year. The first good news is that there was a common strategy of the European Commission for the purchase of vaccines. This was the right step, because the opposite would lead us to vaccination nationalism. The second right step was symbolism: that the first deliveries should be delivered at the same time for the whole Of the European Union. And to continue with the under-the-good news this year.  The figures show it: only 3% of the European population have been vaccinated.  Comparatively: for the US - 9%, for the UK - 14% and for Israel - over 60%. The question of the questions is: why did it come to this? Because some of the countries listed were faster than us, and we have to admit that. We've been delayed.  The second question: why don't vaccines produced in Europe stay here? Is there a gap in the contracts? He needs clear answers. There is a need for transparency, but there is also a need to restore trust between the European institutions and European citizens. Let's lend a hand and work together.

name: Daniel FREUND
text: – Madam President, I would ask Ms von der Leyen why it is we are still not able to see the contracts. So far we have heard that it’s because the pharmaceutical companies do not agree, even though I don’t really understand how the scrutiny of the European Parliament – of the Commission – is somehow conditional on the agreement of pharmaceutical companies.  Anyway, I went to the reading room, I handed over my phone, I signed the non-disclosure agreement, and then I got to read these fun details of the agreements that we have struck.
