These are probably the most valuable contracts that the EU has ever concluded, certainly in terms of the economic impact if we made a bad deal in this case. But we as Parliament cannot read them. You have now offered a contact group and thankfully, a Belgian minister has tweeted the prices. But I don’t think that democratic control can work on accidental or restricted transparency, and actually, transparency should be your best friend because it protects you against blame—shifting by the Member States. That’s what gains you trust, and it allows us to avoid mistakes, particularly in the future. So I think you should try a bit more transparency.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for her work on First of all, I would like to thank you for your sincerity. Not all politicians have the capacity to admit mistakes and, at best, to learn from those mistakes.  But I also think that the critics, your critics, should also take their own noses. After all, it is often the same people who have decided or supported border closures and export restrictions without clarifying this with their neighbours. They are the same people who put the brakes on the Commission at the beginning of 2020 when it wanted to buy medical equipment and protective masks together.  But sponge over it. This is where we get better off if we tackle together: the EU and the Member States. We need the Health Union as soon as possible, which you have announced, and the Member States must also take action on this, Madam Secretary of State. We need transparent and coordinated national pandemic and vaccination plans. Above all, however, we need more vaccine production in order to achieve our medium-term target of vaccination of 70% of our population.  The publication of contracts is, of course, a nice to have. But, this does not increase production. What we need is an EU production task force that has the necessary funding to manage to diversify our supply chains and give producers access to the necessary ingredients and molecules.  But we will only achieve all this together and not against each other. Let's tackle it - save lives together.

name: Mohammed CHAHIM
text: Mr President, it is simple, we want as many vaccines as possible as soon as possible. This means cooperation, both between the pharmaceutical industry and the government and within the pharmaceutical industry. The licences must be shared with other producers so that more places can be produced and we can achieve the main goal together: vaccines for all. If pharmaceutical companies do not want to reveal their prescriptions and data, we must act firmly and force them to do so. We can't depend on a handful of pharmaceutical companies trying to beat a virus. The vaccines were developed with public money from all of us. It is therefore only logical that we have something to say about this. We have the opportunity to produce in more places in Europe and can legally enforce it. This legislation not only exists, but is even created for situations like this. If we do not exploit these opportunities during the current crisis, when will we?

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: – Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, it is important that we have this thorough and lengthy debate, because there has been a great deal of disappointment and uncertainty about vaccines, but also a great deal of expectation and hope. The Commission has said that it wants to increase transparency in vaccine supplies outside the EU and has created a new authorisation procedure to this end. Are the results of this authorisation procedure already visible and can we increase the important transparency and reliability of both deliveries and procurement? Our new huge challenge is mutations. How is the Commission prepared for this and for the fact that we may still need a second round of vaccines after this year? The World Health Organisation has estimated that, globally, we will not yet achieve herd immunity this year, even if this critical 70% in the EU is achieved. Here in Finland, for example, we are developing a very promising vaccine in the form of nasal spray, and it is important that these new solutions are also remembered in the future.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, Mrs Kyriakidou, in this debate it is necessary to put our finger on the type of sun. What went wrong, President von der Leyen, and clouded the image of the great, historic decision of the common supply of vaccines? Why, since the interests of European citizens are safeguarded, did companies not get the message — together with pre-financing — in time that the European Union will not make any compromises on deliveries? It is necessary to catch up so that we do not repeat the same mistakes. It is also necessary to ensure that vaccines are sufficient that 70% of our population will be vaccinated in the second half of 2021. No delay on the part of companies can be accepted anymore and it is necessary to move on to global alliances with partners and allies of the United States in order to ensure the materials and their inadequacy necessary to manufacture vaccines. We also need to have uniform rules for moving within and outside the European Union. The vaccination certificate proposed by the Prime Minister of Greece, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, remains on the table as a reliable tool, which will make it easier for citizens who have been vaccinated to travel without additional tests and tests but will not exclude anyone else who wants to travel safely. Finally, I would remind you that my country, Greece, is back in lockdown. No aid can replace economic activity. That is why, Mrs von der Leyen, it is time to do whatever it takes to shield our citizens by the summer.

name: Romana JERKOVIĆ
text: – Dear Vice-President, the health of our citizens must be and remain the number one priority. The latest figures show that vaccination in the European Union is only 3%, in the United Kingdom it is 16%, not to mention Israel with 60%. These differences are large, and they are in addition to being large and also worrying, and we rightly question whether too much emphasis in negotiations with the pharmaceutical industry has been placed on the purchase price of vaccines, rather than prioritizing production and security of supply. In any case, the fact is that we underestimated the challenges associated with the complexity of vaccine production and distribution, but also that we only overestimated the promise of industry. The right of pharmaceutical companies to profit cannot be greater than the right to health. Therefore, all options - such as using the capacity of other manufacturers and export controls - must remain on the table. I guess it's clear to all of us that the speed of our recovery depends on this.

name: Claudia GAMON
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Madam President von der Leyen, you are right: it was right and important that the EU jointly provide vaccines for all Europeans. But today's EU, the cooperation between the Commission and the Member States, has failed this stress test. Tomorrow's EU must not happen again. We need a Union that can act decisively and quickly, a Union that does not have to ask every 27 at every second step whether something can be done for them. We must now first of all learn from this and eliminate any unnecessary bureaucracy in the vaccine approval process – especially with regard to the virus variants, the whole thing will be relevant in the near future. And we must help all vaccine manufacturers and their partners to increase their capacity, and do so as quickly as possible. The European vaccination programme must become the force of our generation – day and night, as long as it now takes all people who need vaccination to get it.

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Madam President, we declared vaccination a common cause, a common European solution to both the health and economic crisis, and the Commission made an enormous effort to procure vaccines at the best possible price and safety and reliability standards. Yet success came at a price: a delay of the vaccination process itself.  I hope the vaccine shortage will be behind us quite soon. And still, we face two major problems. One is the mass reluctance of the people to vaccinate, and another is the staggering gap in the pace of vaccination campaigns in the different countries, where countries with completely different standards, like Bulgaria and the Netherlands, are both lingering behind due to mismanagement of the crisis. Therefore I call on the Commission to launch a pan-European campaign against disinformation, but also to actively intervene where national authorities fail to procure vaccines for their citizens. Some might argue it’s a national competence. I would answer that if it’s a common cause, if it’s a common fight, if we are to leave no one behind, then we should not leave behind those already left behind by their governments.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe must be given the opportunity to research into vaccines and to buy jointly. Today the crucial problem is mass production capacity, because access to vaccines is good for all Europeans but it is also a global effort. If there has been an underestimation on the subject of production, we must concentrate our efforts here.  Breton's initiative is good to push companies as hard as possible, to multiply production sites through voluntary collaborations of companies. But that is not enough. We politicians have a duty to assess all the hypotheses on the ground in order to secure sufficient stocks, to assess what the demand will be, to be ready for any eventuality, so that we do not find ourselves unprepared in the future. We must therefore consider the path of compulsory licences, which recognize the intellectual property of patents but also allow, with royalties, to make other companies produce by giving the necessary knowledge and means. This path will create new industrial supply chains and lead to strategic autonomy in a crucial sector such as pharmaceuticals and healthcare.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Mr Von der Leyen, President of the Commission, i.e. the President of the Commission, i.e. the Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thank The smoothness of vaccinations is absolutely crucial to our lives and our health. Also for our economies and for the cohesion of the European Union. We face the pandemic together and we will only get through it together. Although the EU's influence on health policy is limited, thanks to the EU, we were able to procure the vaccine together, to guarantee vaccines for the whole of the Union, to all citizens, not just the largest, the richest or the loudest countries.  But vaccination is too slow. The most vulnerable will take the biggest hit. That is not acceptable and we are demanding answers. Why did it take so long to get the agreements in place, and how are they written? We must be transparent and transparent. That is why we need a principle of public access, and I would like to know how the President of the Commission wants to get in place.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I welcome today’s debate, as effective, open communication is essential in the midst of this pandemic. I urge the Commission to increase communication with the Parliament on vaccine procurement and deployment, and I welcome President Ursula von der Leyen’s commitment today to set up a contact group between the European Commission and Parliament. During the Brexit process, it was effective engagement and dialogue from the Irish Government that secured the unwavering solidarity and deep understanding across the EU for the unique challenges facing Ireland. This solidarity cannot and should not be forgotten. Therefore, it makes it all the more unfortunate that the Commission made the recent error of proposing to invoke Article 16. Heavy criticism followed, and understandably so, but thankfully, so did engagement with the Irish and United Kingdom governments.  The fact remains that this major error came about as there was no consultation with those who would be the most affected. We need assurances that lessons have been learned and that sufficient procedures are being put in place to ensure that this cannot happen again – because it must not happen again.  However, the protocol is not primarily the problem here. The problem is Brexit, which is the regretful reality we must all face. And the protocol was the only tangible option available, considering the stance of the British Government. What’s needed now is courageous and responsible leadership to utilise existing structures in the agreement, to ensure the protocol works for all.  I call on the British Government to play its part and implement agreements in the protocol to make sure it actually works for people and businesses. It takes two to tango!

name: Cyrus ENGERER
text: – Immainaw li kieku sebg aa u gsoxrin pajjiż ta' qisien differenti, kienu qeg adin jinnegozjaw b'mod individwali u separat ix-xiri tal-vain. Kieku kienet tkun festa gsall-kumpaniji tal-Big Pharma. Konvint li l-istorja se tiudika and il-mument diffili b aala wie서ed essenzjali fil-mixja tal-integrazzjoni tagna. Kif kien qal Schuman; "l-Ewropa mhux se tinbena f'daqqa jew skont pjan wiesed, iżda b'kisbiet concrete li l-ewwel ma jibnu hi s-solidarjetà". Is-solidarjetà, Sinjura President - Niftakru x-xeni ta' kważi sena ilu meta pajjiżi li ma bdewx ilassqu wasedhom mal-imxija tal-pandemicja, u-ittadiniustament staqsew, kif l-Istati Membri ddeidew illi jmorru g서an-nazzjonaliżmu fis-sas-a f'dak iż-żmien particulari. Kif tsallew wasedhom dawn il-pajjiżi? Kif dawn il-laqgsat kollha li jkollna hawnhekk fi Brussell ma fissru xejn gsall-서ajja ta' kuljum ta-ittadini? Sinjura President tal-Kummissjoni Ewropea, żew affarijiet; ejja nibdew minn issa ninnegozjaw u nixtru d-dożi fl-eventwalità tal-bżonn tat-tielet tilqima, kif ukoll aktar trasparenza. Il-mument illi l-Unjoni ma tkunx trasparenti hu l-mument illi-ittadini jitilfu l-kredibilità f'din l-Unjoni.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Madam President, we are slowly getting the feeling that the saga of dealing with the coronavirus pandemic will never be over. We have a highly anticipated vaccine and we have a strategy that is good in theory, but unfortunately not as effective as we would like. The Commission's decision to jointly commission was a good one and it ed us with optimism, including satisfaction, but it is less and less today. For? Because mistakes were made in contracting with vaccine manufacturers. And because, unfortunately, that's not the only reason. Even more important – perhaps even the most important reason – is the lack of transparency in particular. If we continue with the secret and vague explanations, we will lose citizens' trust altogether, which can then have an even more negative impact on their decision to vaccinate and, consequently, to achieve a common goal: to exit the pandemic. Therefore, the Commission must take responsibility and present to European citizens openly and clearly all vaccine-related information, thus preventing further confusion and spreading doubts.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we sometimes need to remind ourselves, during the debate we are debating, how serious the scale of the tragedy in which these political decisions that we have to take today are.  Since 1945, there has never been such a violent global recession, with more than two and a half million deaths. The European Union, while it has decided to react economically with extraordinarily effective action, has been faced, not without mistakes, also from the point of view of health, with the greatest provocation it has received. As an Italian I can say that we have been guaranteed more than 300 million vaccines as a reservation. It would not have been possible without the European Union, which has booked EUR 2 billion and EUR 300 million for the 27 Member States. The mistakes must be corrected, there is no doubt about it, but our strength as individual countries would not have allowed us to give this thread of hope to our citizens.  Now the rate of supply is not enough, we are only 4 % in the administration of these vaccines on the total population. We need to improve, and we must therefore ensure that the plans are effective within the individual countries, that bottlenecks are removed on staff ing and on the communication of information systems. But the road is the right one. Our countries can say that, thanks to the European Union, we also have an answer and we can hope for such a great tragedy.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, I am still speaking out, in particular, in favour of seeking better targeted treatment for Covid-19, as well as for the use of pre-existing medicines, if they have been shown to be at least somewhat effective. But better than cure is, of course, preventable, and here it is clear that vaccination, even if it is not a miracle cure for a pandemic, is for now the most effective way of at least cushioning this dramatic situation, accompanied by hundreds of thousands of deaths and the economic crisis. The aim of the common European procedure for the procurement of vaccines, which I am advocating, was to ensure their rapid and fair distribution to all Member States. But the long-lasting delays in the supply of agreed vaccines are causing huge disappointment to our citizens. We must therefore allow vaccines to be made in all Member States that can ensure this. We must force producers to give up their patents, as they have received our taxpayers' money for research and production, because, like me, I will explain to our electorate that, despite the millions invested in various farm companies, they do not agree with the dislocation of production.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President of the Commission, in recent weeks we have seen a growing number of criticisms of Europe on the supply of vaccines. There is no doubt that mistakes have been made by the Commission and the Member States, and the criticisms that have been made are also to be welcomed. We are calling for this transparency and clarity, but I believe that at the same time we should be honest with the citizens of Europe. Do we really think that if each Member State had dealt on its own with the pharmaceutical companies today we would have more vaccines? Or do we want to recognise that the absence of Europe would only have favoured one or two large countries to the detriment of all the others? So, thanks to the vaccination strategy, since Last June we have helped to finance research by diversifying possible suppliers. Let us now focus on the efforts to pressure the pharmaceutical companies, reminding them of their commitments, monitoring possible abuses and organising the best possible administration of the vaccine in our countries. Weakening the European institutions will not help us to close this ugly page of our lives as soon as possible.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – It is undeniable that restoring social and economic life in the European Union is the main task of our Union. It is undeniable that the common solidarity approach in this unprecedented crisis is the right one, not the national selfishness.  From now on, however, the priority is to deliver as many vaccines as possible as soon as possible and the fastest vaccination of citizens in the Member States. My call is also for the Commission to assist Member States in vaccination campaigns and by region. We also need to increase production capacity with a European financial investment offensive, which is extremely necessary.  Vaccination is the light in the tunnel, but let this light not become the light of the oncoming oncoming train in the form of viral variants, which are not protected from the current vaccines. I am pleased that the European Commission is also starting to work on these issues.  We need to be prepared for all the opportunities that are ahead of us so that the main goal of restoring social and economic life can be achieved as quickly as possible. This is what European citizens expect: transparency, security, information and work against disinformation. My call to you is for communication to be even better and for every question that is asked to be answered as quickly as possible.

name: Petar VITANOV
text: – As a representative of one of the poorest Member States of the European Union, I would like to stress that the Commission's common approach was an act of supreme solidarity because small and poor countries were given conditions for vaccines that they would never have been able to negotiate on their own.  At the same time, I welcome the publication yesterday of a contract with another producer company, but remember that the European Parliament has been pushing for transparency and publicity since the summer of last year, because the lack of transparency was creating a food environment just for anti-European and conspiracy theories.  I have three questions for the European Commission: What measures will the European Commission take to ensure timely deliveries from vaccine manufacturers.  How member states that are significantly behind vaccination rates will be supported, encouraged or sanctioned.  And is there a pan-European information campaign to overcome mistrust about vaccines in some Member States.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, 'you should have', 'there was only one to'' We have heard criticism this morning of you and the Commission. I assure you, if you had not exercised the necessary caution, you would not have heard the same screaming, but howling to tell you that you had been unsealed, that you had rushed.  I say thank you, thank you for the supply, even if today it is not enough. Thank you on behalf of all Member States who would have been unable to buy a single dose of vaccine for their citizens. Thanks to Europe, through unity, through solidarity, we have been able and you have been able to ensure that European citizens believe in Europe and believe in this much-needed solidarity. Of course, the vaccine is the first step towards economic recovery that we all want. Our economies are crossed, the reality of the virus demands that we stand together again tomorrow. I really ask you to use all the levers that are yours to prevent some Member States from playing it solo, whether it is Hungary, Germany or others, to avoid leaving this field of solidarity. It would make no sense in relation to the values we stand for at European level. It would not make any economic sense either, as our economies are cross-referenced. We must win this fight against the virus. We can only win it together thanks to the Commission's action.

name: Mónica Silvana GONZÁLEZ
text: – Madam President, President Von der Leyen, that vaccines are a global public good means that they have to reach developing countries. The news is good that COVAX will deliver its first vaccines this month and that the Commission is preparing its own mechanism for donating through Team Europe, but the challenge is much greater. While in Europe we are expected to have 70% of our population vaccinated this summer, the rest of the 145 COVAX participating countries could cover only 3.3% of their population, depending on the distribution we have received. This opens up a new gap and will create inequality that will add to existing ones. If we want to be a global player, we must also implement a geopolitical strategy, given that China and Russia are already doing so in Latin America and Africa. There are proposals on the table: an urgent donor conference, for vaccine producers to grant compulsory licenses to generic manufacturers in developing countries, and for the European Union to promote consensus at the World Trade Organization to make intellectual property rights more flexible. Thank you very much and let's get to it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, we have been discussing the seriousness of the situation for four hours now, because we all feel that we have a common responsibility. The vaccination plan is delayed in our countries because companies are not fulfilling agreements because they seem to have overestimated their capacities. For example, in the Czech Republic, I can say that our plan was to vaccinate 5% of the population by the end of February, we have 3.8% vaccinated. It is therefore certain that we are late, but we also have a promise that deliveries will improve, and I am convinced that we will only achieve this through joint efforts. I hope that the new Novavax vaccine, which has applied for recognition from 2 February, will also be put into distribution as soon as possible.  There has been a lot of criticism in the debate about poorly negotiated contracts. And here I would like to ask you again, Madam President of the Commission. Maximum transparency must be achieved and, where possible, the other important parts of the contracts to be made public, so that there is certainty and that there is certainty that we, and not just companies, have the distribution of the vaccine under control. People's health and lives are at stake, and in this situation, for example, the health and lives of people are at stake. Hungary has decided to open its system to the Russian and Chinese vaccines because it says health is more important than politics. Well, I don't know if this is really about health or politics, because if it really is about health, then I don't understand how they can take a vaccine that has not been recognised by the EMA. I would like to thank once again, President of the Commission, for your efforts, Commissioner, you have my full confidence and I believe that we will be able to vaccinate that 70% by the end of the summer.

text: Qabel ma ngħaddi għall-kelliema li jmiss, se niftaħ l-ewwel sessjoni ta' votazzjoni tal-lum. Se nivvotaw dwar il-fajls hedge kif inhuma indikati fl-aġenda. name: Carlo CALENDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcomed the EU vaccine strategy and the centralisation of negotiations with pharmaceutical companies. Today we must say just as clearly that this process has not worked as it should have done and many things are still unclear as to the content of the contracts negotiated and the disaccuracies supply plans. In this respect, It seems peculiar to me that it was not until 4 December that the Commission asked Commissioner Breton to lead a new working group with the aim of identifying and removing bottlenecks in the vaccine production chain. It is plausible that vaccination will have to be repeated in the coming years to face new variants. We therefore urgently need a clear report on what has not worked, an emergency plan to speed up the vaccination process this year and an updated, credible and long-term vaccine strategy that takes account of production and contractual problems.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: – Dear President Von der Leyen, In the fight against the coronavirus, the numbers are key, as the speed of the vaccination process depends on the lives of people. Unfortunately, however, centralised vaccine procurement is still not in line with the expectations of citizens and Member States, thereby risking the lives of Europeans and the faster relaunch of the European economy. The EU's level of instilation is still below 4 percent, while in Britain the index is now close to 20 percent, but we can also mention the United States, Israel or Serbia. The current, already very bad situation is made worse by the populism represented by the Hungarian left, which is living with anti-vaccination demagogy in my country, Hungary, and here in Brussels, attacking the President of the European Commission on party political grounds. I believe that it should be the responsibility and duty of the European Commission and the European Medicines Agency to obtain and authorise the safest vaccines as soon as possible, regardless of who manufactures them. Efficiency and accessibility should not be geopolitical issues when people's lives are at stake. The formula is simple: whoever's fast enough saves lives, who's slow, loses lives. We need more intensive, faster negotiations and a more proactive APPROACH to vaccine procurement in the EU. In order for the European Commission's vaccine procurement project to be successful, we must act immediately. We are all ready for this and we support you in this, Madam President.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: - Dear President, at European Union level, a joint effort was to take all possible measures to contain the pandemic and find a vaccine. This path is supported by financial support to the pharmaceutical industry at an important stage of research. Today, only a year after the beginning of the crisis, the vaccine is available not in the dynamics we counted on and this tells us about the necessity of strengthening our own production. But the undertaken is increasingly prudent in this unprecedented time with political wisdom and operational instruments. The European Commission's engagement in the long process of jointly ensuring a quality, effective and safe vaccine was driven by the best interests and intentions and solidarity. Using only its own resources would create a gap between economically unequal Member States. Yet what we want is information and transparency. Our citizens want it, and after a year of living under pandemic rules, they deserve it. I applaud your intention to communicate clearly, to create a platform for sharing data. I understand that we are in a complicated moment, that not all maps may be on the table, but without accurate and clear information we cannot make decisions and have valid arguments. We're fighting on multiple fronts right now. We want to preserve the lives of our citizens, ensure livelihoods, fight disinformation, anti-vaccination movements, preserve the economy and ultimately want to vaccinate our citizens. I welcome the introduction of a transparency mechanism and would like to know what else are our contractual options in case pharmaceutical companies do not comply with the contractual rules again. There is no single remedy for all political and social problems, but the most powerful weapon we possess, the vaccine, of course, must not be a weapon of divisiveness of our values.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Ms Zacarias, Madam President, honourable Members, let me first of all thank you for this vibrant debate, which is a testament of how this House has this very important role and how important this issue is that we are debating here today. I want to start from where President von der Leyen left off.  We are doing our best to fight the virus. Across the Union and across the world it is now abundantly clear that we will only meet this challenge if we all stick together. We are all fighting to defeat a common enemy: COVID. The vaccines against this pandemic are the key to unlocking the door out of this crisis. We will continue to work day and night to ensure that these vaccines are brought to our citizens and by the end of the summer we want 70% of adult Europeans to be vaccinated. We want to ensure that this happens in a fair and equitable way, in a way which ensures that this strategic public good is distributed as quickly as possible to all — to all our Member States, fairly and equally, regardless of size, always with their full agreement and in full transparency.  A total of 26 million vaccine doses have been delivered in Europe since December, and more than 17 million people have been vaccinated in every corner of Europe. The pace of vaccinations can, and should, increase and we are doing our best to ensure that this happens in the coming weeks.  Let us recall the three fundamental points which are at the very basis of the debate today. Firstly, that it was right that we Europeans procured the vaccine together in solidarity. Secondly, that we have a moral duty to show the same solidarity to partners in our neighbourhood and across the world. And thirdly, that we are already drawing on the lessons of what we can improve — the regulatory environment, the industrial ecosystem, the operational environment and the predictability our Member States should have to roll out vaccinations. We have drawn these lessons and we are already acting on them.  Now let me turn to some of your questions. Firstly, on transparency. I have stated several times in this House that, with the EU vaccine strategy, we have always strived for as much transparency as possible every single step of the way. We owe it to our institutions and our citizens to be transparent and accountable in our decisions, and this is the only way we can build trust in this critical area.  In order to enhance our cooperation even further, and as mentioned by the President, we propose the creation of a contact group on vaccines. This will allow us to regularly exchange views on the most pressing issues and, most importantly, to work together on finding solutions.  I welcome the fact that following our request, three of our contracts, as you know, have been made publicly available. Tomorrow the Johnson & Johnson contract will be available in a reading room. We will persist with other companies in order to obtain their agreement to make our contracts available to the Members of the Parliament and public at large as quickly as possible.  When it comes to vaccine production and deliveries, there are indeed many lessons to be learned from this process, and it’s perfectly natural for everyone to expect a rapid and seamless roll-out of vaccines. This is precisely why we had spread our investments across a broad portfolio of vaccine candidates and why we fixed the number of doses and delivery schedules in our agreements. I can assure you that we acted as fast as we could with, and on behalf of, all 27 Member States when it comes to securing doses and investing in production capacity with companies in looking at safety.  This was never about only prices or being difficult. It was about ensuring that our citizens would have access to the safest and most effective vaccines, that we would have strong provisions on liability, and that we had all the safety procedures in place. And all these are vital. We did expect that there would be hurdles along the way, including unexpected ones. We can for sure go back and find things that we could have done differently, even better, but now our focus is on ensuring that vaccines reach our citizens and the rest of the world as quickly as possible, working with companies to eliminate bottlenecks in production and also looking at adjusting and stepping up vaccine production for the new variants.  What we need now is an immediate response to the urgent threat of coronavirus variants and what we need going forward is the capacity at EU level to produce vaccines independently. As of next week, we will launch a biodefence preparedness programme, our first action under the new Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Authority (HERA). We will launch a public-private collaboration to develop and manufacture vaccines at scale to respond to the threat of new variants more forcefully. We know that preparedness is everything, but preparedness requires foresight, both in the current crisis and for any future ones.  Honourable Members, we fully share your sense of urgency. We’re on the same side and there are many pressing issues at play. You have raised many of them today and there will undoubtedly be more challenges ahead. The emergence of new variants only adds to this emergency and the sense of urgency. President von der Leyen said that this is a marathon, and it is. And we need to show the same level of determination, resilience and unity. This is why we need to cooperate closely with this House to find sustainable solutions to these crucial issues, because we are in this together. Collaboration and trust offer the surest path to overcoming this crisis, and this is what true solidarity is about.

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Covid-19 pandemic has underlined the importance of working together and how much that represents for the European project. He also reminded us that it was essential to take bold and courageous measures to meet common challenges. Solidarity, coordination, cooperation should continue to guide our response to Covid-19. That is what the citizens are asking of us and that is what we must commit ourselves to.  This Parliament has set a good example today with the adoption of the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism. It doesn't take much imagination to conceive of the chaos we could be in without a common strategy on vaccination. We would be competing with each other for scarce resources, without security and without equity. We would not have taken advantage of the scale of pan-European scientific power. Our voice and our ability to action would be much smaller.  Together we are stronger. And many members of this Parliament have said so here today, coming from various political families, showing well the need for interinstitutional solidarity to find the best solutions and, at the same time, to achieve what has been requested here: more transparency and monitoring in this process.  As much as there may be less positive points, we must all recognise that this European solidarity, with regard to the vaccination strategy, has been a determining factor in increasing the capacity of the member states' national health systems in responding to the pandemic.  We therefore support the Commission's efforts. We support your efforts, Madam President. Thank you for your continued determination. We will continue to support these efforts with a firm commitment that only then can we have more and better solutions in common. That's our duty. That's what the citizens ask of us. It is a question of working with ambition, realistically, effectively, to increase the production of vaccines, to better manage the issue of borders, to improve the level of research in the face of the different variants of the virus and, eventually, to bring new treatments as well. It is working together to combat disinformation to improve the level of our international cooperation.  These parliamentary debates are an important part of European democracy, they are an essential element in the relationship between the different institutions and are a direct bridge with our citizens. That is why I am beginning with an appeal: we are going to renew this sense of unity, of solidarity, so that we can emerge from this pandemic as a stronger, more resilient, fairer European Union. It's time to deliver.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: Writing. – There is no doubt that European coordination for the management of the COVID-19 pandemic is the only safe path for EU Member States. We're stronger together. European citizens are right to set the bar high. They require us to be speedy and efficient. Wrong manipulations and oligopolies are hard to forgive. In recent times there have indeed been some arrhythmias. To some extent they may be justified because of the unprecedented and complex health environment internationally. But there is no room for failure when human lives are at stake. We must respond immediately and effectively to the voices of criticism and questioning that damage the prestige and credibility of a united Europe. This will only be done by deeds. I am absolutely certain that in the near future we can turn the challenge into an opportunity. We can show more determination, faster reflexes, a fist in the negotiations. We can, with coordination and method, be worthy of the expectations of European citizens. We can prove that together we know how to overcome obstacles, win difficult battles and live up to our leading role in the global environment. In Greece we say "every beginning and difficult". But we also say that 'the result counts'. And, ultimately, all of us who support the European Union from the result will be judged.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: in writing. – The vaccine must become a public good, urgently accessible to every European citizen who wants to do so. We have now asked the President of the European Commission at a meeting on the future of the vaccination strategy at European level. European support and funding for the Cantacuzino Institute to produce vaccines again. It's a race against time. There are two essential things for this goal: 1.We must be able to produce increased quantities, with clear delivery times so as not to miss this race against time, by developing production centres in each Member State. 2.Am requested additional funding so that Romania could again produce vaccines at the Cantacuzino Institute.  It is clear that, at the moment, we need to apply a clear strategy, that plan B – which I keep proposing in Romania, but no one hears – which implies 3 clear measures applied simultaneously: 1.Fast testing extended, free – the only healthy option for prevention (obviously the safest way not to get infected with coronavirus is not to come into contact with a coronavirus carrier , symptomatic or not. 2. Immunization against time. 3.Finding effective medication (for prevention and therapy) – and here, no possibility should be neglected.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. – I am sincerely concerned by the recent reports of delivery delays and dose reductions compared to the forecast for the first quarter of 2021, regarding producers BioNTech-Pfizer and AstraZeneca. I believe that these delays seriously undermine the Union and Member States vaccination plans’ objectives and the total effectiveness of the European COVID-19 vaccine strategy and the Union’s exit from the health emergency, including in terms of recovery economic. As done for the introduction of generic drugs for HIV at affordable prices 20 years ago, and the distribution of another vaccine during the polio epidemic in the 1950s, to guarantee widespread and equitable access to vaccines on a global scale, I ask the European Union: to evaluate to support the adoption of a moratorium that allows the suspension of patents and the sharing of technology, data, know-how, allowing generics manufacturers to contribute to increasing global availability, including through support for India and South Africa’s proposal at the WTO; to evaluate, as a member of the WTO, subject to an appropriate legislative act, the granting of a compulsory license for the production of covid-19 vaccines to public agencies or a generic drug manufacturer, according to TRIPS and the Doha Declaration.

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: In writing. The European vaccine strategy has proved to be a failure! From the lack of transparency in the negotiations with the multinationals of the drug to the delivery, there have been only failures. Let us take the lead on this incredible series of errors by the Commission, starting with the negotiations on the purchase price. I wonder how to explain such a difference between prices, including, according to Belgian Secretary of State Eva de Bleeker, between 1.8 euros for the AstraZeneca vaccine and 18 dollars for Moderna? Second, the Commission kept the contracts and exemption clauses of manufacturers secret. The MEPs, elected by the people, were certainly allowed to consult two copies, but they had to settle for illegible copies, the crucial passages of which had been defaced. And finally, we can cite the shambles about deliveries, since pharmaceutical companies have favoured the best bidder, notwithstanding the juicy instalments paid by the Commission. Only one observation is that it is imperative for nations to retain their sovereignty over public health, as the Commission is not in a position to deal with major health crises.

name: Alin MITUȚA
text: in writing. – Some Member States would not have had access to vaccines against COVID-19 today if the EU had not had a common vaccination strategy. But if we compare ourselves to the top countries, the PACE of the EU is slower.  The Commission has had delays in signing contracts and has failed to help companies increase their production capacity. In addition, it has not transparented the contracts and has not yet published a precise delivery timetable for each Member State. The Commission must therefore act expeditiously by publishing a precise timetable for supplies of vaccines for each Member State.  A concrete plan is also needed to increase production capacity and guarantee access to the necessary raw materials. An existing solution that requires development is to contract the production capacities of companies that do not yet have their own vaccine.  At the same time, there is a need for transparency of contracts and renegotiation of confidentiality clauses, where appropriate. Let us not forget neighbouring countries with European aspirations. For example, the Republic of Moldova still does not have access to vaccines and needs to be supported. Romania has promised to deliver 200,000 vaccines, but more is needed.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – This is the second plenary session in a row whereby the main point of discussion is focusing on the COVID-19 theme, and rightly so. Millions have died. Millions ended up prisoners in their homes. Businesses and jobs have been lost. Meanwhile, pharmaceutical companies have been competing hard to achieve fast research and production breakthroughs and then to obtain regulatory approval for their vaccine against the virus. We needed this race to happen in order to acquire swiftly control over the pandemic. So now that we have reached the production stage for the vaccines that have been created, it is incredible that world governments remain apparently tied to a business as usual approach regarding the production and delivery of vaccines. Globally, many companies are able and ready to master the knowhow and participate in the production and provision of vaccine doses. Oligopolising global manufacturing of COVID-19 vaccines is not working now, and it will not work in the future. Therefore, I fully support the call for the relevant patent rights to be waived, in order to allow a massive production worldwide of vaccines and a subsequent fast and wide-ranging rollout of vaccination programmes. At stake are hundreds of thousands, indeed millions, of lives.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Next item: Council and Commission statements — Democratic control of social media and protection of fundamental rights (2021/2512(RSP)). I remind Members that none of the debates in this meeting will be heard on the basis of an application, nor will we adopt a Blue Card.  The first speaker on behalf of the Council is Ana Paula Zacarias.

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, recent weeks have shown that even the most robust democratic structures are not safe from damage. What happened on the other side of the Atlantic must inform our debate in Europe, as our democratic societies are not immune to the harmful influence of hate speech, disinformation, fake news and incitement to violence.  These events have also shed light on the increased importance of online platforms and social media companies in shaping public debate. They have highlighted the growing interconnection that exists between digital transformation and democracy, which is one of the priorities of the Portuguese Presidency. It is unquestionable that social media companies have the status of public squares, which means they should have responsibilities when it comes to enhancing citizens’ participation and ensuring freedom of expression. Nevertheless, freedom of expression is not absolute. It should be balanced with the goal of combating illegal hate speech, incitement to violence and radicalisation, both online and offline. What is illegal? What is illegal offline must be illegal online. Online platforms have repeatedly been criticised for the lack of transparency in the use of algorithms, on content moderation and for targeting users on the basis of a vast amount of personal data generated from online activity. The digital space has also become a breeding ground for conspiracies and fake news. Disinformation spreads faster than any virus. Education, media and digital literacy are the best vaccines against that.  We expect online platforms to play their part in this common fight, but it is up to the democratic institutions – our laws, our courts – to set the rules of the game, to define what is illegal and what is not, what must be removed and what should not be. Without democratic scrutiny and a level playing field, there is a risk to users’ rights, information flows and public participation.  The protection of fundamental rights requires transparent and consistent rules for all of us, including social media outlets. The recently proposed European Democracy Action Plan, the Digital Services Act and the Digital Markets Act are important steps forward and will make the digital environment more transparent and actors like social media companies more accountable. The Council has already started the discussions on these important instruments. These initiatives must also be considered in conjunction with the upcoming Media and Audiovisual Action Plan, which will be the subject of the Council conclusions that we intend to adopt during our Presidency.  In addition, we are expecting, for the third quarter of the year, a Commission legislative proposal to ensure greater transparency in the area of sponsored content in a public context, complementing the Digital Services Act. The Council is ready to cooperate with this Parliament to ensure adoption sufficiently ahead of the 2024 European elections. Moreover, the Presidency will host the Digital Assembly in Lisbon in June, where the concepts of digital democracy and digital rights will be discussed.  The Presidency intends to consolidate the idea that Europe is a reference in the digital era and that our values and way of doing business are a competitive advantage. We want to place this idea at the heart of the European Digital Strategy for the next digital decade. The Presidency will also hold a high—level conference on the future of journalism and its interconnection with artificial intelligence, with a special focus on the robotisation of news production.  The current times have brought into sharp relief the unavoidable reality that what is happening online shapes our lives, beliefs and choices. It deeply influences what we buy or who we vote for, who we listen to, and even our opinion on vaccines. In its recent conclusions, the Council stressed the need to foster a well—functioning digital public sphere, greater accountability and improved transparency in addressing disinformation. Countering this scourge is crucial to preserve open political debate and the effective participation of citizens. We need to prevent social media functioning as an echo chamber which suppresses different points of view, and we need to make sure our citizens are equipped to manage the flood of information they are exposed to every day. In times such as this, believing in unreliable information may be lethal. We welcome, therefore, the work on the Rapid Alert System and other monitoring instruments. We encourage support for media and digital literacy, media pluralism, media independence and fact checking.  Let me reassure you that the Presidency is committed to working with the European Parliament, the Commission and the European External Action Service on these crucial issues in order to promote and protect our fundamental rights and our democracy.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for organising this debate. I know we don’t have much time, so I will try to be brief rather than exhaustive in my introductory remarks. Social media has transformed the way we communicate with each other, debate on political issues or do campaigning. There are a lot of new opportunities, but also a lot of problems. With the recent attack on the Capitol, we’ve got a tangible yet tragic proof that many people have simply lost trust in democratic institutions. Going online only exacerbated many of the existing problems and cleavages in our societies. The US events are the moment of reckoning, also because they reminded us of the power Twitter, Facebook and other technological corporations possess. The fact that they can permanently remove an account of a sitting president based on vague criteria and unclear oversight is really worrying.  Even though, I believe President Trump’s irresponsible incitement to violence deserved action, it is high time to reign in the unchecked power of the digital corporations. Whatever we do, we must uphold the principle of freedom of speech. I do not want to create the ministry of or arbiter of truth. This is the main principle. So what can we do? First, we need tougher regulation, more enforceable obligations and to increase the responsibility of digital players. We have recently proposed the Digital Services Act, that will increase accountability of online platforms and clarify the rules for taking down illegal content, including hate speech and incitement to violence. This is a ground-breaking proposal, and will also give us the tools for stronger monitoring and enforcement of the obligations of online platforms. We need these rules urgently and we are ready to work together with you and the Member States to quickly adopt this law. What can we do already now, while waiting for the Digital Services Act to become law? We can equip ourselves already now with better tools to fight disinformation and harmful content. The European Democracy Action Plan is our map of what we should do next in this respect. We can already now strike a new pact against disinformation with better accountability of algorithms and no arbitrary decisions by big online platforms. We can and should have more transparency of their policies and access to relevant data. In the Digital Services Act we moved away from assessing harmful content and focused on the manipulative techniques of online distribution. We need to go more in detail on this – paid promotion and paid likes, reactions from fake accounts, bots can be particularly dangerous for democracy, notably during elections. This is why I will propose new regulation on online political advertising.  And freedom of speech is not the same as freedom of reach. Regulation alone will not, and in my view should not, address all the details of digital life. When I talked to Mark Zuckerberg and other CEOs of the Big Tech, we discussed solutions that go beyond regulation because we must not sacrifice freedom of expression, which requires open space, be it online or offline.  They cannot judge and evaluate every piece of content posted on them. This is why we need to reshape the thinking of tech companies and tech workers. Architects follow not only law but also ethical codes to ensure that the buildings they design are safe for people. Coders and IT experts should have a similar approach when designing their algorithms, something I rarely hear from the tech executives. And third, we cannot focus on social media platforms alone. We need to make our education fit for digital reality. We all have to become more digitally literate, understand the basics of what is happening online and why we are seeing certain content. This will allow us to navigate safely online.  As a person coming, as many of you do, from an ex—totalitarian country, in my case communist Czechoslovakia, I have tasted life without democracy and freedom of speech. I believe we need to bring order to the digital expression of democracy and to end the digital Wild West. What is illegal offline must be illegal online, but we also have to work on restoring trust among citizens. Facts belong to everyone. Opinions belong to an individual. And this distinction has been damaged and can only be repaired if there is trust in science, in authorities and society. We all have a very important role to play in this as well.

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear! The war for media freedom has been going on in Poland for several hours. The war over whether Polish citizens can know the truth or whether power is to decide what this truth is supposed to be. By lying that it is about more taxes, power is really about greater obedience to citizens. Because power, through the media, obeys the citizens it wants to cultivate. As in Hungary. As in Russia. What should we do when the authorities of a Member State of the European Union deprive their citizens of the right to reliable information? Again, Parliament is to say: does our Brussels agreement not have permission to do so? Again, he just has to talk? Snag your foot and scream? There is a limit to which helplessness becomes humiliation. The humiliation of those who, alone, defend freedom and democracy. As the Roman maxim says, "Vim vi repellere licet" – forcibly repel force. A force adequate to the threat. I therefore call on the entire European Union to act accordingly. That is why I call on all the free media in the world to show solidarity with the Polish free media. Because if it happened to us, it can meet you as well. Here I finish. What is left of my time is for silence. For silence, which let it be a warning. Because if we do not react now, soon this moment of silence can become a minute's silence, silence over the coffin of Polish democracy. And since Polish, then also European.

name: Marina KALJURAND
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, all this disinformation and hate speech is not a new issue; it has been developing for years. Although some measures have been introduced, such as the East StratCom Task Force, they have so far been insufficient to counter efficiently the assault on our democracies. After the riots in Capitol Hill, the ultimate price of allowing disinformation and hatred to spread unchecked online is clear for all of us. Finding a balance between limiting harmful content while maintaining freedom of speech might be a challenging task, but it is doable and it must be addressed now.  I look forward to this debate, particularly as we now have a concrete opportunity to address these issues through new draft legislation, including the Digital Services Act, which will establish new rules, including on advertising, transparency, illegal content removal and data access. Continuing to improve the Commission’s code of conduct on disinformation is a necessary step.  But we also need to extend our offline safeguards to the online world by limiting the use of targeted advertising and the profiling of users. I welcome the Commission’s initiative on online political advertising.  We also need to explore ways to promote media literacy skills to increase users’ knowledge. With the GDPR, the EU led the way and set an example. Now we need to go further. The Digital Services Act can facilitate the development of our digital economy while protecting fundamental rights and providing increased security from online harms. This is our EU opportunity to lead the way, and I hope that we can do it together with our allies in the United States and beyond.

name: Dragoş TUDORACHE
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, in a world where being connected has become as important as a fundamental right, the rise of social media has fundamentally transformed our society. The idols of our children are born on social media, we can be bullied or abused on social media, elections are lost or won on social media. Looking at the years ahead and the decisions facing us, I want to make three points.  First, there is no online and offline world. There is only one world, one in which we must protect our citizens’ rights and our democracies in equal measure, both online and offline. The Digital Services Act (DSA) is a good step in this direction, and I commend the Commission for the level of ambition in the proposal.  Second, social media has become a political tool for some, a tactical battlefield for others. Politicians, informal communities, structured organisations, and even states themselves, all embrace social media as the weapon of choice. But social media platforms are private companies so they alone do not have the incentive, the means or the legitimacy to take on politicians or state actors. They require democratic oversight and assistance for that, just as we require from them cooperation and compliance. So we are not adversaries, us and the platforms. We need to find together a burden-sharing equilibrium that guarantees both the common good and technological progress.  My third point is that social media is global and geopolitical, so we need to use our entire diplomatic arsenal to protect our citizens’ rights and our way of life online. We need to work with the United States and other like-minded partners to define the rules of the future based on our shared values. And we need to use our dissuasion tools to address appropriately states such as Russia who use social media to sabotage our democracies and our common European project, or states such as China who work to build an alternative digital future without playing by the same rules or without relating to the same values.

name: Annalisa TARDINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, large platforms and social media undoubtedly offer great opportunities, useful to society, all the more so in today's situation in which physical distances have extended, but which must move within clear rules.  Web giants have for years claimed to be neutral containers. Today, however, it is clear that their policies affect the real world, proclaiming themselves censors of what are acceptable messages and which are not. And this leads us to a big question, which has precise political and legal connotations: who has to decide what can be published in the digital space? You see, I don't think any party interests are at stake here. It is not a question of defending the ideas of a party or an individual elected representative, but of protecting the values of democracy and freedom of expression, including of the individual citizen. That is why, as a League, we have called for this debate. I believe that a possible darkening of the pages of Donald Trump or Ursula von der Leyen or of a newspaper or anyone should be decided by laws that define clear parameters and procedures, and not thanks to homemade guidelines from private giants that almost act as judges of democracy. This is a role for the legislators, to whom we cannot and must not abdicate. The European Union must act without delay to safeguard the democratic and free debate on social media.

name: Alexandra GEESE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, with so much information available and the possibility for billions of people to express their opinions freely in the Internet, democracy should flourish. Why is the opposite happening? Why are we seeing disinformation and hate speech thriving, fuelling extremism and violence, as we have all seen on Capitol Hill? The answer is easy. Because this information is circulating on giant private platforms whose only goal is maximising profit. And we are the raw material. Companies like Google and Facebook track every single step we take online and offline, and put micro-profiles and models that allow them to predict our behaviour. Those predictions are then sold to advertisers. This is where the revenue of those companies comes from: from us, from our behaviour. And the same micro-profiles allow the companies to keep us very effectively on their platforms, appealing to strong feelings like fear and hate and anger, which trigger us to interact longer, to share more, to generate more revenue. Hence the hate, hence the disinformation. And now some people think that we can solve the problem these companies have created by asking them to arbitrarily censor this harmful content themselves. That is not an option for democracy. But the good news is the remedy is easy. Let us ban the surveillance business model, starting with a ban on targeted advertising. This is something we can easily do in the Digital Services Act. Colleagues, let’s do it.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the Digital Services Act will stimulate the digital single market, which is crucial for our SMEs, among other things. It is good that we want to curb the omnipotence of the platforms, but the notice and action system will lead to censorship as a result of the reporting, knowledge and liability mechanism. The platforms will pass every message through their algorithm resulting in hyperpolitical correct censorship, as was the case with Facebook. The EU must take freedom of expression as a starting point for these platforms to impose a universal service obligation. After all, the platforms are both the mail and mailboxes of the twenty-first century. Censorship should be limited to an exhaustive series of serious cases. It is up to the courts to rule on the rest, as is the rule of law. I come from one of the few countries where censorship is constitutionally prohibited. Let that also guide the European Union.

name: Anne-Sophie PELLETIER
text: on behalf of the band The Left. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, 'how do we stop men from raping?' Hundreds of Twitter accounts have been suspended for asking this question. So I use my freedom as a citizen and my position as an MEP to question you. Does anyone dispute my freedom to ask this question that many consider legitimate? Let us have the courage to say "stop" to the major platforms on the opaque censorship organized against freedom of expression and opinion. On the internet, the freedom of some must not stop where the big bosses of social media have decided. The Internet must be a space for individual and collective emancipation, without excessive centralisation of regulatory powers in the hands of private actors. The pre-eminent place of platforms in moderation of political public debate is a threat to our democratic models. Their monopoly, their algorithms, their conditions of use, the inability of public authorities to control moderation are problems that structure the democratic impasse in which we are. Censorship of political figures, censorship of speech and erasure of content without a court order, censorship of feminist accounts, censorship of campaigns to raise awareness of LGBT rights, highlighting controversial content, are different illustrations of attacks on citizens' freedoms and net neutrality. Censorship is never the answer. It is only through media pluralism and educational policies that develop critical thinking and tolerance that our societies will be able to combat all forms of online hatred and the manipulation of information.  Transparency, shared accountability and the protection of citizens' fundamental rights must be the guidelines for future frameworks of digital services legislation and legislation on the digital market, as it is up to politicians to frame the influence of social networks on political debate before they frame it for us.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, social media has expanded opportunities for participation in public life and political debate, facilitating access to information and freedom of expression. However, we are not yet adequately protected from the proliferation of fake news, discriminatory content, incitement to hatred and violence. We have experimented with how campaigns of disinformation and foreign interference can find fertile ground to influence public opinion, to polarise societies, to undermine democratic processes. With the Democracy Action Plan and the proposals on digital services and markets, we therefore expect significant action to regulate opaque microtargeting practices and to achieve greater transparency on the functioning of algorithms in online content control and moderation procedures. At the same time, however, it is essential to mitigate the risk of conflict with freedom of opinion resulting from decisions taken on the basis of discretionary powers of an oligarchy of private commercial entities, rather than on the basis of rules that give greater guarantees of freedom and impartiality.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Dear colleagues, now that the interventions in the name of the political groups have ended, I would like to remind you that we have a very long speaker list in this debate, a really long one. So the only way to keep to the time is if you keep to your speaking time. I would like to say that I am going to be very strict and very loud and very serious about keeping to the speaking time, so please keep to your speaking time.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, Madam Secretary of State, Commissioner, the public sphere and the sphere of communication have changed radically. From the world in which we had mediators and mediations (in politics, parliaments, parties, institutions; in the social sphere, the press, television, radio), we suddenly passed through social networks to the illusion of direct democracy.  The mediators have fallen and now, on social media, everyone thinks they can abolish the media and traditional media. Everyone thinks that through direct participation they can even replace parliaments. There is no shortage of countries in which the abolition of parliaments is enacted or advocated. No more mediators. Only direct participation, through social networks, with a vote that even in laws and decisions could be daily through digital instruments.  The problem is that suddenly we realize that behind social networks and the companies that hold them, there is a mediator, a hidden mediator, a secret mediator, which is the algorithm, which is the controller, who is the owner of social networks and therefore freedom of expression is in danger. You're in danger of outside interference, you're in danger by hidden mediation, you're in danger for lack of democratic regulation, and so we can't be in the hands of social media. We have to put them in our hands. It is this challenge that is being debated here today.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: – Madam President, although we are now one year into the pandemic, Facebook only decided this week to take down posts claiming vaccines cause autism. It took them one year to act against fake news. And a study released this week reveals that 83% of young people have already been confronted with fake news on social media and 25% of them cannot distinguish between fake news and real news. And this is, in my eyes, a threat. For years, and I think I am not exaggerating when I say social media platforms and Trump, for example, have benefited from each other. Only after Trump’s election defeat and him calling on his supporters to storm the Capitol did they decide to ban him. That means that Facebook, YouTube and Twitter took more than four years to ban him. And while I think it was right to ban Mr Trump from social media platforms, I would say that private companies should never act without reference to the law, and as the European Union this is the way we have to go.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: – Madam President, I think it’s now clear that most social media have wildly outgrown their founders’ expectations and their impact on society is felt globally and, of course, in each individual country. With such great power must come greater responsibility, because today there is very little incentive for social media corporations to ensure that their products are not used as vehicles for the mass spread of hate or lies or disinformation. In Slovakia, last year, journalists tracked 56 death threats posted publicly on Facebook, and actually had to call Facebook’s PR department before the death threats were taken down. So it was because of the action of journalists that the threats actually disappeared.  This is illustrative of a much bigger problem, which is that the social media corporations are unable or unwilling to ensure that their content not only meets ethical standards, but actually complies with the legislation and the laws of the country in which they operate. So, when we think about the future, the regulation must not be virtual, but real.

name: Alessandra BASSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in the media diversity and pluralism should be linked by the same fundamental objective in a liberal democracy: to offer citizens a variety of content. We know that in the DSA, in particular, large platforms are in fact obliged to equip themselves with internal mechanisms to receive notifications from any person or body of content deemed illegal. The same article states that the notices received give rise to actual knowledge or awareness, effectively forcing you to remove supposed illegal content or disable access to it. In essence, any report made in supposed good faith obliges removal. I find it reckless that the subjective assessment of individuals or bodies can have a decisive influence on full respect for freedom of speech. Do we want to go in the opposite direction to the pluralism that should characterise a democracy? I think we urgently need to think about this.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: – Madam President, democratic scrutiny and protection of fundamental rights has to go hand-in-hand with addressing the issue of the dominant position of some tech platforms. Recent events in the United States demonstrated that large platforms, due to their size, have a systemic role in amplifying and shaping information flows and create parallel information bubbles. With the new Digital Markets Act, we need to enable an environment where people can not only scrutinise if they are being targeted by malicious actors via the platform, but also gain back effective control, where they have a choice to switch to an alternative, decentralised, open and privacy-friendly service. Only in this case can democratic scrutiny and the protection of fundamental rights have full effect.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Does the world's power be taken over by the big tech corporations, which already control public debate today, influence election results, don't count with anyone, go unpunished? Early internet gave freedom, acted like Hyde Park online. The goal of the Silicon Valley giants in the early days of their business was to give people access to information for free, and their principle of "do no evil." But that was yesterday, and today we have "1984" again," predicted the future of Orwell and other science fiction writers. This time, however, it's really happening. You don't agree with Big Brother, it's going to shut your mouth, even if you're president of the United States. The victim is always conservative views on the web. Several Big Tech billionaires, in the name of leftist ideology, have declared war on freedom of expression, and their actions can be compared to those of totalitarian states.  We are witnessing an unprecedented threat to freedom. On the one hand, censorship and account blocking, on the other hand digital surveillance and manipulation. The European Commission's inadibility towards these monopolistic practices is astonishing. It is high time to counter act and introduce regulations to protect freedom of expression online.

name: Sira REGO
text: – Madam President, Abascal in Spain, Salvini in Italy, Le Pen in France, Orbán in Hungary, etc., etc. All of them with a common denominator: hate speech, racist bulos, LGBTIphobia, machismo, the exaltation of fascism. That is why, for me, the substantive debate is that of impunity, that of tolerance with which the narrative of the violation of human rights of the far right has been accepted and, from there, the use of social media as a spreader of hate speech. A danger. And, of course, it is normal for the question to arise: should it be a multinational that determines when and why the use of an account is limited, or should it be a great anti-phasical consensus that results in public regulation to do so? Of course, we believe that you should bet on the latter. The only way to guarantee the fundamental right of access to truthful information, the only way to eradicate hate speech, is the intervention of the public authorities, the firm alliance to expel hatred from any public space.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, we are faced with the emergence of a new, powerful and unscrupulous mafia that is more dangerous than all forms of organised crime so far. It's about a mafia that uses the media instead of guns, and it's a media of all forms for a campaign of fear to sell billions of its products. For the past year, almost all mainstream media across Europe and the world have been notifying citizens and publishing untruths, completely untrue data can be found in all media published in the same way. It is clear that this is the same source of funding that wants to enable their financiers to sell several billion of their products every year through a fear campaign. Be aware fear campaigns won't stop because they make tens of billions every year.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Madam President, what we hear today is that we as a Chamber are sometimes somewhat inconsistent in our calls to platforms, and thus by this we risk becoming irrelevant. We urged the platforms to act during the Rohingya case in 2016 when thousands of people were killed, but in 2021, when five people were killed in the Capitol attacks, we asked the platforms why did you act and silence Trump? So the problem, I think sometimes, is that we often call for different things.  I accept that platforms should not have the right to easily silence a president, of course, but what are the rules that would make this impossible in the future? I believe our job is to create them, and we are indeed on the right track. But in order to create them, we need to make sure we have clear definitions and visions of how we actually treat platforms. Do we consider them to be media? Are they a type of providers similar to cable TV operators? Or are they simply an environment in a place where everything is possible and can happen?  I think we need a coherent definition of that, and only then could we perhaps be consistent in our calls and, most importantly, successful in our efforts to create a just and a good environment, good rules for platforms that most importantly safeguard our fundamental rights and values.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Madam President, media freedom has been in the spotlight for a reason in recent years. Imagine that years ago, when social media wasn't there, newspapers and news outlets would all be spending fake information, wrong. It may have been the advertisers who misled, but not the press, the reporters, the leaders. Today, however, there are a series of verified and unverified information channels available to the individual to help them create the truth.
