I am very concerned about how easy it is to publish a complete lie and disinformation and not take any responsibility for it, saying that it is about freedom of speech and in this way discrediting the target of the attack. Such and similar publications, attacks, insults in the majority today are used by the populist right, which, with its autocratic tendencies, undermines democracy and booses fundamental human rights. They even see free media as their enemies and not as a fundamental aspect of a free society. One of the more effective tactics of spreading disinformation has proved a partisan usage of the newly formed media, which serve exclusively to promote party ideology. Unfortunately, such practices are used by a growing number of politicians who slurr and spread untruths about their political opponents, including in Slovenia, the Slovenian Prime Minister. Different views and beliefs are, of course, something completely normal. When constructive dialogue is replaced by lies and offensive or even hateful rhetoric, our democracy is truly in danger. That's when things go so far as a coup happens, as happened on capitol hill. We find ourselves at a crossroads between freedom and the rights of the individual to express themselves, and I very much welcome the action plan presented by the European Commission.

name: Karen MELCHIOR
text: – Madam President, we have no digital democracy. We have democracy. We have no digital human rights. We have human rights. Our freedom of expression must be protected equally online as we protect it offline. More and more of our communication and democracy is taking place online and, under COVID, it has quickly become much more, as we no longer make a distinction between the online and the offline but rather regard it as one and the same – our lives, our reality, our democracy. What that means is that the same principles of human rights must be respected online as well as offline. In the past decade, we’ve observed the platformisation of the internet. Openness and free spirit have been consolidated into the monopoly of a few platforms. Therefore, the regulation of digital platforms has become even more important. However, the laws of physics online are different from those in the offline world. Therefore, we cannot simply apply regulation designed for the offline world online. Attempting to do so leads to a restriction of our human rights and has a chilling effect on our democracy.

name: Tom VANDENDRIESSCHE
text: Mr President, social media today is what printing was in the Middle Ages: a tool for citizens to express their views and defend their interests. As in the past, however, the ruling elite reacts with censorship and oppression to determine what the truth is, under the guise of fighting so-called fake news. But a truth that must be protected by censorship is a lie. Under the guise of combating so-called hate speech, the fight against so-called hate speech is to criminalise resistance to unwanted migration and multicultural population. But just as a mother takes care of her children, this resistance is not out of hatred for what is strange, but out of love for what is its own. A democracy cannot exist without freedom of expression. That is not a question of left or right, or of agreeing or disagreeing; that is a fundamental right that protects us all from tyranny. Censorship on social media should therefore be punished. We must break up the Silicon Valley oligarchy to protect the fundamental rights and fundamental freedoms of our citizens and our democracy.

name: Gwendoline DELBOS-CORFIELD
text: – Madam President, the NGO AlgorithmWatch reports that existing transparency tools have failed. Our laws are not yet fit for purpose in the digital world. Our democracies are not ready for the challenges to our liberties and fundamental rights. We often debate these issues, but we still do not have adequate rules at the European level. What we need most here is transparency of algorithm, to hold platforms accountable for the impact on democratic processes and to scrutinise their actions. We need transparency of algorithm to share the data with researchers, for example, at the new European Digital Media Observatory. We need transparency of algorithm to fight disinformation, and we need transparency to help us understand how online spaces have become hotbeds of systemic inequality and discrimination. Women and minorities are deserting the online space more and more often, after extremely violent experiences. We are not just talking about a few isolated cases, but about a problem that is becoming more and more mainstream, and we do not have this transparency of algorithm.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, like the ECR, we have called for this debate because most of our social, educational, economic and political relations are now taking place on digital platforms, and it is not possible to deny regulation to private multinationals, especially if this affects our democracies.  It may or may not like what a simple European citizen or the President of the United States of America says at a certain time in history, but their freedom of expression can only be restricted or suppressed if it is determined by a public authority, against which it may appeal if it is believed that it has been wronged. What is illegal offline must also be illegal online, it was said just now. Right. It is in fact the so-called legal reserve which undersea the rule of law.

name: Niyazi KIZILYÜREK
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Social media must not become a platform for hatred, racism, disinformation and hatred. Free access to the Internet, information and communication must be guaranteed for all and access to the Internet must be a public good. A free Internet with democratically controlled platforms is therefore the order of the day. This means: common EU rules, in particular strict anti-monopoly or antitrust control; active participation of Internet companies; involvement of civil society. In addition, the various platforms must commit to clearly expressed terms and conditions. Users must also have the right to take data and relationships from one social network to another. After all, it is high time for fair taxation and distribution of the enormous profits of the Internet giants. The rich finally pay!

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, recriminations and blank moral crowns; The United States, China or the European Union? With relevant digital agreements serving the interests of the groups and under the pretext of the protection of personal data, the European Union and the United States compete to control the mass recording, file, marketing and exploitation of data by state and other agencies and groups, on the basis of their astronomical profits, which — indeed — are multiples in the midst of a pandemic. At the same time, they cooperate by distracting and transmitting personal data and information to the backs of the peoples, intensifying the snitching and repression against the labour movement. As long as the data, their collection and processing are owned and controlled by the monopolies of the urban states that serve capitalist exploitation, there is no way to protect them. The labour struggle and the struggle to defend popular rights and freedoms are inextricably linked to the struggle to overthrow this barbarity that turns enormous scientific and technological possibilities into new bonds at the expense of the peoples.

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear colleagues, It is now commonplace for internet giants to delete opinions that they do not like ideologically at the touch of a button. Blocking an American president, regardless of his person or image, is completely unacceptable and violates democratic principles. Today, large social platforms are no longer simply social networks that make it easier to connect with your friends, but also online platforms that affect all aspects of life: business, public services, art, culture, public discourse and thus politics. Developments in recent months have clearly shown that the leaders of the tech giants have become political actors restricting freedom of expression, where appropriate.  In the absence of rules, they abuse their position: they delete, moderate, censor as they please. Much of the political expression is now on the web, so it is necessary to ensure that freedom of expression is always on the Internet. Tech giants can't be arbiers of publicity. Free expression is a cornerstone of democracy and can only be restricted in exceptional cases and only on the basis of laws. If we have laws governing the functioning of the written and electronic press, then the same is necessary for the Internet. We need rules that induce internet giants to operate legally, transparently and verifiablely and do not allow them to arbitrarily restrict the freedom of all of us in their own interests.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! Social media today is far more than just virtual yearbooks or isolated chat services. Their distribution and use has turned them into public spaces. Posts on social media turn into news on TV, newspapers and radio, and the news media share their stories on social platforms, where young people in particular get the majority of their news. Here, citizens influence politicians, and politicians. There is no doubt that social media plays a major role in the democratic conversation, and that is why we must insist on democratic rules of the game.  Regulating virtual public space is a complicated task. I believe that we must have three principles for further work, legality, transparency and redress. What is legally offline must also be legal online. That must be our first principle. It must not be the taste of social media that restricts freedom of expression. Secondly, there must be transparency in the decisions of the platforms. As a legislator, we need to be able to gain insight into the algorithms that promote or inhibit posts and the decisions that underlie removing posts. Finally, there must be remedies so that social media users can have their case tried if their content is removed. We must ensure the best conditions for the democratic conversation, even when it is done in virtual terms. That is why today is a really important debate.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Mrs Zacarias, anti-democratic viruses are circulating on social media right now that nullifies the democratic immune system of many people. Forming tribes around dogmas of ideological hostility is simple and has consequences in our real life. All totalitarianism begins with the disqualification of adversaries, by their dehumanization. We talk about democratic control of social networks, but the first space is that of those of us who hold public office, and especially of people with government responsibilities. Encouraging ideological hostility from governments is the most serious game: we have seen it in the United States, in Russia, in Hungary, in the Catalan region; We know this with the second vice president of my country, Pablo Iglesias. Commissioner Jourová, it would be interesting to have an ethical, European code of use of social networks by public authorities and public office, as a way of clarifying and establishing the standards of behaviour required of public and government officials. This code would be a basis for Member States to be able to incorporate such criteria into their national rules on good governance.

name: Philippe OLIVIER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what is freedom to express yourself if you are forbidden with paper and ink? Yet this is what is happening around the world today for citizens, activists, personalities and elected officials who are arbitrarily censored by social networks, without prior condemnation and without the possibility of appeal. In France, for example, senator LR Sébastien Meurant, ex-LREM MP Joaquim Son-Forget and MP Emmanuelle Ménard, all of them censored by Twitter for thinking differently, are the case. To come up with a different idea is not a crime, it is a right. Our European Parliament would grow to defend freedom of expression in the face of the new censors that are the giants of the Net. It is a difficult fight, but freedom of expression only makes sense if it protects ideas, all ideas, even those that can go against the tide. The others, the official truths, as we know, are admitted even in the worst dictatorships.

name: Patrick BREYER
text: – Madam President, if the dominant internet platforms were states, they would be dictatorships that use an army of robots to spy on their citizens and manipulate them, that dictate the news headlines, that arbitrarily censor what their citizens may say, that cut off communication channels with citizens of other countries, that expel them at will from their country. The EU must stop putting these tech despots and their error—prone machines in charge of curing society and of preventing violence and crime, lies and hate because this only fuels the despot’s powers, and despots will use despotic means.  The weapons of a democracy are humans, the rule of law and independent courts to take decisions. Let’s start setting up our own federated platforms and make corporate platforms interconnect. Let democracy reign in the digital age, not corporations and their machines.

name: Robert ROOS
text: – Mr President, big tech is too powerful and its power must be broken. Citizens who interfere in the public debate are digitally steered in a certain direction through selective algorithms and moderation. That is unacceptable. Social media platforms are the soapboxes of the 21st century: a platform on which everyone can express their opinion, no matter how controversial, unfathial or contrarian. The debate must therefore be free to conduct both online and offline, without interference from any public authority and without respect for borders. This is defined in Article 11 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and is a fundamental starting point that must always be respected in this House. We must combat illegal content, child pornography and incitement to violence, but protect freedom of expression. The only filter function in the immeasurably large spectrum of opinions should be determined not by the EU or big tech oligarchs with a political agenda, but by the power of public debate itself.

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Madam President, while the internet widened the scope of social dialogue and freedom of speech, the past decade revealed the unfortunate truth that the internet also grants unlimited space for extremist ideologies. It also showed that dangerous groups and echo chambers can be formed not only in the Third World with deep social divisions, but also in the United States and elsewhere in the developed world.  Populists are quick to exploit the advantages offered by social media, and where they have a grip on power they already started speaking about regulating it themselves. In my native Hungary, the Orbán government is already drafting national legislation to regulate social media and the internet. We have no doubt about their real intentions: provide legal protection for the next smear campaign and sabotage the work of the opposition.  Self-regulation is no longer sufficient. It requires action internationally and simultaneously in fighting fake news and shaping public democratic discourse. It is high time to create a European public media service.

name: Sven SIMON
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. Social media is both an opportunity and a threat to democracy. When we talk about democratic control of social media and the protection of fundamental rights, it is at the heart of our liberal democracy. Democracy, the rule of law, but above all fundamental rights that can be ensnared individually – that is our European identity. The fundamental right to freedom of expression is of fundamental importance. If we want to protect it and at the same time fight fake news, then first of all we have to start with ourselves, and if we communicate ourselves, do not spread false facts in the political sphere. When we talk about the Mercosur agreement, for example, in international trade agreements, we have to stick to the facts. When we talk about vaccination policy in Europe and what is in the Treaty with AstraZeneca, for example, the institutions of the European Union must stick to the truth and the facts. Only then will we gain confidence and credibility. I am pleased that we agree in this debate that the restriction of and interference with freedom of expression can only be done in line with the law and that we must not leave this to private individuals in Europe and in the world.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Madam President, one minute, for one point. Our societies are too dependent on a few big social media platforms, most notably Facebook, Twitter, YouTube. They determine what we see and when, not based on journalistic standards, but on popularity, anything that keeps our attention. In traditional media we have nurtured editorial independence and diversity, leading to a variety of newspapers and broadcast companies. Indeed, this is essential for an informed, balanced, free public debate, and social media should be no exception. So we need to strengthen the digital service sector in the Digital Markets Act, break with the deliberate business model of personalised ads, through which Facebook and Google cornered the market much to the detriment of ordinary publishers and assure access entry.  We don’t need less Facebook, we need more Facebooks, we need a variety of Facebooks, we need diversity.

name: Moritz KÖRNER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. We were all terrified by the pictures from the Capitol. But we all remember this young senator who became the first black president on social media. Both Trump and Obama have been elected using social media. It's not social media that's good or bad. It's what we do with it, what rules we give them. Instead of restricting freedom of expression through upload filters, we should get more transparency about algorithms and give users more opportunities. Instead of giving private companies the choice of what is illegal, the courts must continue to decide and we need better cooperation with authorities.  We will continue to see people writing nonsense on the Internet. But we should better protect our democracies against external disinformation campaigns.  More freedom of expression is the way we have to deal with it – with wise rules – not by restricting them. This must be the European way forward.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the President-in-Being Yes, I always feel like George Orwell when it comes to freedom of expression and the new media in the EU. You say 'disinformation', but you actually mean politically unwelcome opinions. You say 'media pluralism', but you mean pro-government media. And when you talk about 'civil society', you are talking only about politically opportune groups. And citizens' commitment is only desirable as long as it does not deviate from the prescribed course. And especially now, when the EU's failure is obvious to all citizens, you are, of course, keen to combat so-called disinformation. Otherwise, citizens could ask themselves unwelcome questions, for example, why trillions of euros are being redistributed, but there is no money at all for effective vaccines. Or why, in the midst of the economic crisis, the EU wants to destroy its own industry through the Green Deal. Or why the EU wants to open the floodgates to migrants. Of course, the lid has to be kept on it. That is why we have this action plan! Your policy not only endangers the health of citizens, your policy not only endangers citizens' jobs, your policy, above all, jeopardises the freedom of citizens!

name: Sergey LAGODINSKY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What we have been experiencing for years is a change in our public discourse space. These changes are manifold - we've heard it.  There are the opportunities and there are the risks. We are in the midst of a conflict over the order of the digital age. This is a conflict between freedom that empowers and freedom that insults, incapacitates and humiliates. We are looking for solutions. But the worst solution that can be given is if we leave it to private providers to make decisions about it. We may rejoice that hatred and hatred of Trump have now fallen silent. But I cannot be pleased that this decision was made by a private company. Freedom of expression today - tomorrow, freedom of expression.  That is why we must take at least three decisions. Firstly, online monopolies must be dismantled. Secondly, decisions to resolve this conflict between freedom and freedom must remain democratically legitimised. And: automation of such events must not be allowed. Neither AI nor big money can decide our fundamental rights.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Madam President, it now alarms how similarities between liberal democracies and totalitarian states are increasing. Restrictions on rights and freedoms with the pandemic are added to attacks on freedom of expression in networks. The supposed moderation and verification is already shamelessly censored. Victim of everything is the one that dissents from the social democratic consensus of the establishment. It's happened to President Trump and it's happened to my party, whose Twitter account has been ignominiously closed a day before the Catalan election campaign began. Internet service providers must choose: either they are neutral and not responsible for the content, or they are politically lined media and are criminally accountable for what they publish, as any means. It is unacceptable for Europeans to receive without lying propaganda from Maduro's criminal, from the Iranian dictatorship, but to close accounts to Vox, his followers or journalists for ideological reasons. These attacks on freedom and democracy by foreign private companies cannot be tolerated. And jurisdiction has to be had by nations to defend their fundamental freedoms.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Madam President, it has become fashionable to say that social media must be controlled. However, one wonders who will surveil the surveiller. Censorship in social media is a slippery slope and, except in very exceptional cases, it is not justified. But let me be clear: opinion must be free, but fascism is not an opinion. It is a crime. But who can assure us that the rules created today will not be used against minorities tomorrow? Social media has been an area for debate and free speech that a lot of the time has called into question the official narratives that big economic and political powers have tried to impose on us. That is real progress for all of our citizens, who can express themselves without constraints. With social media the flow of ideas runs freer than ever. Free speech is a human right and we must defend it as such.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Madam President, social or social networks have become a platform where not only private but also public rumour takes place. The recent decision by a private online platform to remove the profile of a democratically elected president is a dangerous precedent. No one, not even the private owners of online platforms, should deprive anyone of their right to express themselves. This can only happen in exceptional circumstances on the basis of a democratically passed law. From a formal point of view, Twitter can be private property, but it is a deeply social entity in its capacity. Therefore, freedom of expression in a democratic society based on the rule of law has an essential and unmistable value. Freedom of political speech is a litmus paper for the state of democracy in society. About 2,400 years ago, Diogene was asked what was the most beautiful thing in life. He replied that freedom of speech. The word has caused him to die and suffer many free-thinkers. Let new ICT technologies not shrink our space of freedom, but on the contrary, let them spread it. If we are already in the EU to regulate this matter, we must, above all, allow equal access to universal means of communication, services, and, above all, the clear responsibility of the private digital giants operating social networks.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are debating democratic control of social media today. What if democracy is gone? If the government's authoritarian propaganda takes over new channels of communication and tactics salami cuts off more areas of freedom?  In Poland, a protest by independent media has been taking place since the morning. The PiS government, under the guiling pandemic, wants to charge them another tax, while also pouring two billion zlotys into state media annually. The authoritarian system is being close. Polish tango with civil society and international institutions continues. Poland, in the eyes of Europe, is becoming an indemocratic state. Just like Hungary. First they came for the judges, then they came for the women, and now they came for independent journalists.  So I, from this place, from the heart of European democracy, say firmly: we must not allow autocrats to nullify the beautiful history of European integration. You just have to act – and as soon as possible. It is necessary to suspend the Polish and Hungarian governments in the European Council, to take away this vote from them. There is nothing to wait for anymore.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – Madam President, increasing responsibility and transparency on social media platforms must be at the core of our strategy for protecting fundamental rights and democracy in the digital sphere. Self-regulation has proved not enough, obviously. However, over-regulating is also not a solution. Just as rules apply for the democratic debate offline, they need to be adapted for the digital age. The balance lies in refraining from censorship and in establishing clear and predictable lines so that we do not suppress democracy in our attempt to protect it.  Transparency is fundamental. As users, we need to be aware of who pays for what, why we see a certain content, whether that content was altered, who and what is behind what we see online. We need to follow the money, especially when it comes to political advertising. Last but not least, education is fundamental. We must not and cannot build ministries of truth, but we can educate people so that they understand that such ministries actually do not exist.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, social media platforms such as Facebook and Twitter have taken on the exorbitant power to regulate freedom of expression on the Internet. They take the opportunity to impose the law of conformity by ruthlessly censoring all ideas that offend, shock or worry, in violation of the Handyside decision of the European Court of Human Rights which expressly protects them. Their dominance has become such that they have even cut the accounts of the American president, yet reputed to be the most powerful man in the world. This oppression and censorship has lasted far too long. The European states and the European Union, which is nothing but their delegate, must take back control of the situation. In line with the European Parliament's resolution of 20 October 2020, I call for greater public control over these platforms to guarantee freedom of expression. I also ask that every decision to remove illegal content can only be taken as a last resort by an independent national judiciary and not by a commercial entity.

name: Kim VAN SPARRENTAK
text: – Madam President, whether you are a political activist, drag queen or the President of the United States, if we let private companies like Twitter and Facebook decide if you can speak freely, we are endangering our democratic society.  These same big corporations who have profited for years from the large—scale spread of misinformation are now acting as referees of our public debates. Let me be clear: incentivising platforms to delete even more is not the solution. This only reinforces their current power over our free speech. We have to tackle the root causes.  A small number of very large and powerful platforms are controlling our public debate and amplifying fake news and hate on a large scale, specifically targeting certain people for profit. Let’s be ambitious in tackling this in the DSA and DMA. Who can say what, where and when should not be up to CEOs and shareholders. Not private companies but our democratic laws should determine the boundaries of our freedoms. Not big tech but judges should decide what is illegal or not.  We need to take the power over our freedom of expression out of the hands of private companies and place it firmly back in the hands of the people and our democratic institutions.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, please show some mercy. Please save us some hypocrisy. Please spare us some crocodile tears on the freedom of speech. To most Europeans with a little common sense, one thing is crystal clear: this House does not care about free speech.  We did not see a reaction from the European Parliament when tech giants removed President Trump from their networks in January. We did not see a reaction when Parler was removed from all major app stores. We did not see a reaction when Vox activists were brutally attacked in Barcelona last weekend.  Yes, there is pure censorship now in Europe: in Spain, against the only right-wing, traditional, national, conservative political party – Vox. This is provided by Twitter, for example. We didn’t see a reaction when this House promoted fake news about so-called ‘LGBTI—free zones’ in Poland. On the contrary, this European Parliament promoted such false information. The fact of the matter is that this House does not permit opposing views which attack the liberal consensus. The new politburo will not tolerate diverging opinions which don’t accept the agenda of the day. The liberal establishment does not accept views against illegal migration, against NGOs helping human trafficking in the Mediterranean Sea, against the LGBTI ideology and propaganda, or against federalism. The USSR had a one-party system. This European Parliament has a multi-party system, where political parties don’t really matter. Nothing. The majority of this House takes the same stance on the issues I mentioned. But do not worry, please. Freedom will always find a way, and liberty will always win. You cannot shut us down and we will not be silenced.

name: Ioannis LAGOS
text: Madam President, I am an elected MEP like all of you here. We have each received thousands of votes in our country to represent what we believe in and what the world has sent us here. How democratic, then, is it that a person we do not even know — an employee of a private company — can deprive us of the right to speak? That it can deprive us of what we have voted for and for which we are here — that is, the representation of our ideas? How democratic is it that I personally — and there is evidence of what I am telling you — have been punished so many times by Facebook, YouTube, Twitter and anywhere else for speeches I have made in the European Parliament, in which I express what I have voted for? How democratic is it and why is democracy afraid of the opposite view when I have come here to declare that I am a proud Greek, a Christian, fighting for the rights of all who voted for me? Where is democracy in all this? If democracy has begun and is so afraid of the opposite view, then I am afraid it is not a democracy but it is very close to tyranny.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Madam President, online media platforms have become some of the most powerful private social actors in history. The situation is unprecedented. In the past, their lack of action has repeatedly led to real world violence and recently they’ve suddenly silenced a democratically—elected president.  The bottom line is that the freedom of speech of democratically—elected representatives, just like the uncontrolled spread of manipulative disinformation, cannot be just a private matter for global companies. Decisions on these issues need democratic scrutiny and regulatory oversight. It is therefore one of the key regulatory challenges of our era to draft a new set of public rules to respond to the power and potential dangers of social media.  We need more ambition than is currently envisaged in the recently proposed Digital Services Act, especially when it comes to the responsibility and transparency of online platforms in the fight against hoaxes. The DSA is a much—needed step in the right direction, but we must do more to slow down the pervasive spread of manipulative and harmful content online.  We will never be able to put an end to all deceiving lies, but we are surely able to give truth, facts, credible science and democracy a fighting chance in a digital space. I am convinced that Europe and this House must lead these efforts on behalf of all European citizens, who deserve equal protection online across all Member States.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what has happened in the United States in recent months shows once again how totalizing the power of social media has become, so much so that it is possible to obscure the President. A power that calls into question the founding values of our societies: democracy, pluralism, freedom of expression and privacy.  All this is the result of years of practices that have favored user manipulation for profit reasons, highlighting content based on visualizations, and reinforcing everyone's biases thanks to extreme proliferation through data. The right to see your expression expanded through payment to have more visibility of your content is a false right. And we've seen scandals like Cambridge Analytica's. Then it can no longer be postponed. While respecting net neutrality and freedom of expression, we must take away absolute power from social networks. We need to put a stop to harmful practices and we therefore need a new constitution in the digital field, which finds in the proposals of the regulation on services and digital markets a fundamental piece on which to build.

name: Nicola BEER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Freedom of expression is the basis of our democracy. The exercise of freedom of expression is essential for political decision-making and fair and free elections. We live in a media world where political decision-making takes place digitally. As long as in this digital world, the expression of opinions based on freedoms is guaranteed, we should not interfere further as a policy. But the reality, it is now different: freedom of expression on social media platforms is under fire. Some oligopolies of social media platforms themselves set the rules in their terms and conditions on how will formation is organized. I'm not just thinking about the Trump account; I am thinking of the many accounts that have been blocked accordingly, of users who are made almost impossible to understand locks, blockages, greylisting, shadow banning in any way and to defend themselves against these practices. We in the European Parliament must set the rules for the forthcoming Digital Markets Act and the Digital Services Act on how freedom of expression on social media platforms is adequately guaranteed for our citizens, because it is a question of restricting civil liberties. And the decision as to which freedoms are restricted, that decision belongs in Parliament!

name: Susanna CECCARDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, citizens around the world have in recent years voiced their thoughts and reflections through social media, fantastic vehicles of freedom, often censored and rendered inaccessible by the world's liberticidal dictatorships. But, in recent times, there has been a very worrying trend on the part of these communication multinationals. Millions of citizens are censored every day by officials who decide behind a desk what is right or not to think. Is it right that de facto monopoly companies should hold this enormous power? What is a free man but his word and his thought? Who has the right to judge what is right or wrong? The judges inside the courts or the gentlemen of Facebook and Twitter who invented successful applications? The most worrying thing is that digital oligopolies are appropriating a real civil service, that is, to decide what is tolerable or not in the debate. In the rule of law it is the law that decides what is right or wrong, what is punishable or liable to censorship. These multinationals not only consider themselves to be above the law, but also above European and national taxation. Small entrepreneurs and VAT numbers are currently being burdened by the crisis and the tax authorities, and perhaps even censored for their ideas on social media. Free citizens who want to have the opportunity to express themselves demand that they be able to exercise this inviolable right freely, including on the Internet. Transparency and freedom are two values that are first and mostly European: let us prove it, including through proper digital democracy.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her "I thought I was going to die". In these words, U.S. Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez describes her fears during the terrorist attack on the U.S. Capitol. It would now be too easy to say that social media platforms bear sole responsibility for dividing our societies. But the truth is that business models of big-tech companies like Facebook are creating a breeding ground for hatred and violence. We have lost control of big tech, and it is high time to get it back. In a democracy, parliaments must determine the rules, not large digital corporations. Google has a market share of over 90% in the EU. Our democracy and our economic system are broken when a few corporations dominate our communications and markets. Consumer rights are being weakened and small businesses are dying.  We must democratise big tech's business models and not shy away from the break-up of large corporations. Let us start with this now.

name: Dace MELBĀRDE
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent Colleagues! I believe that at European Union level, a mechanism must be created that prevents neither global platforms, authoritarian countries nor third-country influence agents from manipulating the content of our messages and, therefore, with political decisions and public actions, but still restrictions here are not enough. Firstly, it is necessary to lay down favourable conditions for the development of reliable media in the digital environment so that users have access to quality media content in the first place, and here the European Union must invest more in independent media and their digitisation. Secondly, platforms must impose strict and legally regulated obligations to address abusive and targeted organised behaviour. "Kremlin trolls" must have no place in a democratic information space. And thirdly, global platforms must guarantee equal security for users in the languages of all the Member States of the European Union, not just representatives of large languages. It is precisely smaller information rooms, such as the Baltic States, that the Kremlin has defined as its own area of special interest.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Madam President, balance is what must characterize a democratic society. Finding the balance between maintaining freedom and combating excesses is the challenge in social media. Social media has been a tremendous asset to civil society - and therefore to democracy. They have made it possible to disclose the truth, they have allowed gatherings of committed citizens, they allow everyone to freely express their thoughts and to have an auditor if necessary.  Unfortunately, the dangers of social media (not to mention criminal activity) are just as great, and the damage to democracy is catastrophic. Indeed, social media is also a forum for hatred of all kinds, for total misinformation and for conspiracy theories, and all this most often with complete impunity. The need to legislate is necessary. However, our governments are too slow. One can criticize the closure of Donald Trump's Twitter account by the platform, but was the solution to leave it open?  The dangers of democracy must be taken into account. Too often, under the guise of 'democracy', democracy is weak. I believe it is the duty of democracy to defend itself. My freedom ends where the freedom of the other begins. Freedoms in democracy stop where democracy is in danger.  The vacuum left by democratically elected political power is unacceptable. Responsibility cannot be left to the platforms. It's up to us to set the limits, to legislate, and fast!

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a formatted, open internet has ended up in the hands of a few companies. Algorithms that run social media can influence election results and escalate violent confrontations. Fake news can destabilize societies. Until the next Case Capitol happens, we don't want to have to wonder whose responsibility it is to delete fake news or close an account. The answer can't be, no one's responsibility. It is the responsibility of democratically elected decision-makers that legislation, including on platforms, is up-to-date. The EU must protect the fundamental rights of its citizens, security to use social media too. Transparency and the possibility of auditing shall be required. We cannot trust or intervene if we do not know how the algorithms are designed. As data move globally, we need to seek cooperation with countries that share our values within the UN and the OECD, and the EU and the US can work together. We must act boldly and quickly, because democracy and the rule of law can also be lost.

name: Anna Júlia DONÁTH
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. I am pleased that the European Union has also recognised the need to regulate large tech companies. The problem is that it also occurred to autocratic leaders who do not want to do the same for the interests of the people, but only for consolidating their own power. After the Polish, the Hungarian government also announced that it wanted to take control of Facebook. Would we really allow a Fidesz authority appointed by Viktor Orban to tell us what Hungarians can post about and what they can post on Facebook? Would we really let that happen, knowing Viktor Orban and his attitude to the free public?  Because let us have no doubt that the hungarian government's sole purpose is to subjug the last slice of the Hungarian public, social media. My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. That is why European regulation is needed to prevent this and to speak out in the interests of everyday people rather than those in power, as opposed to technology giant platforms. It is time to pass a fair Facebook law and a time to prevent new censorship laws in Europe.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Facebook blocked the English-language account of the Polish Institute of National Remembrance, because it posted historical material on its profile regarding the Germanization of Polish children during World War II. A second example from recent days: Facebook blocked an ad for a post by Lublin Children's Hospice simply because it dared to promote palliative care for terminally ill children.  These are examples of unfounded and unlawful blocking of profiles and content posted on social media in Poland. Is this what the understanding of freedom of expression and freedom of expression by foreign corporate giants operating in the European digital market is supposed to look like? These actions undermine the foundations of democracy, which in this House is always carried on the banners. Were the examples I mentioned to some extent unlawful or prohibited? Absolutely not. We do not condone this type of behaviour. We will defend firmly the fundamental right to freedom of expression. The European institutions must be strong against the strong and effectively protect their citizens where they cannot defend themselves.

name: Arba KOKALARI
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Following the heinous storming of the US Congress, the spotlight has now been drawn on the role of social media in our society. I think we can all agree. Social media has become a central channel of our democratic conversation and freedom of expression online.  The lack of clear rules of the game and laws means that platforms today remove content on arbitrary grounds. Many people are wondering now: Why does Facebook delete my posts and account without explanation, and I have no one to call? Why do platforms allow threats, child and illegal products to flow freely online? As my group negotiator for the new Internet Act Digital Services Act, I will work to bring order to this digital wild west that prevails today. Then it needs to become clear that what is illegal offline must also be illegal online, and that it should then be removed from social media.  We need to ensure fair competition that promotes innovation and entrepreneurship, and promote the right to express our opinion online as well. It must be guaranteed. Because, if we are to be completely honest, increased censorship of legal content does not benefit democracy, but rather increases what we are trying to counter here: conspiracy theories and increased polarisation.

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: – President of Sinjura, il-media llum saret indispensabbli. Kumpaniji bħal Facebook, illum, saru utilitajiet li ma ngħaddux mingajħrhom fid-dinja moderna. Utilitajiet li permezz tagħhom i大-ħittadini tagħna qegħdin jiksbu l-informazzjoni, qegħdin jaħdmu u kif ukoll qegħdin jagħmlu x-xirjiet tagħhom. Però waħda mill-aspetti wkoll illi ħarġet b'mod ħar waqt il-pandemija kien ir-rwol illi l-media so大jali tilgħab fil-ħajja tagħna. Però fl-istess ħin il-media so大jali qiegħda tpoġġi quddiemna wkoll perikliġodda. Dan hekk kif illum qed tilgħab ir-rwol kru大jali fil-mod kif l-informazzjoni qiegħda tasal għand iħand iħ-ħittadini tagħna u għaldaqstant qiegħda taffettwa l-imġiba, id-de-dediżjonijiet u l-azzjonijiet illi kull wieħed u waħda minnha jieħu madwar id-dinja. Il-pressjoni politika kull i jmur qiegħda tiżdied. In-nies qegħdin jistaqsu dwar ir-rwol, il-poteri estremi u l-control ta大-大ensura illi dawn il-kumpaniji għandhom. Huwa inkwetanti illi quddiem għajnejna qegħdin naraw ta' kuljum prattiħi diżonesti, intrużjonijiet fil-ħajja privata tagħna u abbuż fl-użu tad-staff tagħna, illi qegħdin jintużaw għall-benefi大大juju he' ftit kumpaniji. Qegħdin jinħolqu perikli għas-soħjetà meta dawn qegħdin jaġixxu b'mod irresponsabbli, kemm etiku kif ukoll so大jali. Huwa allarmanti li dawn qegħdin jidde大iedu fuq kull aspett tal-ħajja tagħna. Huwa ina大大ettabbli li dawn qegħdin jispi大大aw jiddettaw huma stess il-qafas regolatorju illi fih huma jridu jaħdmu. Il-qafas legali preżenti mhuwiex adegwat. Mhuwiex adegwat sabiex nirrispondu għall-isfidi li dawn il-kumpaniji qegħdin joħolqu ta' kuljum. L-iskrutinju democrat tal-media so大jali u l-protezzjoni tad-drittijiet fundamentali tagħna huwa neesesikesità importanti. Għalhekk għandna bżonn qafas regolatorju ġust u trasparenti sabiex insaħħu d-demokrazija u s-saltna tad-dritt, nissalvagwardjaw l-interessi pubbliħi u nipproteġu d-drittijiet u l-libertajiet fundamentali tagħna. Id-DSA u d-DMA huma opportunitajiet tad-deheb sabiex nagħmlu dan.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Madam President, social media offers enormous opportunities, and at the same time it poses great challenges for our democracies.  For a long time, platforms have hidden behind the phrase "We are not publishers, we do not filter content, we are open spaces for the public". Recent decisions to ban leaders Khamenei and Trump have dismantled that alibi. They also demonstrated the dangers that platforms could pose if they are not regulated. The Internet offers open forums for freedom of expression, but these forums must be safe. Unfortunately, platforms are often used to promote violence: physical, verbal, political. Net neutrality does not mean that we must remain neutral in the face of illegality, violence and foreign interference in our democracies. It is the democratic authorities who must decide the rules of our civil dialogue and this is a challenge for which Europe must live up to it.

name: Stelios KYMPOUROPOULOS
text: – Madam President, social media have transformed our lives and revolutionised the way we conduct politics. But they have also created challenges related to disinformation, the integrity of our elections and several fundamental rights, to name just a few. As proven over the last year, platforms – and in particular the so-called ‘gatekeepers’ – can do much more to facilitate a healthy democratic debate through content moderation. Proactive measures such as labelling misleading or unfounded posts online proved to be very helpful.  But at the same time we should be mindful of striking a balance between safeguarding the civic debate and protecting fundamental rights such as the freedom of expression. We need to preserve the prohibition of imposing a general monitoring obligation and reconsider the liability exemptions for active platforms while providing for safeguards such as adequate oversight and judicial redress mechanisms.  Finally, transparency over algorithmic decision-making will be key. As a society, we need to have a better understanding of the functioning of social media algorithms. In this regard, platforms should provide researchers with further access to data, in order to examine potential systemic risks and the socio-economic harm they may cause.

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: Madam President! Social media is, after all, basically a boon for our democracies, but unfortunately it is also clear today that they have become a huge challenge. Every day we see examples of illegal goods being sold to children on these social platforms without intervening, and Europeans being attacked by disinformation, a deliberate attempt to distort democratic debate. It creates a devastating polarisation that degrades our democracy and creates unnecessary enemy imagery. Last time we saw it, when the storm at Capital scared us all, but at the same time we also saw more platforms exclude the then US President. So is that the solution? No, of course it isn't. We must be extremely careful not to attack the right to freedom of expression, the right to freedom of the press, the right to refer to ourselves and others on these social platforms. It is a matter for us liberals to have freedom of expression, and that is why we have a special obligation as liberals to strike this balance between freedom of expression and putting it in order online. We must, of course, live up to that particular obligation.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has done so. In the end, we are talking here about nothing less than our civilisation and what holds our civilisation together.  We have seen a culture of human dignity and freedoms grow from Europe and in Europe. We have seen the Enlightenment. The Enlightenment has led to the understanding that these values apply to everyone and also lead to freedom of expression and freedom of speech. However, we must not overlook the fact that we have also seen in history that these great ideals can be trampled underfoot, and even eradicated. This has not happened anywhere like in Europe. That is why we must be very, very careful – careful – with these issues. Social media platforms have brought a lot of good, but also many dangers. They have made it easier to divide our societies. Attempts at division from the outside, we are dealing with in the special disinformation committee in order to fight against disinformation. That is what we are working on in the European Parliament, and there are also attempts at division from within. What happened on Capitol Hill in the United States in Washington DC is just a tip of the iceberg of what is possible. What we must ensure, because parliamentarianism is also one of the values of our civilisation, is that it is parliaments that can set rules with laws and not allow private companies to censor.

name: Vlad-Marius BOTOŞ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Secretary of State, fellow members, social media has brought a global addition. Interpersonal communication is easier, distances disappear, and globalisation has reached the human level, individually.  Without denying all the positive aspects for society and for individuals, we must recognise that the lack of regulation has sometimes created a danger from these platforms for democracy and even for the development of society. We can no longer accept that the rules of communication are set only by companies, we can no longer accept that ethical rules are set at the platform level, and we certainly can no longer accept the algorithms under which certain posts and information are recommended to the detriment of others.  We understand that it is a new market, that it is a new economy, but rules and algorithms must be approved differently: according to ethical criteria, legislation; otherwise we risk these social media platforms also being a danger to our democracy, as we know it, and an extremely valuable tool in the hands of those who want to destabilize it.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: - Dear Chairman, citizens' exposure to disinformation including misleading or false information is a major challenge for Europe. Tackling disinformation in the age of social media and online platforms must be a coordinated effort involving all relevant actors from institutions to social platforms, from news media to individual users. The figures in the European Commission's latest reports on the removed content of digital platforms say the following: as of January 2020, Google has removed or blocked more than 90 million coronavirus-related ads in the EU for violating advertising policies, including disinformation about medicines. In Croatia, 12,390 Google ads were blocked, 10 million in Germany, 9 million in Austria. During November, Facebook and Instagram platforms in the EU: 35,000 posts removed due to disinformation that can lead to imminent physical harm, content relating to fraudulent preventive measures or medicines.  There is a fine line between the freedom of speech that we stand for and that we support and the dissemination of harmful content that can have far-reaching implications for our health, security, stability of our societies, but also on disrupting democratic processes. We have made a big step forward by adopting a package on digital services. Social interaction has also digitised the policy space, but it also strengthens those so-called ordinary users to be media and that's where we need to find a balance. Media literacy, consider strengthening it, and the question is the anonymity of the profile. It is clear that what is punishable in the real world must also be sanctioned in the digital world.

name: Svenja HAHN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Authoritarian governments block or censor social media.  Platforms delete content according to unclear house rules or demands from governments. Whether through politics or business parks, locks require algorithms and artificial intelligence to detect content. When we talk about democratic regulation of social media, we also have to talk about what tools do we allow and who can hold them in their hands? The decision on what is legal or illegal must not be deported to companies. Upload filters and excessive deletion incentives jeopardize free speech through overblocking. Artificial intelligence must give people opportunities instead of taking liberties. For this, a legal framework must look at the application, not at the technology itself. The planned regulation of artificial intelligence must protect our fundamental rights. Restriction of freedom through technological progress would be the greatest step backwards for our society and a dangerous weapon in the hands of authoritarian regimes.

name: Javier ZARZALEJOS
text: – Madam President, Madam Secretary of State, Commissioner, welcome this debate because yes, we are very concerned and concerned that undue censorship of platforms can be exercised and we are concerned about the impact of its power on the exercise of freedom of expression, which we well know is the basis of democracy and is the basis of a political system of freedoms. Like it or not, platforms are recognizing their responsibility for content, even when they are wrong and when they are exceeded, and this is a good starting point for regulation, including repair routes. We need to provide platforms with legal tools so that they can carry out what we ask them to do: collaboration and compliance with obligations to detect, notify and eliminate illegal content, from terrorism and sexual abuse of minors to misinformation and hate speech. But freedom of expression has to be respected and defended as a whole, and I think it is appropriate to remember it so that the claim of freedom of expression is not hijacked by the extremisms that are also present in this House, because these extremisms, while demanding respect for them, harass uncomfortable journalists, point them out, impede their access to press conferences , organize discredit campaigns against the media or directly promote boycotts to damage their dissemination. These true violations of freedom of expression can be named; what is clear is that this double measuring stick does not serve a debate like this.

name: Klemen GROŠELJ
text: – Madam President, social networks are an opportunity in a democracy, but also a risk.  An opportunity for active citizens to express views and to act within a democratic public space, the risk of abuse, the spread of fake news, disinformation, conspiracy theories, hate speech and extreme political views that, as we have seen in the US, can lead to attempts to violently demolish democratic regulation.  Or rather, as the examples show in some Member States, such as Poland, Hungary, unfortunately Slovenia, the weakening of democracy, its institutions and the establishment of non-liberal democracies.  It is therefore obvious that social networks also need a certain level of regulation. This does not mean imposing censorship and a universal restriction on freedom of speech, even that deciding what is appropriate and what is not appropriate is left to an individual's subjective discretion. Let alone be decided by the interests of network owners.  We need clearly defined regulation, designed in the context of established democratic processes, so as not to interfere with the essences of networks that strengthen democracy and its development, but at the same time prevent their misuse for the purposes of political manipulation and weakening of democracy.

name: Peter POLLÁK
text: – Madam President, the spread of hoaxes during the corona crisis has had real consequences for the health and lives of people across Europe. Many have posted lies on social media that Covid-19 is a common flu. Unfortunately, many of them have also died. The corona crisis has shown how weak we are in the fight against lies and disinformation, as well as in the fight against hatred, extremism, aggression, sedation and attack. A few weeks ago, we witnessed an American ex-president mobilise fanatics precisely through social media. It's a good thing they ended up blocking his account. Although many of us agree with this, we cannot leave such decisions in the hands of media owners whose main objective is to make money. Let's face it, social media content has completely spiralled out of control. Although this is not being listened to well, I believe that the lies and hoaxes about Covid-19 have caused the deaths of many people in Europe. I am by no means in favour of regulating the freedom of social media. However, we must prevent the spread of lies, hatred, extremism and disinformation.

name: Bart GROOTHUIS
text: – Madam President, whether you think it’s good or bad that Donald Trump has been banned from social media is not the right political question. The right question is whether the ban of Donald Trump should have been decided by Silicon Valley, or by transparent democratic policies.  We govern ourselves here. We govern our own political sphere, and that means that liberal democracy should set standards for social media companies. Companies should make policies out of those standards, and they should be upheld, not by us, not by companies, and certainly not by governments, but by independent oversight. They should ensure that what is illegal offline is also illegal online. But we have clear evidence that our democratic security is also at stake.  The issues of voting integrity, health crises or national security emergencies can be intentionally undermined both by foreign and domestic actors, and I would like to remind the House that such malicious intent is also illegal offline, and should be online.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, social media platforms such as Twitter, Facebook, Instagram have provided a huge number of new opportunities for interaction and interaction between people.  What are the rules that have been followed on these platforms? They have been based on the commercial interests of these platforms. Now their economic and social power throughout the world has grown so great that this can no longer continue. It is important for us in Europe to ensure that the legislation that we already have in society applies in the same way on social media and on the Internet. It is important that European values, democracy, freedom of expression and human rights are also realised online, as in this real world. It is also important to put these more precisely into legislation, and this work is currently being carried out. At the same time, it is important to remember that when we want to combat disinformation, propaganda, fake news on the platforms, the most important way is still for us to invest in people's skills. Good literacy, good digital skills, quality and free media are the best ways and the most effective ways to combat fake news, propaganda and disinformation. In other than when we clearly set rules on the Internet that what is illegal in societies in Europe is also illegal on the Internet, we must also support people's skills and digital skills.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Secretary of State, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate is extremely useful because it brings to our attention an extremely sensitive issue for our democratic societies. Clearly, technology has provided us with extraordinary communication tools through which our lives have fundamentally changed.  Social networks today influence the political life, financial markets and, as clearly as possible, the daily lives of all our citizens. The question is how far this freedom that these extremely useful instruments are going, because self-regulation has not been shown to have failed, and I am extremely sorry that we are not able to find tools to meet the challenges to which we and the European Union are subject.  We have seen, in the midst of the pandemic, entire campaigns of misinformation to which our citizens have been subjected by states that have stood behind such instruments. The Commission has tried to react, but it has not been enough and I believe that freedom of expression must be defended, but at the same time we must take care of our citizens, because we have seen many voices in Parliament saying that it is glad that Donald Trump has had his account closed. I wonder why we weren't happy when Putin announced on Twitter that he had annexed Crimea.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to thank the honourable Members for this debate and for all your opinions and views. For me it is extremely important to hear the opinions of this House because this is the first broad debate about if, and how, to regulate the Internet if I may simplify that. And I take several main messages.  First, what I heard from the vast majority of you is: it’s time to get to work. If we are not ambitious to become the rule-makers we will continue to be the rule-takers, the rules which have been created in Silicon Valley and which are imposed on our territory in the EU. So it’s time to get to work with a sense of urgency and I very much count on the European Parliament and your approach to adopt the legislation which the Commission proposed soon enough. Also because we see a lot of impatience on the side of some Member States who want to go their own way. They want to have their own rules for the Internet and I think that it was quite clear also from this debate that we want to have a pan-European smart solution without any fragmentation by Member States.  The second main message which I got is that we are searching and working on the ideologically-neutral solution that the rules we are going to adopt should not be left or right, and that we will seek the solution which will protect the freedom of speech as the primary principle. So these are the main messages I took from this very important debate.  Coming back to the rule-makers, what we are doing is the continuation of the effort of the EU to be the rule-maker with global effect. We already managed to do that with the GDPR where we said that individual people must have the right to have their identity, their privacy, under control. And now we are coming with a set of, I hope, consistent rules which are also consistent with the GDPR and its philosophy. We are coming with the Digital Services Act, the Digital Markets Act, the European Democracy Action Plan, and by all that we want to prove that the EU has a very healthy instinct when it comes to the risks which we see on the Internet and which can cause big harm to our societies.  What I heard from many of you was that the digital big tech grabbed too much power and too little responsibility. I would add I agree with that. The platforms captured a lot of public space. I sometimes say that they privatised the public space, and this is a public space without any public scrutiny whatsoever. So this is also our task: to demand more transparency and more accountability, because what’s happening online is heavily influencing real life.  I think it was Mr Tudorache who said that there is no difference between online and offline, that it’s one world. I tend to agree with that. On the other hand, it’s quite easy to blame the Internet and platforms for all our troubles. I think that we should really take a lesson from what happened in the US at the beginning of January. The platforms for the transmitters of the messages of the former President Trump who was inciting violence, whipping up the crowd who then invaded the Capitol, and there were victims, there were dead people. So I think this is also a very strong goal on all of us who have influence on public opinion and on the reaction of our society to be more responsible and to be aware that social media can be a weapon, a dangerous weapon in our hands.  I am not calling for self-censoring for politicians. I am calling for more responsibility and awareness of the consequences when we use these social platforms and social media. I would like to recommend that you read Madeleine Albright’s book Fascism: A Warning. She speaks about social media as a weapon when it is used by bad people, when it appears in bad hands.  Let me react to several comments regarding disinformation in the time of COVID. I’m sure you know that the Commission has an agreement with big tech to do more against disinformation. So it’s not true that they have just started now, and I appreciate the recent announcement of Facebook that they want to do more against disinformation relating to vaccination. The agreement is simple. I wanted them to enable more space for information from authorities, from health authorities, from those who are responsible for communication and for providing the people with trustworthy and evidence-based information. For the health sector I think that is a very clear message: if you do not occupy the space it will be occupied by disinformation. The Ministers of Health are aware of that and they do their best. I have to praise them for everything they are doing in this very difficult moment and crisis, and they are doing their best to occupy the space with reliable information. The thing is that the people have to trust the information provided by the health authorities.  The fight against disinformation also contains what we offer or what we propose. It contains fact-checking. Honourable Members, let me do this now. I have to react to Mr Haider who said that the EU has not invested anything into the development and production of vaccination. This is fake news, and I think that if something like that is said, it’s also our obligation to come with the facts and deny that. I also want to react because we speak here about the freedom of speech. I want to react to those who were mentioning the situation in Poland. I think we all have seen the black screens. The black screens are quite telling. I think they are screaming. Today it’s a question of protest of the media in Poland, expressed in a black screen. Tomorrow black screens might become a sad everyday reality. We also need to protect the freedom of speech by supporting independent media, not by suppressing them with additional financial burdens.  This doesn’t apply only to Poland. We have recommended many times to the Member States that they should support also financially media who are also the frontrunners in the COVID crisis, media which were already before the COVID crisis under big financial distress because the business model has changed brutally. The money from advertisers is being shifted to the online sphere which we keep speaking about today, and so we need to guarantee that the media can do their job because they have a very important role in our democratic societies.  So coming back to the law which we are now analysing. I have to say that we always advise the Member States to support media, as I said, but coming to the law, we are aware of the draft law and we need to look into it in more detail. We expect Member States to ensure that their fiscal or other policies will not affect the commitment to ensuring a free independent and diverse media ecosystem. I have to add that about the legislative process, which is ongoing in Poland, that it is important to consult such legislation also with the media sector, and I understand from the recent information from Poland that this is foreseen.  I am sorry, I probably was longer than I wanted to be, but I really wanted to react to many of your very important opinions, which I had to take.

name: Nicola BEER
text: It’s an important topic so we are very happy that you really discussed it with us.

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Parliament for this valuable contribution to this debate and also to thank the Commissioner for her answers and, at the same time, to ensure that the Council remains committed to continuous work to protect and promote the fundamental rights of our citizens. This issue should be the subject of a constructive and transparent dialogue between the co-legislators and the different stakeholders. We have to talk to the platforms, with civil society, with the experts, for the good of our citizens. The Council firmly believes that digital technologies can make a significant contribution to the protection of fundamental rights and democracy, provided that democratic processes, appropriate controls and balances are safeguarded. How to adapt our legal instruments to the speed and immediacy of the online world? How can we achieve and ensure the right balance between freedom of expression, media pluralism and the protection of citizens' rights against online hatred and disinformation? How to improve the digital education of our citizens? It is for these answers that we need to work with the European Parliament, seeking legality, transparency, diversity and freedom of expression.  The variety of information and the plurality of voices are an integral part of our democratic systems, but let us not forget that safeguarding them also means ensuring protection against violence and hatred, the protection of minors, consumer protection. The digital space needs to be safe for all of us. This is also part of the rules of democracy.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Writing. – Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Instagram – we all know and use online services. These huge platforms reach billions of people worldwide. But, despite their enormous reach, they are still barely regulated. Platforms have long been left with the option of voluntary self-regulation – they should take action against disinformation themselves on the basis of the EU Code of Conduct. But the rise of fake news and harmful content shows that this idea of self-regulation has failed. Only by democratically controlling social media platforms can we get to grips with this problem. We need a strong legal framework that protects freedom of expression and fundamental rights while limiting harmful content. The European Parliament therefore made it clear back in October last year that the decision on what needs to be removed must lie with the democratic institutions. They must create the legal framework in which independent courts make decisions. Laws, not private entrepreneurs, must determine what is permissible and what is not. This creates legal certainty for citizens and for platforms. We in Parliament will now do everything we can to create strong legislation on freedom of expression and against disinformation on the basis of the Commission's proposal.

name: Ernő SCHALLER-BAROSS
text: Writing. – Social media platforms are a hub for the public. For this reason, their interference in the process of forming opinions has particularly serious consequences, while their activities and decision-making on user-published content are not transparent. The European Union has so far partially given way to self-regulation in the functioning of online platforms, but now it is designing the right direction in a new package of digital services legislation and limiting market-leading digital companies. Uniform EU action in this area is of paramount importance and the EU should do so on the basis of Member States.  Increased supervision of platforms should be exercised, but this supervisory authority can only function properly if the European Union also builds on national authorities. It should be taken into account that each Member State of the European Union has different national characteristics and regulatory environments. There are differences between Member States as to what constitutes illegal content under national criminal codes. Member State authorities have essential experience with the functioning of digital platforms at Member State level. Transparency, functioning in accordance with the rule of law and requiring political neutrality are fundamental principles that are a common goal in the digital space, and this objective can only be achieved jointly, through EU action, building on the Member States.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on the package of measures for the recovery of capital markets: MiFID and the EU Reconstruction Prospectus, including the report by Markus Ferber on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU with regard to information obligations; product monitoring and position limits to promote economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic (COM(2020)0280 – C9-0210/2020 – 2020/0152 (COD)) (A9-0208/2020) and – the report by Ond ej Kovaik on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the proposal for a European Parliament regulation on a European Parliament regulation and the Council amending Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 with a view to the EU Reconstruction Prospectus and targeted adjustments for financial intermediaries to support the economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic (COM(2020)0281 – C9-0206/2020 - 2020/0155 (COD)) (A9-0228/2020). I would like to remind you once again that neither spontaneous speeches nor blue cards are allowed in the debates of this part-session. In addition, there are plans for interconnection from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Unfortunately, we have not yet made the progress we would have liked in the fight against coronavirus. This means that we will have to live with the economic upheavals for a while yet. This, in turn, means that many companies will still be in a difficult, very difficult situation for a while to come and will have to make massive use of their capital reserves. As legislators – and this is one of our highest duties here – we must set the course for this to be possible. Public support measures are one side. For capital market-financed companies in particular, however, we must also ensure the best possible financing conditions on the markets. With the targeted changes to MiFID, we are doing just that by making it a little easier for professional market participants to operate in the markets. At the same time, we have made it easier to provide stock analysis for small listed companies, making them more attractive to investors. Finally, we have also drawn some conclusions from the crisis for private investors, so that the investment advice process works even if the client cannot physically sit or stand with his advisor. These are certainly only small adjusting screws, but they are many small adjusting screws, but they can make a big difference in sum and will thus also support the economic recovery. And let me be very clear: anyone who wants to support the economic recovery cannot vote against the Capital Markets Recovery Package, and it cannot vote against the adjustments in MiFID.
