That is why I have always been very clear: I do not understand why our dear colleagues in the Social Democrats have already made it clear that they want to vote against it today. In the negotiations, I have tried to significantly improve the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises. This is now being criticised for not being done. Who was against it? It was the Social Democrats, the Greens, the Communists against. If you had been involved! Don't make press releases, but join in! Then it would have been better. The same applies to the question of advice: we do not give up anything for the private investor at all! But no one can explain to me why a professional investor, a pension fund or a bank needs exactly the same documents as a private investor! The fact that we are reducing costs here helps everyone in the end. What can we have against it? And then – we have just had a nice debate on the subject of fake news – fake news is really being spread. And this is the issue of commodity derivatives. No one in this House wants food to be speculated on. But what we desperately need is that the underdeveloped markets in the electricity sector – derivatives on electricity supplies, price hedging on electricity supplies – can finally develop. Our system does not fit in there, and only at this point do we change, and that is clearly regulated. And that is why I really ask you to read what we have said! But what irritates me most is that I have to read here in a press release from the Socialists and Democrats that this would be a conservative MiFID story. Compare what the Commission has proposed with what the Council and Parliament have now adopted together. It is the Commission proposal on which we have essentially agreed, which we have adapted and changed together with the Commission in a few small places. That is not my private matter! What are you actually writing here? That is why I really ask you to reconsider your position. We made a further interruption in the trialogue negotiations because there were wishes of the Social Democrats. In the end, you agreed. And now you say no. Ladies and gentlemen, this is about taking responsibility – taking responsibility for our ability to make a contribution to the financing of small, targeted, tailor-made adjustments to the capital markets, too. I say it again: you were against it. It is a question of ensuring that we reduce bureaucratic costs. They were against it. It is about developing the underdeveloped power plants in such a way that a green deal can even work, so that a cooperative that operates a wind farm or a solar plant can use capital market hedging with the big corporations at all. They were against it. That is why I am disappointed. I hope that there will nevertheless be a majority in this House in order to be able to make these tailor-made, targeted, really good changes, so that the capital markets can contribute to companies making a contribution to ensuring that the economic recovery can take place as quickly as possible. We, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, are of course in favour of this – everyone else is invited to follow this good successful path.

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the focus of this plenary session has been on boosting the public finances for economic recovery. We adopted the Recovery and Resilience Facility, and rightly so, but at the same time, we must not neglect the mobilisation of private capital.  The pandemic is extremely challenging both for investors and companies. They need financial injections through investments, they need access to finance but, above all, they need simple and straightforward procedures with minimal red tape, without, of course, compromising investors’ protection. The Capital Markets Recovery Package is integral to the economic recovery of the EU following the COVID-19 pandemic. By introducing targeted changes to some capital market rules, it encourages greater investments in the economy and helps ensure quick re-capitalisation of companies. It will also increase the capacity of banks to finance that recovery.  The two pieces of this package we are voting on this week will ensure that Europe is in the best place possible to help our markets, financial institutions and businesses recover from this crisis, and here I would like to join the call of the previous rapporteur and invite all of you to support this package. I am proud of the outcome of our negotiations on the Prospectus Regulation, and here I would like to thank both the Council and the Commission for their cooperation for a very quick and productive negotiation process. The prospectus might be a little bit cryptic thing for non-economists but in short it’s a document providing all necessary information about a company you are about to invest in. Removing temporarily extra costs and administration for companies allows them to access the finance that they need more quickly. And the Recovery Prospectus does just that. The adjustments that we have made will help companies to raise capital through shares instead of going deeper into debt. They will facilitate fundraising by banks, which will have a vital role to play in the recovery of the real economy. Specifically, we have introduced a new, lightweight, Recovery Prospectus. This will be a temporary prospectus that can be used by those companies who have already listed on the markets. The Recovery Prospectus will be available for secondary issuances, to issuers of shares, until the end of 2022, and will be limited to 30 pages in length, compared to the current market average of 400 pages. As you can imagine, this will significantly cut costs by hundreds of thousands of euros for those wishing to raise capital, and this is around half of the current cost of producing a secondary issuance prospectus. While the businesses will have fewer costs and less red tape to deal with, we have ensured that investor protection has remained at the forefront of the negotiations. For example, issuers will have to disclose what their level of capital is compared to their indebtedness, as well as a working capital statement. They will also have to publicly outline what will be done with the money invested in their company.  If investors are to invest in a company in these turbulent times, it is only right that they also know how much the current situation with the pandemic has affected the company they are considering investing in. Therefore, in the Recovery Prospectus, issuers will have to lay out clearly how COVID-19 has affected their businesses.  Overall, I am convinced that we have struck the right balance between a streamlined prospectus and ensuring investor protection, while transparency is maintained at the highest level.  Commissioner, colleagues, businesses in Europe have suffered enormously due to the current situation. Significant uncertainty remains, not least for the service sector. The temporary changes we introduced in the Prospectus Regulation will provide financial security to businesses across Europe. The Capital Markets Recovery Package will give breathing space to the financial sector. This will also allow financial institutions to provide for businesses to keep them afloat. Let’s continue to reflect on the simplification of legislation also for the future in the post-pandemic context. A good balance between regulation, safeguards and the freedom to innovate should guide us in our review of capital markets legislation.  I am sure you will agree that we must do all we can to help businesses, especially SMEs, to weather the storm and come through the pandemic with the ability to grow again. They could then become powerhouses that will support Europe as we embark on the digital and green transitions.  The Recovery Package as a whole is only a short-term solution. During the next few years, we must work to ensure a resilient and future-proof framework for our financial markets. In Europe, there is a lot of potential for the Capital Markets Union. We only need willingness to break down the barriers that have hindered cross-border access to finance until now.  I firmly believe that bold and ambitious reforms to our financial framework will allow us to compete on every level with other jurisdictions around the globe.

name: Nicola BEER
text: We are really happy to have Commissioner McGuinness once more in our House. You have the floor.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for the very warm welcome, and I am glad to be back in this House debating a really important topic about our companies and our recovery. I want to begin by thanking our rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs for their efforts, and to look first at the prospective regulation. It’s been said already by the previous two speakers that the COVID-19 pandemic has hit EU firms harder, and over a longer time period, than we had initially anticipated, especially small and medium—sized companies. Many of our companies find themselves in a very difficult situation and really do need new investment to keep afloat. The proposed EU Recovery Prospectus is one way to enable EU companies to raise new equity capital on public markets quickly and without excessive bureaucracy. This short prospectus will be easy to produce for companies, easy to understand for investors and easy to scrutinise for national regulators. That means that it will help companies to raise capital more easily, helping them to stay solvent, recapitalise their business and strengthen their resilience in the recovery. Thanks to your efforts, we’ve achieved a format for the new Recovery Prospectus that eases the administrative burden on companies while giving investors enough information to allow them to make an informed decision. Now turning to the reform of the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive II (MiFID II). Let me explain why this reform is just as important in my view.  The new rules on small cap research will enhance the visibility of small and medium—sized companies for investors, so it will help these companies to raise capital on public markets. On the derivatives reform, the amendments are essentially about green energy, and how to make it easier to finance a new generation of renewable energy projects. Providers of renewable energy rely on a secure income stream and this is what the derivatives markets for energy achieve. To be effective, derivatives markets need to be liquid. If we maintain the current low position limit at 25% per market participant, the nascent energy exchanges will never take off. In smaller Member States, exchanges have only two or three active market participants.  There is also a clear link between these amendments on the derivatives market and the pandemic. During this COVID-19 crisis, energy prices have been volatile because of a more erratic pattern of energy demand. It is essential to protect income for renewable energy suppliers, particularly when demand is so volatile. As highlighted in a recent communication on fostering the openness, strength and resilience of the EU’s economic and financial system, we need to support the development of euro—denominated derivative markets, so that the EU will be globally competitive. Finally, during the COVID-19 crisis, more people are using online financial services; fewer are visiting local bank branches. This switch from paper—based information to electronic format will benefit retail clients, who will receive the relevant information faster. This will also enable investment firms to use their resources more efficiently, and this will also align our financial legislation with the objectives of the Green Deal and Digital Agenda.  Other changes will only apply to business—to—business relationships and will not have any impact on retail investors. While I believe that the MiFID II amendment represents a real improvement, I want to acknowledge this evening the concerns expressed by some of you on these amendments. Some of you have mentioned that there was not a proper impact assessment accompanying this proposal. Last year, when the crisis hit, we wanted to respond in a timely way, but we did so with a very solid look at the pros and cons of the proposed way forward. The main costs and benefits resulting from the amendments, including on the derivatives markets, are analysed in a separate staff working document. Some of you also suggested that the reform would undermine the rules protecting investors, and that more clarity was needed on product governance rules and the real costs linked to investment products.  One objective of the Capital Markets Union Action Plan is to make the EU an even safer place for individuals to save and invest for the long-term and their retirement. In this context, we are working on a retail investment strategy.  We will set out a coherent and consistent approach to all investor protection issues related to MiFID II and other horizontal legislation, and I look forward to working closely with all of you on these issues. To conclude, I would like to stress that the Capital Markets Recovery Package includes targeted measures to speed up the recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic and help the financial ecosystem to recover as soon as possible. We have done this in a timely and efficient manner given the significance of the crisis. Voting in favour of the Recovery Prospectus and the modifications to the MiFID II rules will give a positive signal that the EU institutions can act quickly and decisively in times of need.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, rapporteurs, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to share with you two facts which I think can make us reflect. It is two facts that show a terrible weakness in the fabric of European SMEs, which highlight the great dependence of European SMEs on bank debt, rather than having the luck and opportunity to have greater investors to bet on their equity and free them from that very heavy burden of bank debt. In the European Union, in the first half of 2020, bank loans to SMEs totalled EUR 573 billion compared to venture capital investment, whether venture capital, private equity, business angel crowd,funding, which reached only EUR 14.1 billion. I would like to ask all those who are thinking of voting against these two amendments to the pamphlet and MiFID II whom they believe they are protecting or who they want to benefit. I have been an entrepreneur for eight years of my life and assured them that the greatest luck an entrepreneur can have is a shareholder, an investor, someone who bets on the project one is working for every day. The biggest burden is bank debt, having to repay a credit. Luck is being able to have investors. We need European companies to have more investors. We need to give that oxygen to European SMEs, which are the ones that create jobs. These measures have to be adopted, but not just temporarily. They should be approved on an ongoing basis. And finally, Commissioner, you took the opportunity to say that we should approve the Capital Markets Union project as soon as possible.

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, after three speeches by EPP politicians I’m happy to present the real concerns of the S&D Group around this MiFID quick-fix.  Firstly, the exact link between the proposed changes and the COVID pandemic is rather weak and we risk watering down the legislative framework without a proper political and technical evaluation. Clearly, we cannot use this health crisis to set a deregulating agenda of the financial sector.  Secondly, we struggle to believe that issuers’ ability to raise capital is massively improved by stopping to disclose losses to professional investors, by suspending best execution reports, or by deleting quantitative elements from the ancillary tests. Thirdly, by reducing clarity on product governance rules and the real costs linked to investment products, this quick-fix completely fails to protect investors against all sorts of misselling. Such a step is never justified, and even less so in times of crisis. The S&D Group wants to support SMEs by facilitating the raising of capital and at the same time safeguarding the transparency framework for retail and institutional investors. Please listen to consumer organisations, think-tanks and ESMA, for example, before making your decisions. The best way to do this reform is through the overall review of MiFID/MiFIR later this year.  To my appreciated and experienced EPP colleague, I would like to say I would like to take seriously your words that the EPP is not promoting a deregulation agenda. If that is the case, you can show it later this year when we are doing the overall review of MiFID II. That will be the litmus test for you and your words in front of this Parliament.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, may I say at the outset, I welcome the opportunity to speak on this issue. I suppose we could talk forever with regard to the challenges that businesses face in terms of accessing credit and accessing capital. So any regulations that are changed in the terms of the MiFID ‘quick fix’ and the Prospectus Regulation are welcome in this emergency climate. We are in an emergency situation. We have shrinking economies across Europe, and we have companies that are crying out for cash injections and for access to capital. So I do welcome that.  Of course, the challenge is – and this probably wasn’t foreseen last year – that we are now a year into the COVID pandemic and, while there is an end in sight, it is a long way away. From that perspective, I do believe that we have to be very creative from now until when we can start to unwind from the COVID pandemic to ensure that there is capital, and liquidity and credit available right across the European Union. I don’t think the traditional banking sector will be able to supply that. So I would also urge for a rapid move in terms of the Capital Markets Union and the outstanding issues there to ensure that this is in place for the hopeful upturn that will come post-COVID pandemic.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her After the 2008 financial crisis and multibillion-dollar bailouts for banks and financial juggernauts, disclosure and reporting requirements for the financial sector were increased – a concession to general outrage over the socialization of private losses without recourse to private profits. The result: hekatomb en paper and higher fees for investors. As a result of disproportionate lockdowns in response to a mild epidemic that quickly contained East Asia but overwhelms the EU, the EU is experiencing the biggest economic downturn in peacetime. The answer: this House is voting for 750 billion illegal EU debt and a building fund to combat climate change and more migration – as useful for building up as irrigation of the Sahara. But the desert is growing and thirsting for private investment. For this to happen, disclosure requirements are now relaxed again, because the Green Deal takes precedence over stability. Either disclosure and transparency stabilize markets or they inhibit investment and the economy. Either - or. You do not know for yourself, and what you are doing here will fail, because the money does not go to future industries, but to world rescue projects and dream dances.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, from the outset, when this package was presented, from the Green Group we said in a very clear way that we would be open to discussing any measure that was justified in the context of the COVID-19 crisis that required a retouching of financial legislation, but that we would not tolerate the use of COVID-19 as an excuse to tweak some essential pieces of our financial protection. And with the package presented today, we have the counter-example—what is justified reform and what is not. We will support the reform of the brochure: first, because it is time-limited; secondly, because it is perfectly part of the COVID-19 crisis: we make a new prospectus specifically for recovery, adding also new information related to COVID-19, such as whether that company has received state aid — that will be — and therefore, for us, it is perfectly justified and will receive our support. But in the retouching of MiFID we cannot agree; we are still not convinced that this is necessary: first, as the Commissioner has said, because, even though the Directive says that, before we carry out a review, we need an impact assessment, we do not have that impact assessment yet; and also because, as regards the argument of liquidity in emerging energy markets, we have not been sufficiently well explained why this is necessary; and, in any case, if it were, we could wait perfectly for the overall review of MiFID that we have to do in a few months in order to deal with this very delicate debate, since energy markets are extremely volatile and have effects not only on energy markets, but also, depending on how prices evolve, in others such as food markets. Therefore, this second reform is not justified, and the Green Group will not support it.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, financial markets can contribute a lot to overcoming the economic impact of the COVID pandemic. I therefore welcome the Commission’s swift action to propose targeted amendments to MiFID II and the Prospectus Directive, and also congratulate the rapporteurs Mr Ferber and Mr Kovařík for their work. To recover from the unprecedented health crisis, companies desperately need access to capital. Our regulatory framework should therefore enable, and not hinder, financial markets to contribute to the recovery. It is indeed appropriate to reduce costs and administrative burdens where this is possible, without putting in danger market integrity and investor protection. The capital markets union, Madam Commissioner, is crucial for rebuilding the EU’s economy after coronavirus. It is also crucial for the long—term sustainability of our monetary union, and it is also very important for increasing efficient absorption of risks within the monetary union. So I really would ask you to speed up the work on this capital markets union. It is in all our interests.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Madam President, whenever there are financial deregulation initiatives, the conversation is always the same, it is to help the economy, it is to help small and medium-sized enterprises and now, apparently, it is also to help the environment. But it is not perceived very well, and more confusing than any information in any prospectus of a financial product, is the justification for these two initiatives. If the information being cut in the prospectuses for financial products in this proposal is not relevant information, it is redundant, it only confuses, it is not quite perceived why this information is permanently withdrawn, and it is also not quite perceived that withdrawing information from prospects helps the economic recovery. If financial products are good, then all the information will only convince investors to bet on these financial products. If the products are not so good, then the doctrine that presides over this proposal is to trick small investors into helping the economy that is, as it says, helping the banks. Financial deregulation has never served to recover from any financial crisis. How many financial crises will this Commission help to provoke until you learn such a simple rule? I come from a country where hundreds, by the way, thousands of small investors have been scammed by a bank, losing the savings of a lifetime, precisely because of the lack of relevant information regarding the products they were subscribing to. The guilt of these crimes died single. Neither the European nor the national institutions have responded to these frauds, and I would very much like to be able to say to these small investors that these things will not happen again. These proposals do not help to ensure that this promise is fulfilled.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, as one of the shadow rapporteurs for the Prospectus Directive, I think that we are striking a very good balance between consumer protection and easing the possibility for companies, SMEs included, to collect desperately needed capital in the aftermath of the COVID—19 outbreak. I would repeat the point of informing investors about the impacts of COVID—19, on the information given. But we need to see that even though it is a strong stress for our companies, it is also a strong possibility for renewable technologies, future—proof environmental and digitalisation, and innovative companies. We do need to give the possibility for these kind of companies to collect in an easier way the desperately needed capital, so that they are the future growing entities of our economy, and the ones that seek to raise our economy, employment and competitiveness in the longer term as well.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Madam President, while following the path of economic and financial reforms, in the long-run we must preserve our regulatory standards and prudential rules. Without abandoning them, we ought, however, to be able to adjust flexibly to crisis situations like the one we now face with COVID-19. There is an urgent need to mobilise private capital, not least at SME level, in order to counter the hits that have crippled too many companies. Quick temporary fixes that lighten regulatory burdens on how companies finance their operations without undermining investor protection make sense. The setting-up of an EU Recovery Prospectus until December 2022, in the framework of the capital markets’ recovery package, is one such quick fix.  It should incentivise issuers and investors and help to inject new liquidity in businesses, for drawing up an investment prospectus can be expensive, which might deter issuers from seeking to raise new funds. By lowering this expense, the EU Recovery Prospectus makes new investment less onerous. Provided issuers of shares already are admitted to trading on a regulated market, or investing in a growth with market continuously for at least the last 18 months, the condensed disclosure requirements in the prospectus should now reduce launch costs and make the document easier to read. Correspondingly, limited to the recovery phase, an offer of such securities is, under certain conditions, not subject to the obligation of publishing a prospectus. The threshold has been doubled to  EUR 150 million to allow more offers to be exempted.  The EU Recovery Prospectus will carry minimum essential information for secondary issuance of shares. However, it would also need to have an additional concrete reference to the impact of the COVID-19 on the business of the issuer. It must explicitly inform potential investors of how the businesses concerned by the issuance have been affected by COVID-19. With these simplified features, approval of the Recovery Prospectus should be possible more quickly, for investment speed is of the essence in the recovery. It was encouraging to note the strong political will for this project to succeed shown by all members of the Council, the Commission and not least, most sides...  (President cut-off the speaker)

name: Engin EROGLU
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Everything we are discussing here today still has a long way to do with the 2008 financial crisis. We remember that US banks bundled real estate into securities, sold them to Europe – the securities were, so to speak, toxic. As a result, we had a gigantic financial market crisis of around EUR 3 trillion. The result is that, out of the panic, which was absolutely right, we have started to regulate the financial markets as a whole in all areas. What has now emerged is that it is over-regulation that leads to considerable fixed costs.  These significant fixed costs mean that more and more banks and financial service providers, which are still advising, advising, merging and disappearing from the market. More and more brokerage companies, which only mediate financial products and loans through clicks, are growing out of the Internet.  Our aim must be to have as much personal advice as possible in the financial market sector, and this can only be done by reducing these fixed costs and by enabling Volksbanken and Sparkassen in Germany to offer financial services as a stable anchor for Europe as well.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As is so often the case in the EU, there is a nice headline here – but there is very little else behind it.  For a decade, the ECB has been pumping vast amounts of fresh money into financial markets, and with this disastrous fiscal policy has only helped the bankrupt states and financial speculators. In the real economy, however, only a fraction of these trillions have arrived in euros. The relaxation of a few rules and the introduction of a new prospectus will not help much either.  I would also remind you that, at the same time, the EU is pushing ahead with a huge project to destroy European industry. This project is called the Green Deal, it makes life difficult for European industry all the time and now there is also no legal and planning security for companies in the EU. Unfortunately, this European Parliament also bears a shaken degree of complicity in this – that is poison for the economy.  As long as the EU does not abandon its ideologically driven actions and return to a path of reason and realpolitik, even the most beautiful plans will not help.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Madam President, today's prospectus providing the investor with information about the company in which he is going to invest has hundreds of pages. It is complicated and costs the issuer around a million euros. I therefore support the introduction of a new, cheaper recovery prospectus, which has been proposed as a temporary simplification in response to Covid. Investor protection will not suffer significantly and, with a maximum of 30 pages, will save companies 50 % of the costs, according to the Commission's estimates. However, I regret that the final text failed to improve the indicators for next year's Commission evaluation report on the prospectus. The EU's share of the global market is shrinking, with European capital markets far from exploiting its full potential. In order to improve the regulation in the future, we will therefore need relevant data to show us a true picture of the situation.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, the economic difficulties caused by COVID-19 serve as a pretext for the European Commission to put its protective hand on the financial markets. The pandemic is the pretext for reducing information requirements instituted after the financial crisis that broke out in 2008. The pretext for suspending and easing measures aimed at making these markets more transparent in the context of greater regulation which is thus relaxed at the first opportunity. Curious, or perhaps not, is the fact that stock markets have a higher turnover and transactions, also increased volatility during the pandemic, which is why, at the very least, the need for capital markets to recover will be questionable. These markets have not been buffeted by the tremendous crisis we are experiencing today, as millions of workers have been left without work and without sustenance. As were so many micro, small and medium entrepreneurs. All of these, yes, lack special protection. None of them win with such measures. The pandemic has made it clearer in which world we live. At times like this the waters are more clearly separated.  As the other one said, "It's capitalism, stupid!".

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. We are well known that the coronavirus crisis is putting enormous pressure on the European economy. Now we need to focus on the survival of companies and saving millions of jobs. We must also put the regulation of the financial sector at the service of this. This is supported by the capital market recovery package we are discussing. I hope the left side of the room understands that. We can't stick to the rigid rules we've had so far. We need to reduce the administrative burden and make it easier for capital market investments to work. We need to pay particular attention to retail customers who have less knowledge and therefore need more protection and information when investing.  The Capital Markets Union would allow businesses to obtain fresh resources in a cross-border manner and could therefore play a central role in economic recovery. All the more so as it is increasingly difficult to ensure the competitiveness of European capital markets compared to much larger and more efficient US or fast-growing Capital Markets in China. Moreover, Brexit has caused the EU to lose its most advanced financial market. So we have a lot of work to do. The two legislative amendments we are discussing are helping to achieve these objectives, so I fully support them and I very much hope that the left will eventually change its mind.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, my group has negotiated, agreed and voted favourably, in the last six months, on different legislative texts to facilitate the financing of businesses and to address the financial challenges posed by the coronavirus crisis.  We have negotiated, agreed and voted on the revision of the RRC, we have done the same with the STS, with the change of the RRC requiring the revision of the STS. We have also negotiated the text of brochures and we have also done so with the benchmarks text. However, today we cannot do it with MiFID. And perhaps it would be good to say that, in a text, Commissioner, of just twelve pages of articulation, the rapporteur tabled twenty-nine amendments to us. My group has tried to keep this text as close as possible to the Commission's initial proposal. And it hasn't been possible. We have failed to convince the rapporteur and the other groups in the House, to the right of this House, that it was necessary to remain at the perimeter of the Commission's proposal. And, therefore, we will not be able to vote for it.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, rapporteur Ferber, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has said. MiFID has always been a regulatory monster that has not caused as much trouble for the big banks and corporations as it has for the medium-sized economy. A quarter of all companies said they had not been able to find the right form to meet the requirements. The German Presidency has therefore always been critical of MiFID, and Brexit and COVID are now forcing us to deregulate. We would have liked to see more courageous deregulation, and we must take note of the fact that the rapporteur would then have left a little of the courage, even though the majority in this House stood. We shall, however, vote in favour, because we prefer the sparrow in our hands to the dove on the roof, and we are particularly pleased that the regulation of the position limitation of industrial commodity derivatives can be reduced – that is what German and European small and medium-sized industry needs. We shall therefore vote in favour; however, it must not remain so. The eurozone economy needs less left-green over-regulation and more trust and more freedoms, and that creates prosperity.

name: Aurore LALUCQ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are facing a historic crisis, and what are some of us finally proposing? They propose to take advantage of this crisis to make more deregulation, more deregulation, to remove all the safeguards that had been created to protect Europeans as much as possible from future financial crises, from future banking crises. The very people who generally teach us public finance management lessons and accountability lessons are pushing the issue of deregulation very far. Don't worry, they will obviously be there when it comes to the rescue of the banks through the public finances, but they will also be there later to tell us that we will have to make efforts from a public finance point of view. What for? Because we will have fed the public debt to be able to support some banks and certain financial players. Next time, let us propose to these people to save the Europeans rather than the banks first. Let us also propose to them to take the risks and the responsibility they take in making financial deregulation and to pay for the next crisis themselves, if there is one.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: – Mr President, as a response to the crisis and the need to facilitate diversified sources of finance for our SMEs, the Commission proposed a quick fix to MiFID to ease some of the requirements companies face to raise money on the markets on a temporary basis. Unfortunately, a balanced solution was not the result of the negotiation here at Parliament. The EPP negotiator insisted on relaxing the rules too much, taking us back to a deregulation paradigm, similar to what we had before the financial crisis.  For us that is not acceptable. We cannot live with insufficient transparency, clarity and investor protection from mis-selling. These are key elements in the market and we have the experience from the financial crisis a decade ago to know where deregulation leads. Have we learned nothing from the past? Madam Commissioner, this reform has become dangerous; thus, our Group does not support it. But we still count on you for a balanced structural revision of MiFID this year.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members for their contributions. It’s been a robust debate, which I think is really important. What I see and what you have spoken of today is a pandemic, a health crisis, a very difficult economic situation and businesses that are struggling to survive. And let me be very clear. The people who will benefit from the Capital Markets Recovery Package are small companies, renewable energy producers and retail investors.  Mr Ferber and colleagues are debating – it’s excellent to hear it from this podium! But let me continue.  Our proposals to amend MiFID and PROSPECTUS will make it easier for capital markets to support European businesses so that they can recover from the crisis by raising essential equity capital. They will also facilitate the involvement of investors in the capital markets, while preserving our high levels of investor protection. As I’ve already said, this package will also be a positive signal to the financial markets in general and companies in particular. This package shows that the EU can adapt quickly to changing circumstances to support the real economy. The proposed measures are important and I hope they will be adopted and take effect as soon as possible.  But these amendments are not the end of the road. In particular, I’m ready, with my services, to engage with all of you on our Retail Investment Strategy, where we will take a holistic view of concerns on investor protection raised by the application of MiFID and other sectoral legislation. We will also closely cooperate with Parliament on a broader review of MiFIR to enhance market transparency.  I’d like to refer to some of the comments that were made. As I said, I enjoy a robust debate. This is a vital issue. We know that our capital markets are not fully developed in Europe, we know that banks cannot be the only source of funding for our SMEs and our businesses, and therefore we need to work together to strengthen our capital markets.  And yes, you are right to refer to crises of the past. I recall 2008, and many of us know what happened to families and businesses because of that, but in fact in today’s crisis, because we regulated the banks effectively, we now see that the banks and the capital markets can be part of the solution, continuing to lend to businesses. I therefore think that anyone who might suggest that this Commission, or me as Commissioner for Financial Stability, is on a mission to deregulate, please note that this is not the case. If anything, my experience of the past and my work in this Parliament previously make me more determined to have effective legislation and regulation which protects investors and provides us with a strong capital market. So can I say very clearly there will be no deregulation on my watch.  I know that I won’t persuade many of you to vote in favour of this, but I hope that you understand the sincerity of my contribution to this debate. You know we will come forward very soon and look again at MiFID, so there will be an opportunity for us to work together. As we look forward, I hope we can bring our sides together because we need a better coordinated approach on these issues through the recovery, because if we don’t have that, our companies will struggle. We will not be able to recreate employment in sectors where it is absolutely essential.  So, despite the diverse views and the deep divisions, I take from all of you a desire to work better together, to strengthen our resolve around capital markets, and to protect our SMEs and our workers, and I stand ready to do the same with you and cooperate fully.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 10 February 2021.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements 25 years after the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action: Future Challenges in Relation to Women's Rights (2021/2509(SDR)). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted.  In addition, as was the case during the last part-sessions, there are remotely intervention by Parliament's liaison offices in the different Member States of choice.

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, gender equality is a priority for the Portuguese Presidency, and we are determined to do everything we can to tackle the emerging challenges and to push this agenda forward. The 25th anniversary of the Beijing Platform for Action was an opportunity to take stock of the progress achieved, to reconfirm the commitments undertaken, and to identify new challenges, reminding us that all Member States have a clear obligation to eliminate discrimination against women, and ensure that they fully enjoy all human rights. Much progress has been made over the past few decades to the benefit of women and girls in the European Union and across the world. However, many challenges remain, and we must step up and step up gender equality policies. Unfortunately, the pandemic has aggravated some of these challenges. We need therefore to make an assessment of the impact of COVID-19 on gender equality – in particular on labour market participation, incomes, and reconciliation of work, personal and family life. The Council has recently also focused on the issue of care work. During the current pandemic, more than ever, it is time we recognise and value the importance of unpaid care work, giving credit to those who perform it and keep our societies running. Other challenges that need to be addressed comprise gender discrimination, especially against more vulnerable groups of women, threats against sexual and reproductive health and rights, violence against women, and issues arising from digitalisation, including cyber—violence. Equally important is to tackle the practices, prejudices and customs within society, including those carried out by private persons and organisations that hinder the fulfilment of women’s human rights. The most notable ongoing policy development in the Union regarding women’s rights, and in particular violence against women, is in relation to the Istanbul Convention. Although the proceedings on the EU ratification of the Convention are temporarily suspended, pending the European Court of Justice opinion, calls have been made at Council level for ratification by Member States that have not yet done so. Such ratification will precede adoption by the EU. In this regard, the Portuguese Presidency will host in April a conference in Lisbon to mark the 10th anniversary of the Convention.  Coming back to women and the labour market, the Presidency will also work to unblock the Directive on gender balance on company boards, and stands ready to start negotiations on binding pay transparency measures, on the basis of the forthcoming Commission proposal. We also need to keep abreast of technological developments, and make sure that women and girls can seize the opportunities offered by digitalisation.  Finally, we must ensure gender equality mainstreaming across the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights. With that in mind, the upcoming informal Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council (EPSCO) meeting will address the issue of gender equality in social Europe. Mr President, honourable Members, Commissioner, gender equality is also at the heart of our international engagement. The Council is finalising an ambitious EU position paper in preparation for the 26th session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women.  This will take place in New York next March. The priority theme for this year is women’s full and effective participation and decision—making in public life, as well as the elimination of violence for achieving gender equality and the empowering of women and girls. This topic is very timely in the COVID context, not least against the backdrop of the shadow pandemic of violence against women during lockdowns, but also with a view to ensuring that women are in the forefront of developing solutions during the pandemic and their recovery phase. The rights of women and girls, as well as gender equality needs to be addressed in a cross—cutting manner in all the EU external action, on the basis of the EU consensus on development, and the rights—based approach to development. We must recognise that, in many parts of the world, girls and women continue to be systematically left behind and discriminated against. In this context, the Portuguese Presidency welcomes the Third Gender Action Plan presented by the Commission and the High Representative at the end of last year. We look forward to working with the Member States, the Commission, and the European External Action Service (EEAS) as well as with the European Parliament to implement and advance this ambitious and utterly necessary agenda. The same is true for CSDP missions and operations, where women are still under—represented at most levels. We hope that the EEAS will develop a dedicated strategy and action plan to provide the systemic mainstreaming of human rights and gender aspects, promoting a better representation of women in CSDP missions. In conclusion, much has been done and much more remains to be done. In numbers and relevant sectors, we need to look ahead, and we need to use the relevant elements of the Beijing Platform for Action. Gender equality is, and must remain, at the very core of everything that we do at Union level.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I thank the honourable Members for putting the 25th anniversary of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action on the agenda today. This anniversary provides us with an excellent opportunity to discuss the situation of gender equality and empowerment of women and girls in this particular time. It is important to reflect on where we are and where we are heading to. The Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action was adopted 25 years ago. It is the most inspiring global blueprint of gender equality and it still guides us today. The Beijing Conference was a fundamental step in the global commitment that we have jointly embraced since. Progress has been made in these years but girls and women still face many hurdles and challenges that remain unaddressed. Across the world, including in some of our own Member States, we see a serious threat for, and backlash on, women’s rights. This backlash manifests itself in various forms and settings, like for instance in the opposition we have seen in the EU to adhere to legal frameworks to combat violence against women. This opposition is sometimes based on the mere fact that the word ‘gender’ is used.  This directly endangers the monitoring of the EU’s commitments under the Beijing Platform for Action, as well as the work the EU does in terms of gender equality. It leads to a situation where no consensus can be found among Member States on Council conclusions that aim to report on the EU’s progress on the Beijing Platform for Action. We should all mobilise our forces to counter this very worrying trend and not let this impede our international commitments under the Beijing Platform for Action. Every year during the meeting of the Commission on the Status of Women (CSW) at the UN General Assembly, we reaffirm the commitments agreed in the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action and the engagement to embrace the new challenges ahead. The United Nations Secretary-General called for a pushback against the pushback. Power remains a crucial element empowering women and girls, calls for equal rights for girls and women as boys and men. We need to make these equal rights a reality for all. This year’s CSW session deals with full and effective participation of women in public and political life. It highlights the importance of women and girls as agents of change and as decision-makers and leaders on all issues and at all levels. This is crucial for adequately translating their needs and skills into policies to achieve gender equality and a more peaceful, secure, just and sustainable world.  To reach this we need to help all enablers that allow for women’s and girls’ meaningful participation in public and political life. We also need to eradicate gender-based violence, including online violence, that risks to silence women, and we started our work on EU-wide legislation addressing this. In fact, last Monday we launched a public consultation on this topic. This is a key priority for us, including as part of the Generation Equality Forum, where the EU is a co-leader on gender-based violence.  In order to tackle gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls, the Commission adopted two key policy strategies: the Gender Equality Strategy 2020-2025 for our internal action and the EU Gender Action Plan III for our external action. The crisis we are experiencing has amplified their relevance and urgency to advance and push further the Beijing commitments and make a real change in the life of women and girls. The widening of socio-economic inequalities for women in particular, the spike in domestic violence and the digital gender gap are all at the centre of our areas of engagement, both internally and externally.  The EU is committed to lead by example. This is firmly positioned at the core of the EU policy on gender equality and women’s empowerment. We do this by establishing the requirement of a gender-responsive leadership for all EU leaders and managers in the Gender Action Plan III.  Gender mainstreaming is one of the core principles of both the Gender Equality Strategy and the Gender Action Plan III that we presented last year. This is a crucial principle to advance on gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls. It is central to the philosophy of the 12 Beijing critical areas of concern. It underlines the importance of mainstreaming agenda perspective throughout all the Sustainable Development Goals of Agenda 2030 and its key principle not to leave anyone behind. It is also a crucial principle in the implementation of the Women Peace and Security Agenda, aiming for gender equality, peace and security.  We need to advance not in words but in deeds, including through our financial commitments. The EU long-term budget 2021-2027, together with Next Generation EU, with a stimulus package of EUR 1.8 trillion, will ensure financing for the promotion of gender equality. Eighty-five per cent of all our external actions will be gender-responsive. They will promote gender equality and women’s empowerment across sectors of intervention.  I particularly want to congratulate the European Parliament on its successful role in ensuring a gender-sensitive perspective in the EU budget and recovery. Together with the Agenda 2030, the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action, remains a crucial reference document to advance gender equality and to empower women and girls. The COVID-19 pandemic and the growing backlash against women’s rights highlight the importance of our continued vigilance on gender equality. It is important now more than ever to keep working together to achieve the objectives that we have set.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, after 25 years of the Beijing Declaration, one would have assumed that we would have met already those 12 targets that we set there for women’s equality and for gender equality. But even though there has been some substantial progress, especially in some areas like in the EU, globally we have seen little progress, on one hand. And on the other hand, we have seen some backlashes, as we have seen in sexual and reproductive rights, even in some of the EU Member States. And this is something that needs to come to end. What the Parliament says is: looking through the targets of the Beijing +25 evaluation, highlighting the points that need to be developed further acutely, and then underlies digitalisation, violence against women, especially in social media, the pay gap that still exists, the pension gap that comes out of that. Full parity in representation is still lacking, and social rights, as has been said, very unequally treating male and female people. So, I encourage the Commission and congratulate their activity in their gender equality programme, it’s a good one. And I encourage you to read very carefully the Parliament’s resolution and other reports that we have made in this area, and we ensure the full support of whatever activities you are going to take in this field.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, colleagues, the Beijing Declaration is the most comprehensive global agenda for promoting gender equality, and today, a quarter of a century later, we have to find that, although progress has been made towards girls and women, especially in Europe, overall progress is indeed unacceptably slow and there is a risk that hard-to-achieve achievements in the area of gender equality will go wrong. To date, none of the Countries of the European Union has achieved the objectives set out in the Beijing Declaration. Although all Member States have ratified the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (which, by the way, it came into force more than forty years ago), persisting and even greater inequalities are unfortunately a painful reality. Colleagues, gender inequality is a multifaceted phenomenon. It not only covers all aspects of the labour market, starting with lower women's wages for the same work and precarious work, which in itself leads to a large pension gap between women and men, which increases the risk of poverty and exclusion, especially for older women and single mothers. Gender inequality is not just an economic phenomenon, it is both violence against women and sexual exploitation of women and girls. And this year we will commemorate the tenth anniversary of the Istanbul Convention. However, it is a shame, we must admit that, to this day, some Member States have not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention. I therefore really want to call on the Member States, both the Council and the Commission, to take all measures necessary to ratify the Istanbul Convention so that we can send a clear message that protection against violence is a priority for the European Union. The COVID-19 pandemic has shown very clearly what gender inequality really means. Covid's socio-economic impact is a disproportionate burden for women, as this pandemic has had the greatest impact on women-dominated sectors and occupations such as health, social services, education, retail workers, cashiers, cleaners, women with independent small businesses. And there is a very serious risk that this pandemic will only exacerbate the already wide-off inequalities and change the trend of progress. So, in fact, I call on both the Commission, the honourable Commissioner, and the Presidency and colleagues to join forces to make real progress.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, twenty-five years after the Beijing Declaration — as has been said, the most comprehensive global regulatory framework on women's rights — we must recognize that no country in the world has achieved the objectives of equality; nor in the countries of the European Union. There are many challenges to be achieved: differences in wages, in public, economic representation, in large companies... but above all, you said so, Commissioner, we are facing enormous challenges today about the setbacks and threats to the rights we have achieved. That is why today, when we see that in European Union countries such as Poland women's right to sexual and reproductive health is threatened and trampled on, we need to remember, as twenty-five years ago in Beijing was said, that women's rights are human rights and human rights are women's rights. And in the European Union we cannot allow any country to trampl on the human rights of its citizens. That's why I want to ask you to pay attention to the biggest threats. Violence against women is a major threat and increases. I ask you, Commissioner, to urgently put in place a special protocol of assistance and care for women victims of violence in emergencies, such as the pandemic. Let us not allow, in a third wave, fourth wave, to live in solitude and with their aggressor without the necessary services this violence.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Given the list of speakers, it seems to be an affront to speak as a man on the subject of women's rights. I do it anyway.  Women often complain about a lack of freedom of choice between family and work, because it is really difficult to reconcile the two. We must therefore support this freedom of choice. Men, by the way, like to tell you how many children they have – women don't. Why, in fact? They should not be ashamed of their motherhood. Twenty-five years after Beijing, we should go back to what was really decided there: that gender means nothing but the male and female sex in the social environment. If you really want to stand up for women's rights, dear gender-moving colleagues, then you are simply concerned about the 99% of women who know exactly that they are a woman when they get up in the morning and who do not want to choose one of the 66 sexes. Just accept the biological differences between man and woman and stop plucking the creator into the craft.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we will commemorate the twenty-five years of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action. It was a historic moment, a moment of ambition to really build a multilateral framework for dialogue to advance women's rights. And if there's one thing we have to learn from this anniversary, it's that we need to put back the same ambition we had then on a global agenda to fight emerging inequalities. Because we know that the pandemic is reproducing some patterns we thought we forgot, escalating violence, or forcing women to return to more reproductive tasks because of the pandemic. And that forces us to be more ambitious in our politics. In domestic policy, Commissioner, we already know that we have an ambitious agenda and gender equality strategy that we must develop, but we cannot allow, as other Members have said, that some Member States still trampl, within the European Union, on women's rights. We must be forceful about this and also a powerful voice outwards, with that gender equality action plan that we have endowed ourselves with in the European Union, because the European Union has to intervene in any scenario where women's rights are being trampled on.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear! The 25th anniversary of the Beijing Declaration is an opportunity to take stock of actions for gender equality and the protection of women's rights. So let's look at why it was really dedicated. It aimed to draw attention to the problem of poverty, education, the situation of women in armed conflicts, the issue of violence against women.  Twenty-five years later, let us look at how it works and how it has affected the situation of women in the European Union. More than half a million women in the Union have experienced genital mutilation. We also still have a problem with a large pay gap when it comes to women's pay. Fortunately, in Poland, which is so often mentioned here, this gap is one of the smallest. Yes, the wage gap in Poland is one of the smallest in the European Union.  That's when it comes to women's rights. In the European Union, on the other hand, young girls are still forced to marry adult men, which is a de facto paedophile practice. So we still have a lot of work to do in our common home, in Europe.

name: Eugenia RODRÍGUEZ PALOP
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Mr President, the diagnosis is clear: we are moving at a turtle's pace, there are setbacks, some pulled on the far right, and the pandemic is having dire consequences for women. Extrapolated to the Beijing Convention, this means that no State has achieved its objectives. In the meantime, there is no way to ratify the Istanbul Convention, the proposal for an anti-discrimination directive and that of women in leadership positions are blocked, some reject abortion as a right and generally deny that feminist theory is a field of study. This is a party! But here we continue, unaffordable to discouragement. We need a European care pact that reduces the care gap and goes beyond the European Conciliation Directive; we need to address the feminization of poverty, improving the working conditions of the feminized sectors and serving older women and monomarental families; it is urgent to reduce the pay and pension gap by opting for an ambitious wage transparency directive and introducing correction mechanisms to support those who have already suffered the gap; access to free and quality public services must be ensured, especially in the case of sexual and reproductive rights; against sexist violence: a comprehensive directive, ratification of the Istanbul Convention and gender-based violence as a Eurodelith. Finally, we want money: the gender perspective must be integrated into European budgets and policies, and women's participation in decision-making bodies must be encouraged; that is why we have called for a Council training on gender equality. That's where I leave it.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Mr President, gender equality is a key prerequisite for world peace and development. The Beijing Declaration sets out strategic objectives for achieving equality in twelve key landmark areas for women's issues. Twenty-six years after the adoption of the Beijing Platform for Action, no country has achieved equality for women and girls. Important areas in need of improvement are women's access to work, the reduction of the pay gap between men and women, the elimination of violence against women, and the effective protection of women's rights. The European Union continues to take the lead in ensuring equal opportunities for women for equal access to all areas of social, political and economic life, as well as satisfactory representation in decision-making centres. Unfortunately, the economic crisis of the past decade and this health adventure have exposed women to alarmingly high rates of violence, poverty and impoverishment. The phenomena sound the alarm to governments and citizens so that we do not reject the achievements of the last decades of women's rights. Ladies and gentlemen, looking to future generations, we have an obligation through collectively organised actions to make a decisive contribution to reducing inequalities and vindicating the struggles of millions of women to recognise their rights in practice.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner! Council! Twenty-five years ago, representatives from 189 nations gathered and adopted the Beijing Declaration, with a vision of equal rights, freedom and opportunities for women. I wish we could celebrate this week – celebrating the success of women's human rights. Instead, however, we have debated Poland's restrictions on abortion rights here, in the session. Ten years ago, the Council of Europe's Istanbul Convention was opened and I wish that this year we could draw attention to the end of violence against women. Instead, however, we must continue to fight for all EU Member States to ratify the Convention. Progress has been made since the Beijing Declaration, but it has been far too slow, and we run the risk of the pandemic also taking longer. So we are now faced with a choice. We can continue at the pace that we have now. But then it will be 60 years before the EU is equal. Or we choose to act now, and I want to act.  I want to see a Europe in which women are fully involved in the labour market. In a Europe where both women and men work, economic growth is also increasing. I want to see a Europe where gender equality and climate go hand in hand, because equality is necessary if we want to deal with the climate crisis. I want to see a Europe that will immediately put an end to gender-based violence. Girls and women have the right to their own body. So, colleagues, it is time to step up the pace properly and make the vision a reality of girls' and women's equal rights, freedom and opportunity. I don't want my grandchildren to have to wait 60 years.

name: Chrysoula ZACHAROPOULOU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, 25 years after the Beijing Declaration, Europe is more committed than ever to promoting equality in all its policies.   On the world stage, she leads feminist diplomacy: Gender Action Plan III, Spotlight Initiative, Generation Equality Forum, commitments of which we should be proud.  Yet at the Nairobi summit last year, an international meeting for women's rights, two member states, Poland and Hungary, chose to disassociate themselves from the Europe family and sign Mr Trump's US declaration.  Just yesterday, in this Chamber, we debated the ban on abortion in Poland. Not to mention that the word "gender" is becoming taboo in the Council!  Commissioner, now is the time to look in the mirror. We must manage our own contradictions if we are to remain credible in the eyes of the citizens of the world.

name: Luisa REGIMENTI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 25 years after the Fourth United Nations World Conference on Women in Beijing, and despite numerous cases of formal recognition and progress on gender equality, women and men do not enjoy the same rights and social, economic and cultural inequalities persist. Today, phenomena such as poverty, education, health and violence are enormous challenges for women all over the world and for the realisation of an equal society. There is a strong need to address stereotypes that continue to be the main obstacle to enhancing women's skills and the cultural root of violence. The key words for change are: awareness of problems and education as a lever for transformation to make a change that is no longer retardable.

name: Kira Marie PETER-HANSEN
text: Mr President! In two weeks, I'll be 23. I'm about as old as this declaration. The question then is whether, during my time and the Beijing Declaration, we have achieved equality between men and women, have we ensured that women's rights are human rights? The individual answer is that we do not. A newborn girl is still less likely to attend school, to get an education and to become financially independent. In the EU, men still earn 16% more than women, and their pension savings are bigger, and it scares me that in 2021 we still have to debate whether a woman has the right to have an abortion today in an EU country – it simply does not work! I think we should make 2021 the year when we give equality a boost. We will take an important step in March when we get the equal pay proposal and can start working with wage transparency, and then I hope – I actually expect – that together we work together to close the gap that is between men and women. Not enough has happened in the first 25 years and I hope that we can achieve our goals in the next few years so that I and the Beijing Declaration can celebrate the 50th anniversary of an equal world.

name: Margarita DE LA PISA CARRIÓN
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, what has been achieved in all these years of fighting for equality? For the natural characteristics of women have been completely devalued. Today fertility, motherhood, conjugal love and family are seen as a negative thing. They sell us the freedom to decide on our own bodies. We are promised false autonomy that isolates us, an selfishness that turns against ourselves. Because we're not just a body. We're not a commodity, and neither is the baby we guard. Human beings have a spiritual and transcendent dimension that you are not courage and which, in reality, is everything. This transcendence gives meaning to our lives and allows us to create bonds, relationships based on a selfless love that opens us to the generosity and solidarity of welcoming a new life: the wonderful gift of being parents of a unique, unrepeatable and unique human being from the very moment of conception.  There's nothing crueler than taking his life. Each and every one of us is the fruits of the generosity of parents who have wanted to welcome us. How can we not give what we have received? We all long to have a family.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the 25th anniversary of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action is commemorated, to which the three previous UN conferences, namely the 1st World Conference on Women under the motto Equality, Development and Peace, in 1975 also contributed. We find that, despite the achievements achieved, there are serious problems that remain in women's lives. They continue to be the main victims of precarious work, unemployment, increased inequalities, violence in society, work and the family. We stress that sexual and reproductive health and the rights inherent to it are an integral part of the agenda on women's rights and that it is essential to increase efforts to improve women's rights and reproductive health at European and global level. We reaffirm that the centrality of the impacts that the COVID-19 pandemic is having on the downward spiral in women's lives should be a concern to be taken into account in the short-term challenges.

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Mr President, the Beijing Platform for Action gave us all a strong clear perspective for equality, gender equality. Hillary Clinton made a ground-breaking declaration that really resonated with women around the world: ‘women’s rights are human rights and human rights are women’s rights’. Back then if you had asked me where we would stand in 2021, I would have said the fight for gender equality would be over, that gender-based violence or equal pay and a lack of women’s representation would have been confined to history, it would have been dealt with.  Tragically, this has not happened. We hear it could be 80 years before we get political equality in the European Union. And 25 years post-Beijing and with a new generation of women we must now renew our pledge of purpose to make gender equality a reality.  We need all of society working towards this to end and eradicate gender-based violence once and for all, to combat the whole issue of women living in poverty, particularly single mothers and older women, to tackle the climate challenge with understanding of the real lived circumstances of women, and to have enough women at the decision-making table where there are clearly not enough there in critical numbers at present. The Generation Equality Forum will be an opportunity to tackle those challenges with a new generation of women seeing the next phase of this crusade.  Women have long fought this fight. We need male leaders, male champions, working with us if we are to succeed. Let this Beijing resolution be a real rallying call stating that in Europe we are the gender global leaders working for equality, all of us together. There is much work still to do, but with determination and cooperation, working together as I say, women and men, we can make this a reality.

name: Predrag Fred MATIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, when after 25 years since the Beijing Declaration and platform for action we look deeply and analyze the situation, unfortunately the situation is not satisfactory.   Rising gender-based violence, the gender pay gap, reduced access to health services, discrimination, marginalisation, prevented participation in political and public life - are just a part of the reality that women and girls face on a daily basis.   It is our obligation to correct this and work hard to achieve full gender equality and to deal with all that prevents us from doing so.   With great thanks to all those who more than 25 years ago participated in creating a new direction of gender equality and welcoming the many progress we have made, we must become aware that we are today at one of the crucial moments and I sincerely hope that as a community in this fight we will get on the right side.   Today, it is that side that fights violence, prohibition, abolition, restriction, and which brings together, includes and builds a society whose foundations were laid in those days in Beijing.    Let's not let it down.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Before continuing with the debates, I shall proceed to the communication of the results of today's first round of voting.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the continuation of the debate on the Council and Commission statements on 25 years following the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action: Future Challenges in relation to Women's Rights (2021/2509(SDR)).

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Mr President, this 25-year milestone since the Beijing Declaration is a moment of reflection. We honour the women who shattered glass ceilings and fought for progress. It’s because of them that I can be here today, in a Chamber that looks a little bit more like them. But progress has been slow and uneven, also within the EU. In one of the richest regions of the world there are still women skipping work or school because they cannot afford menstrual hygiene products. Abuse in maternity wards still exists, and there is still a taboo around it. Unpaid care work still falls mostly on women, and we are still being asked in job interviews about our plans to have children. I was as well. And we have governments within the Union that openly campaign against the Istanbul Convention, against combating domestic violence. And they say it is against their values. As if violence could ever be ‘a value’. And we have legislative proposals to fight against many of these problems but the Council has been sitting on it and not providing solutions. So today I demand: the EU-level ratification of the Istanbul Convention; a European Care Deal; and binding commitments instead of empty words. Because actions speak louder than words, and women’s rights are human rights. Stand up for it today as well.

name: Peter KOFOD
text: Mr President! This proposal on inequality, it really says everything about the European Parliament. Everything possible is mentioned: the climate, it is obviously a problem for equality, gender diversity across digital technology areas is a problem for equality, but in these 15 pages, the main problem is not mentioned, and that is forgotten. The main problem for me to see is That is Islamic immigration and its consequences on European soil: oppression of women, violence of domination, social control, forced marriage and that is how we could go on. It is simply not mentioned. To me, this is political correctness of the very worst drawer. Islamic communities are not the best communities to grow up in as a woman or be in as a woman, quite the opposite. When you import Islamic culture with all the problems it must have, you know that things are going to go wrong, and parliament here does not even mention it in the text. I think it's shameful.

name: Pierrette HERZBERGER-FOFANA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, more than 25 years after the Beijing Declaration, the European Parliament adopted last month the report on the strategy for equality between women and men. The report calls for strategic objectives to strengthen women's rights and gender equality. The challenges are many. Inequality persists, particularly in economic terms. Women are more likely to live in precarious conditions. This includes higher wage gaps, precarious jobs or unpaid domestic work, and low participation and representation of women in key and political positions. We, the Greens, are calling for an intersectional and inclusive approach to the gender dimension, a stronger link between the fight against climate change and equality policies, and a strategy to combat the feminization of poverty. The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated inequality, domestic violence, sexual harassment, forced prostitution, female genital mutilation, cyber-harassment and has served as an excuse for some Member States to limit sexual and reproductive rights. We are convinced that in order to eliminate this scourge, all Member States must respect and ratify the Istanbul Convention.

name: Assita KANKO
text: – Mr President, there is no finish line when it comes to equality. It is a daily battle to ensure that the rights that we have gained are not lost again. Despite the progress made in the 25 years since the Beijing Declaration, the lives of millions of women around the world remain painfully unchanged. As we all grow older, we notice that there is little change, little progress.
