For example: less pay when you have equal competences, just because you are not a man; no promotion because you are a mother or can become one; no education because you are a girl; sterilised or raped just because ‘they’ can; forced into a marriage; a survivor of female genital mutilation; death from a backstreet abortion because the state says you don’t have the right to make a decision regarding your own body. The global fight for equality is at the beginning, we are nowhere near its end. This Parliament must be a voice for everyone, fighting for a better, more equal future. We should all build bridges towards each other, with a better future for all women.

name: Giorgos GEORGIOU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the most barbaric, deadliest, most insidious pandemic — possibly more than corovirus — is violence against women. Every day 137 women are murdered by a member of their family. Last year, 243 million women were victims of sexual and physical violence. Violence against women, however, is also their under-representation in decision-making bodies. Violence is unemployment, redundancies and wage cuts for women as a result of capitalist growth and its neoliberal policies. It must be said that violence against women has peaked in the pandemic, even though women are at the forefront of tackling it.  Today, ladies and gentlemen, we are here to talk about the 25 years since the Beijing Declaration and the challenges ahead. But what future challenges, when the challenges of the past have not yet been addressed? Indeed, the Beijing Declaration contains objectives and actions that, if implemented, will cover women's rights in an effective way. But they will not materialize unless evil is struck at its root. Commissioner, this is our duty to every woman, wherever she is. This is our duty to humanity.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: - Mr President, twenty-five years have passed from the World Conference in Beijing — the great world meeting on women's rights and the most visionary programme for women's empowerment around the world. He proposed bold and strategic measures and remains a source of inspiration and framework in our roadmap. But the road during these twenty-five years has lights and shadows and has been desperately slow. No country, as they said here, has really achieved full gender equality. There is a long way to go in co-education, in education in equality, in the labour market, in the pay gap, the digital divide, the pension gap, in the participation in decision-making, so that poverty ceases to have a woman's face, in conciliation, in violence, still with blushing figures. In addition, we add to this that the pandemic has increased and deepened inequalities. That is why this debate is timely, because we must regain the spirit and commitment of Beijing. We have, after the pandemic, an obligation to rebuild the world and therefore we have to be reborn, placing diversity, respect, values and women and girls at the heart of our recovery plans. It is a global imperative for all those of us who believe in equity and justice; requires action and will and stop ideologizing these issues against each other. We all have to be together; equality is not debatable. Without it there is neither progress nor Europe nor there is freedom. That's why it has to be a fact besides being a right.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done on this report. How reasonable, how desirable are the objectives of the Beijing Declaration and Platform? How self-evident should they have been implemented a long time ago? We know the reality: not a single country in the European Union has achieved the 25-year-old objectives of the Platform for Action. In other words, there is a great deal to be done.  Central to me: the economic independence of women. Those who are financially independent can shape their own lives better. That is why the pay gap, the gender pay gap and the gender pension gap must be closed in the same way that we in the European Union need money specifically for women from the Reconstruction Fund right now. Because not only do women snare any crises, they are also at the forefront of future politics. Greta Thunberg and Wangari Maathai are just two of the many fantastic young environmental activists fighting for our future. Let us finally make the 21st century the century for women.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr "Human rights are women's rights and women's rights are human rights." A quote from a famous speech made 25 years ago when the countries of the world came together and laid the foundation for global gender equality work. Those who were gathered at the time, of course, had no idea how bad it would still be 25 years later. Despite all the fine words. That 400 million girls and women live below the global poverty line, that the right to abortion is challenged and withdrawn, that women are still mutilated, raped and killed by men in their vicinity. We must move from fine words to action. We must prioritise money to make a concrete difference. We have to do it all over, do the right thing and do better.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, 25 years have already passed since the Beijing Declaration, the powerful declaration on women's rights, and everyone today admits that its twelve strategic objectives have not been achieved and have not been fully achieved. We are already counting 64 years since the historic founding Treaty of Rome, where the founders and fathers of the European Union envisioned and incorporated race equality into the Treaty of Rome, in order to achieve and take place over time, which has so far not been achieved.  Commissioner, I believe that it is time for the European Union to take responsibility for its history, for its culture, for its principles and values, for the Treaties themselves. Let's make no fool of ourselves. It's not just words and proclamations that are enough. The European Union must take a leading and leading role and implement the Treaties and implement gender equality. And the application of gender equality cannot be done without sanctions to those who do not respect and apply it. These sanctions must be imposed and I propose, Commissioner, every three months that the European Parliament be informed of the state of implementation of gender equality by the Member States of the European Union. From this step, from the European Parliament, from the home of democracy, equality, equality and equality. From here, where 500 million European citizens, men and women, are represented and expressed, I proclaim with all the strength of my soul that we will not stop and we will not stop for a moment to fight, to the end, to achieve full gender equality. We will not stop fighting until the gap in shame between men and women is effectively removed and we will not stop fighting until we do not have to be here to discuss gender equality, but we will be here to celebrate gender equality in the European Parliament.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, europe has years to catch up on the gender gap and that this weighs on the shoulders of balanced and rapid development of our continent is expressed in every official document. But the risk is that the gender issue will be well explained in the documents and then not put into practice in the choices and spending guidelines. That is what has happened, unfortunately in recent years. Now, however, this is no longer possible because the pandemic has further compromised women's quality of life. That is why, with 'Half of it', we have called by the right means for targeted and concrete measures on employment and access to credit. We have asked for national plans, the impacts of which on the gender gap are rigorously assessed. We are also aware, Mr President, that repairing the gender gap also means repairing other social and civil gaps, starting with the equality of opportunity that is offered to citizens. It means, in essence, making our countries fairer, better places, and that is why we will not give up.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mrs Komisarko, i would like to thank you for your comments. I am performing on behalf of Polish women who are fighting for their rights, because in Poland, instead of the right to abortion, we have a hell of a woman. Polish women are not protected from violence, earn less than men in the same positions, have lower pensions, do not have the right to fertility treatment, and some do not even have access to a gynecologist. In an even more difficult situation are women with disabilities, older, non-heteronormative, migrant women, women living in the countryside. This is happening in the European Union 25 years after the Beijing Declaration and the Beijing Platform for Action were established.  Commissioner Dalli will probably say that this is not the competence of the European Union. This is a convenient explanation, but how will it help women in Poland? And if you think that this is not the EU's competence, is the Commission working on a package of treaty amendments?  Indeed, every area of women's human rights, including the right to abortion, must be a competence of the Union.

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: Mr President, today we are celebrating the silver anniversary of the Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing, and an anniversary is a moment to look back. Progress has indeed been made in some areas. However, research by the EIGE has shown that this progress is painfully slow and that there is still a lot of work to be done. At the current rate, it would take as many as 60 years for gender inequality to be eliminated. This is unacceptable, especially in the current corona crisis, which affects women proportionately more severely. So we not only have to step up, but above all we have to be careful not to turn back the clock. We must be combative in order to prevent the crisis from being used to reduce achievements in the field of gender, as well as social achievements. I would therefore urge the Commission and the Member States to finally work on the ratification of the Istanbul Convention in order to highlight the gender pay gap and the directive on female drivers and to work to combat gender stereotypes and the rapid transposition of the Directive on work-life balance. Let's not wait for the golden anniversary to do what we have to do.

name: Vera TAX
text: Mr President, we are seeing a hard-hitting measure emerging in the European Union that deprives women of the right to decide on their own mental and physical health. The Polish Government recently decided to deprive women of the right to legal abortion of a foetus that is not viable. An entire government decides to force one woman to have a hopeless pregnancy. The European Parliament and the European Court of Human Rights have ruled on this and found that this infringes on women's human rights. I have also heard that Marta Lempart, the opposition leader who led the protests in Poland, is facing an eight-year prison sentence. This is no coincidence. The opposition in Poland is being silenced step by step. It is now up to the Commission and the Member States to make themselves heard and stand up for women's rights in Poland.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: – Mr President, I’m standing on the shoulders of giants today. Twenty—five years ago, the Beijing Declaration imagined a world in which women and girls could enjoy equal rights and enjoy fully human rights in all fields of life.  But isn’t it strange that something as natural as this sounds like utopia today. Just one example: we may have doubled the number of women in Parliament in the last 25 years, but 90% of heads of governments are still men, and many of these 90% actually behave as if women fighting for parity were a threat to security.  Well, if you are used to male privilege for centuries, equality may feel like discrimination. But let me tell you something, guys – it’s not. It is just women asking for their fair share and, believe me, we will continue to do so and we may even be a bit more vocal and a bit more assertive in the next 25 years. So you may do better just to join us in that fight!

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: – Mr President, when I studied law at the University of Coimbra in the 1970s, there was not a single woman on the faculty, today there are 32, but there is still only one at the top.  When this Parliament was first elected directly in 1979, the percentage of women was 15%, 15.2%, today it is 40.4% and now I have a commissioner on my right and on my left a minister. Much progress has been made since 189 countries unanimously made commitments in Beijing in Beijing in 25 years, but to date none of them have fully fulfilled them and there are many inequalities that need to be tackled. In Europe, for example, 7 million women remain excluded from the labour market compared to 450,000 men because of unpaid care work, a situation aggravated by this crisis. As Hillary Clinton said, as mentioned today, with regard to the Beijing commemorations, it is not enough to enshrine rights on paper. Women must have the power to fight for them in the public and private sector. Now, for example, here in the Union there is a directive for more women on boards in non-executive positions, which is not...  (The President withdraws his floor to the speaker)

name: Terry REINTKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the If the history of the women's movement has shown one thing, it is this: with nice questions we do not get far in the fight against patriarchy, but only with demands, with protest, with strikes, let it matter and again again with a great solidarity also across borders. And that is where we are today. After all, things that already seemed to be won are also being called into question again. Some countries are preparing to oppose the consensus and joint commitment from the Beijing Declaration. And – perfidiously it could not be – in their perverse world, they are supposedly doing so even in the fight for human rights. At the start is the who is who of the haters of women: Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Belarus and, of course, Poland and Hungary – authoritarian regimes together with authoritarian governments in the European Union. I have a message for these governments as it did a hundred years ago, fifty years ago and twenty-five years ago: we will not be intimidated! We will continue to fight for our rights – now more than ever!

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the European Parliament again for putting the Beijing Platform for Action on its agenda. Thank you to the Members too, for their contributions, which really encourage me and fill me with more strength to work even harder so that we won’t have to wait another 25 years to really have equality. Equality between women and men is one of the fundamental values of the European Union. It is part of its DNA since the beginning, so we are, and remain, fully committed to advocating gender equality and ensuring girls’ and women’s empowerment both inside the European Union and worldwide. Looking forward, it is important now more than ever to work together – women and girls, men and boys, politicians, businesses, together with grassroots activists, non-governmental organisations, human rights defenders. Everyone should be on board. We must work on a sound foundation: that of breaking down gender stereotypes and bias and encouraging women and girls to choose their parts without bias – to be decision makers and leaders at all levels and on all topics.  I strongly believe that this is key to the transition to a resilient and competitive economy, and to a more equal world, as we committed to strive for 25 years ago. Again, I thank you for putting this on the agenda and for your contributions.

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for this debate. It was an important debate, an opportune debate, especially when we face so many challenges that are also linked to the pandamic context we are living in. During the Portuguese Presidency of the Council we plan to examine closely the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on gender equality, with a special focus on the labour market. We believe that a fact-based scientific approach is essential. Our work will be based on research by the European Institute for Gender Equality with the aim of working on Council conclusions for approval at the EPSCO Council in June. This is an example of a deliverable in matters of unquestionable value. We will remain vigilant whenever gender equality, the empowerment of women and girls and their full enjoyment of human rights, including health and rights, sexual and reproductive rights, are questioned or threatened. We will work to ensure that the progress that the policies of the European Union and its Member States have brought over these 25 years is protected from any setback. This is a policy that must progress and not regress. And to do that, 25 years after the Beijing Declaration, we need to work together, men and women, Member States, the Council, the Commission, Parliament, to advocate that women and girls can enjoy, without fear, without violence, in freedom, in parity, to enjoy full equality and develop their full potential. We can't wait another 25 years!

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Ladies and gentlemen, this exciting debate is closed and we hope that the declarations will increasingly follow the facts in order to achieve full equality for women.
